Subject: Oh, you can see that house from the outside that house till the present day.
Interviewer: Can you?

Subject: Yes. There’s no doubt that he lived a slightly better life than an average Jew from Gora Kalwaria.  Before the war, if a Jewish resident lived in a room with a kitchen in Gora Kalwaria, he was considered successful. I must say that myself I grew up in one flat. There was a workshop in that flat and in general my mother did her sewing in the workshop.
Interviewer: In a single room?

Subject: In that room. I don’t even want to talk about that. Compared to the present times, that was sad. As far as the tzaddik is concerned, he must have had a number of rooms. The synagogue, still in existence today, was fairly impressive. Nowadays, many pilgrims come from all over the world to see it. Obviously, his followers and not only his followers but Jews in general. This is, they say, proof of recognition of greatness of the tzaddik from Gora Kalwaria.
Interviewer: As the resident of Gora Kalwaria, were you proud that the famous tzaddik lived there? Did you care about it at all?

Subject: As far as, as far as, not only me but, in general, it must be said that all residents of Gora Kalwaria, we were maybe not proud, but we were all pleased because Gora Kalwaria during those holidays, as I stressed in the beginning, Yom Kippur, Rosh Hashanah and Shavuot, many people came to Gora Kalwaria.  Please note that [the pilgrims] rented flats there from poorer people. Among others, even though it was a single room my mother rented it out to earn a little money. And, among other things, the town hall also made some money as those who came to Gora Kalwaria had to pay one zloty per head to the town hall. During that that time when, let’s say that up to two thousand [pilgrims] arrived, the estimates would be larger. Not true. Because Gora Kalwaria had 7,000 residents and it could not accommodate more that than up to 2,000 persons. Because where would those people stay? [Inaudible]. They supplemented the state budget, which is the budget of Gora Kalwaria. The mayor was a very righteous man by the name of Dziejko[?] who was truly held in high esteem by all Jews, not only by us. He was also a philosemite. For instance, he insisted that Jews put forward their own candidates for councillors during the election to the town council. We also had a very good police chief, in the final years. His name was Janica. It needs to be said that he, unfortunately, Gora Kalwaria also went through different times when Falanga [ultranationalist, patriotic and antisemitic political movement in Poland] was active in the years 1937-8. In 1939, the war psychosis was already there, and such excesses were less common. But the Jewish stands at fairs were still being destroyed and [people were told] ‘don’t buy from a Jew’. And they came from nearby towns like Warka, Grojec, Karczew or Otwock. The police chief stressed, ‘Watch out Jews, you mustn't give in, defend yourselves by any means. That police chief, he was just a very good man. Unfortunately, he died in Katyn. The entire population deplored the fact that he had been killed there. We couldn’t help him in any way because during that time who would... nobody even knew it. He had left Gora Kalwaria like all policemen who went east and died there, the poor soul. We mourn his death till the present day. Whoever remembers Janica, mourns his death. Now, as far as I’m concerned, well, at the time...
Interviewer: Please tell us what were the relations between the local Jewish and Polish communities like in general?

Subject: As regards those relations, like I stressed, they were very good. Very good. When it comes to anti-Semitism, Gora Kalwaria did not know... did not experience anti-Semitism at all. There was no such thing. No, in general, anti-Semitism was not present among the residents of Gora Kalwaria.
Interviewer: Was Polish spoken at your home?
Subject: At our home?
Interviewer: At home.
Subject: Was Polish spoken? We spoke both Polish and Yiddish.
Interviewer: And what was your first language?
Subject: Yiddish, of course.
Interviewer: Yiddish.

Subject: Yiddish. No doubt about that. But afterward, as part of my upbringing, because a lot of persons lived in our immediate neighbourhood, almost 50 per cent of Poles and 50 per cent of Jews. So, I had friends like Bronek Wozniak, Jozek, like Olek Rytko and, in general, Maniek Jarosz. As I underline with all respect due to those persons, when, for example, I came back from that misfortune, I mean, the area where I was kept in hiding, I went to Mr. Rytko first. His first name was Franciszek, a shoemaker. By the way, he kept various Jewish books safe. That was a big thing, really big. He even kept a photo of my grandfather. He stored things that nobody could even imagine. He was not afraid. He had kept them safe, and he later returned everything to me and I, in turn, took them to Warsaw to the Religious Congregation in 1946.
Interviewer: And in school? I understand that you said there were Polish and Jewish boys.
Subject: Yes, yes, less, less.
Interviewer: There were more Jews at that school?

Subject: I cannot [inaudible]. There were less Jewish boys, very few. Of course, children from those progressive Jewish families went to the Polish school. But those from the Hasidic families did not really. Instead, teachers would go to their homes, teach them in Polish but [such pupils] were few. There were more girls, more girls went to the Polish elementary school.
Interviewer: I see. Please tell us something about your siblings. You had a sister and a brother?
Subject: I had a sister. Well, a sister. And my brother was shot dead.
Interviewer: No but in the period before the war, they, you were the oldest child?

Subject: My sister completed seven classes of elementary school in Gora Kalwaria before the war, just like me. I say elementary because I use the post-war language. It used to be called the common school. She was a very good pupil. She was very gifted because, in general, once she had graduated, she travelled to Warsaw. She worked at 14 Radzyminska Street. There was a small soap factory and she kept accounting ledgers for them. She was a diligent student. I was a mediocre pupil. I mean I had very good grades in Polish, history and German. I was not that good at maths, but I never had to repeat a grade. I was no trouble at all. Yes.
Interviewer: And your brother?

Subject: My brother completed the same number of grades as me. My brother completed six grades, just like me. Till the seventh grade, the same as me, he went, I was already in the army at the time, he was an apprentice saddler. No, I wasn’t in the army yet because I was still working as a apprentice tailor. And he was training to become a saddler. He was a saddler. With Poloniecki.
Interviewer: I understand. Please tell me what year were you called up to join the army?
Subject: In 1937.
Interviewer: So you were 21 at the time?

Subject: In nineteen [thirty-seven], yes, yes. Nineteen [thirty-seven], I joined the army on November 4th, I went to Suwalki.  It was, it was an elite regiment, 3rd Cavalry Regiment. There were only three such units in Poland. The 1st Cavalry Regiment was stationed in Szwolezerow Street in Warsaw, it was named, because this will not [inaudible] just like that after Jozef Pilsudski. The 2nd Cavalry Regiment was based in Starogard Gdanski, its commander was..., named after Dwernicki. And the 3rd Cavalry Regiment was in Suwalki, named after Jan Hipolit Kozietulski, the one who had captured the Somosierra mountain pass.
Interviewer: Somosierra.
Subject: Yes.
Interviewer: And you were in Suwalki?

Subject: That regiment was stationed in Suwalki. Of course, as I was a fairly capable soldier, I was selected to join a military academy for non-commissioned officers. I graduated from that academy. I completed an eight-month assignment in the same regiment. I was promoted to a corporal at the end of it. Afterward, instead of returning home in 1939... unfortunately, the war broke out in September.  Then
Interviewer: Before we get there, please tell me you were, I mean, you joined the cavalry regiment.
Subject: Yes, I did.
Interviewer: I mean you were one of few Jews in the unit? Or were there many?
Subject: There were four of us, four Jews, yes, not four but in each squadron, there were four persons of Jewish heritage.
Interviewer: Why? Such were the guidelines?
Subject: Well, that’s how it was exactly, whether there was a limit in general or not, I wouldn’t know that.
Interviewer: It could have been a coincidence.

Subject: That’s how it was more or less. There were 4 squadrons and there were four Jews in each and every squadron. In my squadron, there was myself, Henryk Prajs [Prais], Jan Kylberg, Jakub Feldman and the fourth one was... I don’t remember the fourth one.
Interviewer: You don’t remember. What were you relations with fellow soldiers?

Subject: They were very good. I was much liked. I can stress it hundred per cent till the present day. Among others, I had a friend called Jozef Wolski during the war. When we were on the frontline, we would tell one another, ‘Listen Heniek, if you make it through the war and I’m killed, let my family know’. He lived near the town of Sieradz.  He said, ‘If I’m killed, let my family know’. Afterward, we split obviously because I followed the squadron in the direction in the direction in the south direction as we were told to go through Czerwony Bor.
Interviewer: But you’re already talking about the war period, aren’t you?
Subject: The war period.
Interviewer: So let’s concentrate on your military service. When you came, for instance, home on leave, to Gora Kalwaria, did you stay for long and how was it?

Subject: Yes, very much so. I was well respected and admired. [My uniform] would turn heads. I was a cavalryman and, as such, I stood out because soldiers from other formations would wear four-cornered caps and we were issued with round caps with yellow headbands. So, I was proudly carrying a sabre. Well, this is all I can say [inaudible].
Interviewer: Was there a rabbi in these cavalry units?

Subject: Yes, there was. There was a rabbi, but he was one for the entire brigade, the Bialystok brigade or rather a garrison not a brigade because the brigade was the autonomous Suwalki brigade. No, it was just the Bialystok garrison. It was a rabbi with a grade of captain by the name of... I don’t recall his surname. But he was there. He would come to our unit to hold religious, of course, but also social and even political discussions. He said that Jews had to be loyal to the state because the state came first, the army came first. He would celebrate a service every Sunday. Every Sunday, they would take us to a synagogue for a prayer with the rabbi.
Interviewer: On Sunday and not on Saturday?
Subject: Every Sunday, not Saturday, on Sunday only. Catholics were led to a Catholic church, Russian Orthodox soldiers to a Russian Orthodox church, Protestants to a kirche, and Jews to a synagogue.
Interviewer: What do you mean by ‘led’? You mean you walked?
Subject: Yes, they led us, every unit had a senior officer who would lead the group. There were also four Germans only and four Protestants as well.
Interviewer: And if you didn’t want to go to the synagogue or...
Subject: It was not compulsory, no.
Interviewer: We were not coerced.

Subject: No, no. That was not compulsory. The same during the morning prayer. If the ‘Kiedy ranne wstają zorze’ [When morning dawn is breaking] song was sung in the morning and the ‘Wszystkie nasze dzienne sprawy...’ [All our daily matters] song in the evening. The Jews were not obliged [to join in]. Whoever wished to join the ranks, could do so. If not, they could step out and step away. That was [inaudible].
Interviewer: As I understand it, the life of a Jewish soldier was very similar to the life of a Polish soldier.

Subject: Very much so, very much so. There was no difference at all during the drills. Similarly, if you were capable, you would be distinguished in the same way as anybody else. In general, you did not feel any different in the military at all.
Interviewer: How long was military service during that time? Two years?
Subject: Two years.
Interviewer: Two years. Because you enlisted in 1937. You were supposed to serve until...
Subject: In 1937. I was twenty-one.
Interviewer: Yes, you were.
Subject: Almost 21 because I celebrate my anniversary on December 30th, but this is irrelevant. Yes, what counts only is the month, the year counts.
Interviewer: So you mean you were supposed to join the army reserve in 1939?
Subject: I was meant to join the reserve as soon as 1939.
Interviewer: Meaning that war caught you already...
Subject: War caught me right away precisely in [inaudible] instead. From the very start, right away, our regiment.
Interviewer: You were a soldier when the war broke out?
Subject: Yes, I was. I was in active duty. I held the rank of a corporal. Yes.
Interviewer: What was the atmosphere like in the town of Kalwaria, in Gora Kalwaria before the war?

Subject: It’s hard to say because I was no longer there during that period. But the same psychosis was felt everywhere. Everybody was aware of it in general. When I returned to Gora Kalwaria during that period, in December [1939], everybody already thought that I had been killed. I could not let them know because I was in captivity, I was interned by the Russians in... in Russia.
Interviewer: Am I to understand that people felt, well, it was clear to them since summer 1939 that the war would break out?

Subject: Yes, we knew that too in our regiment because, as I wrote it in my memoirs, because we were surprised because when it comes to Beck’s speech. I no longer recall if it was in March or when he said that [inaudible], we knew already. In the army, we felt that the mood was changing. We were already issued with helmets. Some of us went to dig those...
Interviewer: Trenches.

Subject: Trenches. We laid barbed wire, so we felt it. And later, just as all over Poland, we, like everybody in the country, it was clear, we are even I even mentioned that in my memoirs that Beck [Polish minister of foreign affairs] had said that not only we would not give up Gdansk but we would not part with a button from our uniforms. But, unfortunately, during the war we learned that it was, how do you say it, that it was not real.  I’m not going to talk about the other...
Interviewer: As a Polish soldier, did you firmly believe in victory and in the great superiority of the Polish armed forces at the time?

Subject: We did not believe in victory maybe but in [fighting] spirit, and each of us simply felt strong attachment to our homeland. At the time, we marched firmly convinced that we would defeat the enemy. Additionally, when England and France declared war on Germany, we actually thought that we would win and that we would not give in.  Well, it turned out otherwise later on. Well.

Interviewer: What was primarily your and your fellow Jews’ attitude [toward] Germans and what were your concerns? What I mean really is whether your and your fellow soldiers’ attitude toward Germans was different from Poles’ attitude toward Germans?

Subject: In the regiment itself, I can confidently say that there was no difference in 100%. I had fellow soldiers who were Protestants- Bertold, Zoller, Pratz[?] and Mann. I recall their names clearly. We lived together very well.
Interviewer: Yes, but...
Subject: In the regiment, at the time when we were living in the barracks.
Interviewer: It’s not what I meant. In 1933, Hitler came to power.
Subject: And one has to say that those Germans stayed [with the regiment] till the very end. No, no, they didn’t betray us.
Interviewer: I see.

Subject: The Germans stayed with us till the very end, when Poland, we, our regiment surrendered. They stayed until the last moment. However, when we had moved east all Ukrainians and Belarusians deserted.
Interviewer: I understand but today from the perspective of 50 and more years from the war’s breakout, it’s being said, firstly, when Hitler came to power in 1933...
Subject: That’s right.
Interviewer: That all Jews, majority of Jews sort of knew what Hitler had in store for them. With that in mind, I would like to ask you whether... for instance, you were 17 in 1933, weren’t you?
Subject: Yes. No. Older.
Interviewer: You were older, 16 or 17. After the Zbaszyn incident. After the Diamond Night, Kristallnacht, were your concerns about the Germans greater than those of your Polish friends?

Subject: There’s no doubt that at the time no Jews, I emphasize, nobody, imagined that something like that would happen, even in Germany. We knew about that night; we were aware of persecutions. We heard about Mein Kampf, the book he had published. And, in general, it needs to be said that many people were already emigrating back in 1930s and not only in Poland.  There were kibbutzs in Gora Kalwaria, too. I myself belonged to Hapoel.  I was a member of Polaei Tziyon.  We were all thinking of emigrating, but emigrating was not that easy. First of all, the certificate was hard to come by. It really was. Had we all known what was going to happen, there is no doubt whatsoever that we all would have emigrated to Israel or elsewhere. Maybe not all because older people would have probably stayed behind. But then who could have imagined that something like that would happen. This is what it’s all about.
Interviewer: I understand but you mentioned that you had sort of a Zionist orientation, you were a member of Hashomer Hatzair. Is that the worldview that you had from your teenage years?
Subject: From my youngest years... since I was 13, I was part of it.  I was first a scout and then a regular member.
Interviewer: You mean Hatzair or?
Subject: No, Poalei Tziyon.
Interviewer: Poalei Tziyon. Yes?
Subject: The right wing of Poalei Tziyon. Right.
Interviewer: Right?
Subject: Yes, Ber Borochov’s. A supporter of Ber Borochov.
Interviewer: And that organization was large in Gora Kalwaria?

Subject: In general, there were various organizations in Gora Kalwaria. There was the Communist party, there was also Bund, Bund was the smallest party, and the Zionists were those, including the Mizrahi movement, who were part of the Orthodox Jews, there was Shomer Haleumi, Herzl’s organization, right-wing Zionists and, effectively, Poalei Tziyon, just the right wing of Poalei Tziyon. There was no left wing of Poalei Tziyon.
Gora K
Interviewer: And you had been a member of that organization until the time you joined the army?
Subject: I was a member of that organization. That’s correct.
Interviewer: Until, until you enlisted?
Subject: Until I joined the army.
Interviewer: Good. [inaudible].
Subject: My friends even came out to send me off.
Interviewer: Let’s have a short break.
Good. So we can now talk freely.
Right now?
I mean no, it’s just for...
When they say so, I will speak normally, yes, obviously, I’m touched, there’s no doubt, it’s not on yet, I think…
No, no.

Here we go.
00:01:03I come from a small town situated to the south of Warsaw. It’s called Gora Kalwaria . Like in all small towns in Poland, there was a fairly large Jewish community living in Gora Kalwaria. One can say that Gora Kalwaria was inhabited by Catholics in 50% and Jews in 50%. However, Gora Kalwaria differed from other towns... small provincial towns in that it was where the famous tzaddik from the Alter family lived and where very large conventions took place. Especially for holidays such as Yom Kippur, Rosh Hashanah, that is the New Year and Shavuot. Very many people would then come to Gora Kalwaria on a pilgrimage to see that tzaddik. That was precisely what distinguished Gora Kalwaria from other towns in Poland.
I’m very sorry. Can you tell us your name, please?
Sure. My name is Henryk Prajs Prais. I was born in Gora Kalwaria. I am 78 as we speak.
You were born in the year one thousand…

In what year? One thousand nine hundred and sixteen, 30 December 1916. That’s more or less it. I was born in a poor family. I cannot say we were rich because I didn’t have a father at all. My father  was killed by bandits, specifically bandits. It was a mugging, in nineteen twenty-one, I think, or twenty-two. I was very young. How old could I have been at the time? Well inaudible, I could have been two or three years old, no more than that. So this could have even been in 1918, yes. So I don’t remember my father. I was raised. We were three children. Our mother was a seamstress. She tried very hard to give us any minimum education she could in the form of elementary school. At the time, it was called common school. I went to school as soon as I turned seven. I have very fond memories of my school time. Teachers were very friendly to us, in general to Jewish children. Overall, Gora Kalwaria was specific as there was no anti-Semitism during the pre-war period. The Polish and Jewish communities lived very well together.
Do you come from a religious family?
Myself? No. I come from a non-religious family. Mine was a progressive Jewish family. So it was.
OK.

So I was not a Hasidic Jew. I was normal like any other Jewish child. I attended the Polish general elementary education school and at the same time I learned Jewish language at the Jewish school, the so-called heder. Simultaneously, I learned some Hebrew as it was called at the time and ivrit at present. It used to be called Hebrew. This is how I have come to know some Hebrew. I was a fairly good student as far as it was possible. I completed 6 grades of elementary... general education school. I could not continue schooling because my family did not have enough money. We did not have money so I learned... I learned the profession of a tailor. I studied it for a few years. Later...
But where? Also in Gora Kalwaria?
Yes, in Gora Kalwaria. My master tailor’s name was Cybula. Precisely Cybula, that was his name.
He was a Pole?

No, he was Jewish, yes. I learned the profession there, I worked as his apprentice for maybe three years. Afterwards, I worked for Gorecki who was a Catholic. Gorecki. I don’t even recall his first name but his last name was Gorecki. I worked in his workshop for 2 years probably and I also worked for Jasinski for 2 years as a tailor. And then came the army period.
Please tell me one more thing, you were talking about Gorka Kalwaria, how many residents were there when you were born and during your childhood?

How many residents were there? Overall, Gora Kalwaria had approx. 7,000 residents. Of those, there were some 3,000 Jews and some 4,000 Poles. I mean in total Gora Kalwaria with the, how do you call them, sub....
With peripheries?
Yes yes but they are called, sub.. no, not an auberge, it’s called, you know those, those, not just Gora Kalwaria but those
Peripheries?
Right, peripheries, no but
Mountains
may, may, may be that could be it, maybe
Outskirts of Gora Kalwaria,
Oh, yes, this is what I meant.
So there were 3,000 Jewish residents?
How many were there? That’s correct.
Three thousand. And what were  theorientations among them? As far as I understand, there was, after all, a very strong Hasidic group.

Well, there were very many craftsmen. Among other things, I wrote so in my memoirs. Predominantly Gora Kalwaria because there were no factories at the time, none. There were just small shops and craftsmen, namely tailoring, shoe-making, boot-making, knit cap making, saddle-making and such, as well as carpentry and baking. This is what the whole of Gora Kalwaria was made of because no other (...)
How many religious Jews, Hasidic Jews, were there?

Religious ones? When it comes to religious Jews, there were few. I mean there were more progressive Jews the way I described it, simple Jews. As our great writer, Sholom Aleichem,  once wrote: ‘we come from folk’. Those Jews were religious, no doubt they were religious, but they were progressive. They did not wear those Orthodox clothes but dressed normally like Europeans.  Jews, those Hasidic Jews could have been in Gora Kalwaria (...) if there were three thousand Jews, roughly 1,000 were followers but no, not followers of Gora, not followers of the tzaddik, let me stress that, but just regular followers of Hasidic Judaism.
Various orientations

Yes, yes, yes, different orientations because just like they were part of, they had their rabbi in Kozienice,  in Klodzko  and in Gora Kalwaria there were also, I mean there were supporters of that tzaddik from Gora Kalwaria.
And how many supporters were there of that tzaddik from Gora Kalwaria, more or less?
Well, I can say that there were no more than five hundred.
Five hundred.
He did not have more than 500 followers in Gora Kalwaria.
Because you are aware that looking at it today, Gora Kalwaria Chasidism are undoubtedly among the main groups in Israel and America.

Yes, one of the main groups, and that’s because Jews, predominantly orthodox Jewscame to Gora Kalwaria from all over Poland. Actually, a lot of Jews from Lodz,  very many, from Krakow  and in general from all cities in Poland came to Gora Kalwaria to the tzaddik and that’s where his greatness comes from. There is no doubt about that. He was a wise man because very many and even Catholics came to him with various questions, with different how to say it, how to define it
Questions, kushiyot.
How?
Puzzles, questions, problems.

No, no, questions but still you can say it differently, you can define it differently, guidance, sort of guidance, guidance in general they wanted to do this and that with his knowledge. Among others, there was that well known resident of Gora Kalwaria. His last name was Lech. I don’t recall his first name. He never did anything without the approval of the tzaddik from Gora Kalwaria. Whether he wanted to build or buy something, he always had to come specifically to the tzaddik for advice, yes, advice.
Did you meet that tzaddik in the street?
Lech?
No, the tzaddik from Gora Kalwaria, Elster Alter?
The tzaddik, he never ventured out, he didn’t make an appearance.
He didn’t go out.

No, he did not walk around Gora Kalwaria. He did not come out. However, for his followers, he would stroll back and forth on his balcony for 10 or 15 minutes for his followers every Saturday at 3pm. He came out for them. He never spoke a word just made an appearance. His followers stood in the yard and watched him. Obviously, they were happy to be able to see the tzaddik
And what did his house look like?
Pardon?
What did that tzaddik’s house look like?
What did his house look like? I hardly...
What I meant is, from the outside, was the house large or small?
Oh, you can see that house from the outside that house till the present day.
Can you?

Yes, There’s no doubt that he lived a slightly better life than an average Jew from Gora Kalwaria.  Before the war, if a Jewish resident lived in a room with a kitchen in Gora Kalwaria, he was considered successful. I must say that myself I grew up in one flat. There was a workshop in that flat and in general my mother did her sewing in the workshop.
In a single room?

In that room. I don’t even want to talk about that. Compared to the present times, that was sad. As far as the tzaddik is concerned, he must have had a number of rooms. The synagogue, still in existence today, was fairly impressive. Nowadays, many pilgrims come from all over the world to see it. Obviously, his followers and not only his followers but Jews in general. This is, they say, proof of recognition of greatness of the tzaddik from Gora Kalwaria.
As the resident of Gora Kalwaria, were you proud that the famous tzaddik lived there? Did you care about it at all?

As far as, as far as, not only me but, in general, it must be said that all residents of Gora Kalwaria, we were maybe not proud but we were all pleased because Gora Kalwaria during those holidays, as I stressed in the beginning, Yom Kippur, Rosh Hashanah and Shavuot, many people came to Gora Kalwaria.  Please note that the pilgrims rented flats there from poorer people. Among others, even though it was a single room my mother rented it out to earn a little money. And, among other things, the town hall also made some money as those who came to Gora Kalwaria had to pay one zloty per head to the town hall. During that that time when, let’s say that up to two thousand pilgrims arrived, the estimates would be larger. Not true. Because Gora Kalwaria had 7,000 residents and it could not accommodate more that than up to 2,000 persons. Because where would those people stay? Inaudible . They supplemented the state budget, that is the budget of Gora Kalwaria. The mayor was a very righteous man by the name of Dziejko ? who was truly held in high esteem by all Jews, not only by us. He was also a philosemite. For instance, he insisted that Jews put forward their own candidates for councillors during the election to the town council. We also had a very good police chief, in the final years. His name was Janica. It needs to be said that he, unfortunately, Gora Kalwaria also went through different times when Falanga  ultranationalist, patriotic and antisemitic political movement in Poland was active in the years 1937-8. In 1939, the war psychosis was already there and such excesses were less common. But the Jewish stands at fairs were still being destroyed and people were told ‘don’t buy from a Jew’. And they came from nearby towns like Warka, Grojec, Karczew or Otwock.  The police chief stressed: ‘Watch out Jews, you mustn't give in, defend yourselves by any means’. That police chief, he was just a very good man. Unfortunately, he died in Katyn.  The entire population deplored the fact that he had been killed there. We couldn’t help him in any way because during that time who would... nobody even knew it. He had left Gora Kalwaria like all policemen who went east and died there, the poor soul. We mourn his death till the present day. Whoever remembers Janica, mourns his death. Now, as far as I’m concerned, well, at the time...
Please tell us what were the relations between the local Jewish and Polish communities like in general?

As regards those relations, like I stressed, they were very good. Very good. When it comes to anti-Semitism, Gora Kalwaria did not know... did not experience anti-Semitism at all. There was no such thing. No, in general, anti-Semitism was not present among the residents of Gora Kalwaria.
Was Polish spoken at your home?
At our home?
At home.
Was Polish spoken? We spoke both Polish and Yiddish.
And what was your first language?
Yiddish, of course.
Yiddish.

No doubt about that. But afterward, as part of my upbringing, because a lot of persons lived in our immediate neighbourhood, almost 50 per cent of Poles and 50 per cent of Jews. So I had friends like Bronek Wozniak, Jozek, like Olek Rytko and, in general, Maniek Jarosz. As I underline with all respect due to those persons, when, for example, I came back from that misfortune, I mean, the area where I was kept in hiding, I went to Mr. Rytko first. His first name was Franciszek, a shoemaker. By the way, he kept various Jewish books safe. That was a big thing, really big. He even kept a photo of my grandfather. He stored things that nobody could even imagine. He was not afraid. He had kept them safe and he later returned everything to me and I, in turn, took them to Warsaw to the Religious Congregation in 1946.
And in school? I understand that you said there were Polish and Jewish boys.
Yes, yes, less, less.
There were more Jews at that school?

I cannot inaudible. There were less Jewish boys, very few. Of course, children from those progressive Jewish families went to the Polish school. But those from the Hasidic families did not really. Instead, teachers would go to their homes, teach them in Polish but such pupils were few. There were more girls, more girls went to the Polish elementary school.
I see. Please tell us something about your siblings. You had a sister and a brother?
I had a sister. Well, a sister. And my brother was shot dead.
No but in the period before the war, they, you were the oldest child?

My sister completed seven classes of elementary school in Gora Kalwaria before the war, just like me. I say elementary because I use the post-war language. It used to be called the common school. She was a very good pupil. She was very gifted because, in general, once she had graduated, she travelled to Warsaw. She worked at 14 Radzyminska Street. There was a small soap factory and she kept accounting ledgers for them. She was a diligent student. I was a mediocre pupil. I mean I had very good grades in Polish, history and German. I was not that good at maths but I never had to repeat a grade. I was no trouble at all. Yes.
And your brother?

My brother completed the same  number of grades as me. My brother completed six grades, just like me. Till the seventh grade, the same as me, he went, I was already in the army at the time, he was a apprentice saddler. No, I wasn’t in the army yet because I was still working as a apprentice tailor. And he was training to become a saddler. He was a saddler. With Poloniecki.
I understand. Please tell me what year were you called up to join the army?
So you were 21 at the time?

In nineteen thirty-seven, yes, yes. Nineteen thirty-seven, I joined the army on November 4th, I went to Suwalki.  It was, it was an elite regiment, 3rd Cavalry Regiment. There were only three such units in Poland. The 1st Cavalry Regiment was stationed in Szwolezerow Street in Warsaw, it was named, because this will not inaudible just like that after Jozef Pilsudski. The 2nd Cavalry Regiment was based in Starogard Gdanski, its commander was..., named after Dwernicki. And the 3rd Cavalry Regiment was in Suwalki, named after Jan Hipolit Kozietulski, the one who had captured the Somosierra mountain pass.
Somosierra.
Yes.
And you were in Suwalki?

That regiment was stationed in Suwalki. Of course, as I was a fairly capable soldier, I was selected to join a military academy for non-commissioned officers. I graduated from that academy. I completed an eight-month assignment in the same regiment. I was promoted to a corporal at the end of it. Afterward, instead of returning home in 1939... unfortunately, the war broke out in September.  Then
Before we get there, please tell me you were, I mean, you joined the cavalry regiment.
Yes, I did.
I mean you were one of few Jews in the unit? Or were there many?
There were four of us, four Jews, yes, not four but in each squadron there were four persons of Jewish heritage.
Why? Such were the guidelines?
Well, that’s how it was exactly, whether there was a limit in general or not, I wouldn’t know that.
It could have been a coincidence.

That’s how it was more or less. There were 4 squadrons and there were four Jews in each and every squadron. In my squadron, there was myself, Henryk Prajs Prais, Jan Kylberg, Jakub Feldman and the fourth one was... I don’t remember the fourth one.
You don’t remember. What were you relations with fellow soldiers?

They were very good. I was much liked. I can stress it hundred per cent till the present day. Among others, I had a friend called Jozef Wolski during the war. When we were on the frontline, we would tell one another: ‘Listen Heniek, if you make it through the war and I’m killed, let my family know’. He lived near the town of Sieradz.  He said: ‘If I’m killed, let my family know’. Afterward, we split obviously because I followed the squadron in the direction in the direction in the south direction as we were told to go through Czerwony Bor.
But you’re already talking about the war period, aren’t you?
The war period.
So let’s concentrate on your military service. When you came, for instance, home on leave, to Gora Kalwaria, did you stay for long and how was it?

Yes, very much so. I was well respected and admired. My uniform would turn heads. I was a cavalryman and, as such, I stood out because soldiers from other formations would wear four-cornered caps and we were issued with round caps with yellow headbands. So, I was proudly carrying a sabre. Well, this is all I can say inaudible
Was there a rabbi in these cavalry units?

Yes, there was. There was a rabbi but he was one for the entire brigade, the Bialystok brigade or rather a garrison not a brigade because the brigade was the autonomous Suwalki brigade. No, it was just the Bialystok garrison. It was a rabbi with a grade of captain by the name of... I don’t recall his surname. But he was there. He would come to our unit to hold religious, of course, but also social and even political discussions. He said that Jews had to be loyal to the state because the state came first, the army came first. He would celebrate a service every Sunday. Every Sunday, they would take us to a synagogue for a prayer with the rabbi.
On Sunday and not on Saturday?
Every Sunday, not Saturday, on Sunday only. Catholics were led to a Catholic church, Russian Orthodox soldiers to a Russian Orthodox church,  Protestants to a kirche,  and Jews to a synagogue.
What do you mean by ‘led’? You mean you walked?
Yes, they led us, every unit had a senior officer who would lead the group. There were also four Germans only and four Protestants as well.
And if you didn’t want to go to the synagogue or...
It was not compulsory, no.
We were not coerced.

No, no. That was not compulsory. The same during the morning prayer. If the ‘Kiedy ranne wstają zorze’ When morning dawn is breaking song was sung in the morning and the ‘Wszystkie nasze dzienne sprawy…’ All our daily matters song in the evening. The Jews were not obliged to join in. Whoever wished to join the ranks, could do so. If not, they could step out and step away. That was inaudible
As I understand it, the life of a Jewish soldier was very similar to the life of a Polish soldier.

Very much so, very much so. There was no difference at all during the drills. Similarly, if you were capable, you would be distinguished in the same way as anybody else. In general, you did not feel any different in the military at all.
How long was military service during that time? Two years?
Two years.
Because you enlisted in 1937. You were supposed to serve until...
In 1937. I was twenty-one.
Yes, you were.
Almost 21 because I celebrate my anniversary on December 30th but this is irrelevant. Yes, what counts only is the month, the year counts.
So you mean you were supposed to join the army reserve in 1939?
I was meant to join the reserve as soon as 1939.
Meaning that war caught you already...
War caught me right away precisely in  inaudible instead. From the very start, right away, our regiment
You were a soldier when the war broke out?
Yes, I was. I was in active duty. I held the rank of a corporal. Yes.
What was the atmosphere like in the town of Kalwaria, in Gora Kalwaria before the war?

It’s hard to say because I was no longer there during that period. But the same psychosis was felt everywhere. Everybody was aware of it in general. When I returned to Gora Kalwaria during that period, in December 1939, everybody already thought that I had been killed. I could not let them know because I was in captivity, I was interned by the Russians in... in Russia.
Am I to understand that people felt, well, it was clear to them since summer 1939 that the war would break out?

Yes, we knew that too in our regiment because, as I wrote it in my memoirs, because we were surprised because when it comes to Beck’s speech. I no longer recall if it was in March or when he said that inaudible, we knew already. In the army, we felt that the mood was changing. We were already issued with helmets. Some of us went to dig those
Trenches

. We laid barbed wire so we felt it. And later, just as all over Poland, we, like everybody in the country, it was clear, we even I even mentioned that in my memoirs that Beck  Polish minister of foreign affairs had said that not only we would not give up Gdansk but we would not part with a button from our uniforms. But, unfortunately, during the war we learned that it was, how do you say it, that it was not real.  I’m not going to talk about the other...
As a Polish soldier, did you firmly believe in victory and in the great superiority of the Polish armed forces at the time?

We did not believe in victory maybe but in fighting spirit, and each of us simply felt strong attachment to our homeland. At the time, we marched firmly convinced that we would defeat the enemy. Additionally, when England and France declared war on Germany, we actually thought that we would win and that we would not give in.  Well, it turned out otherwise later on. Well.

What was primarily your and your fellow Jews’ attitude toward Germans and what were your concerns? What I mean really is whether your and your fellow soldiers’ attitude toward Germans was different from Poles’ attitude toward Germans?

In the regiment itself, I can confidently say that there was no difference in 100%. I had fellow soldiers who were Protestants: Bertold, Zoller, Pratz ? and Mann. I recall their names clearly. We lived together very well.
Yes, but...
In the regiment, at the time when we were living in the barracks.
It’s not what I meant. In 1933, Hitler came to power.
And one has to say that those Germans stayed with the regiment till the very end. No, no, they didn’t betray us.
I see.
The Germans stayed with us till the very end, when Poland, we, our regiment surrendered. They stayed until the last moment. However, when we had moved east all Ukrainians and Belarusians deserted.
I understand but today from the perspective of 50 and more years from the war’s breakout, it’s being said, firstly, when Hitler came to power in 1933...
That’s right.
That all Jews, majority of Jews sort of knew what Hitler had in store for them. With that in mind, I would like to ask you whether... for instance, you were 17 in 1933, weren’t you?
Yes. No. Older.
You were older: 16 or 17. After the Zbaszyn incident. After the Diamond Night, Kristallnacht, were your concerns about the Germans greater than those of your Polish friends?

There’s no doubt that at the time no Jews, I emphasize, nobody, imagined that something like that would happen, even in Germany. We knew about that night, we were aware of persecutions. We heard about Mein Kampf, the book he had published. And, in general, it needs to be said that many people were already emigrating back in 1930s and not only in Poland.  There were kibbutzs in Gora Kalwaria, too. I myself belonged to Hapoel.  I was a member of Polaei Tziyon.  We were all thinking of emigrating but emigrating was not that easy. First of all, the certificate was hard to come by. It really was. Had we all known what was going to happen, there is no doubt whatsoever that we all would have emigrated to Israel or elsewhere. Maybe not all because older people would have probably stayed behind. But then who could have imagined that something like that would happen. This is what it’s all about.
I understand but you mentioned that you had sort of a Zionist orientation, you were a member of Hashomer Hatzair. Is that the worldview that you had from your teenage years?
From my youngest years... since I was 13 I was part of it.  I was first a scout and then a regular member.
You mean Hatzair or?
No, Poalei Tziyon.
Poalei Tziyon. Yes?
The right wing of Poalei Tziyon. Right.
Right?
Yes, Ber Borochov’s. A supporter of Ber Borochov.
And that organization was large in Gora Kalwaria?

In general, there were various organizations in Gora Kalwaria. There was the Communist party, there was also Bund, Bund was the smallest party, and the Zionists were those, including the Mizrahi movement, who were part of the Orthodox Jews, there was Shomer Haleumi, Herzl’s organization, right-wing Zionists and, effectively, Poalei Tziyon, just the right wing of Poalei Tziyon. There was no  left wing of Poalei Tziyon.
And you had been a member of that organization until the time you joined the army?
I was a member of that organization. That’s correct.
Until, until you enlisted?
Until I joined the army.
Good. inaudible
My friends even came out to send me off.

Segment 11

In July 1940 I did not have to move because my building was in the ghetto but there came others and we had to accept them. Some families from the neighboring villages came to Gora Kalwaria too. Dominikanska street, the market place, Strazacka street and part of Pijarska street and Kalwaryjska street were the ghetto borders. It was not closed completely, there was barbed wire on one side in Strazacka street (so that people could not cross the Wisla River) but there were streets which went through the ghetto and they were not closed but Jews were told they would be killed if they went outside the ghetto. There were no gates. I lived in Pilsudskiego street. Catholics lived in the same building:  Wozniak, Rytko and Jarosz and they had to leave their apartments and go to Jewish apartments while Jews came to live in their apartments. In my small apartment (5 metres by 6 metres [ 17 feet by 20 feet]) there were five people: my family and someone from the countryside sent by Judenrat.

There was typhus because there were sometimes 10 people in very small apartments, lack of food, the poor people ate soup and a piece of bread offered by Judenrat. Richer people had to give contributions because a bath was to be built for Jews. When the bath was ready Jews were deported to Warsaw. There were Jewish police but they did not beat people and  only came to apartments and took to work people selected by Judenrat.

Next to our apartment there was a closet and this additional person sent by Judenrat slept there. We were not allowed to leave the ghetto, people were not allowed to visit us, we could do no work apart from the forced labor, we were hungry. A lot of people died, at that time Germans still allowed to go to the cemetery and bury the dead.

When I came back to Gora Kalwaria a lot of Catholics friends visited me, Joziek Lewandowski used to give me firewood, a lot of them sympathized with me. Even in 1940  they brought wood or potatoes. My family and I were not hungry although it was not that we had plenty, but we had potatoes or groats [Polish "kasza"=kasha]. We even were able to sustain the man who lived with us thanks to my Catholic friends, Poles.

In July 1940 it was different. Poles were not allowed to enter the ghetto. Some Jews who went outside the ghetto and did not returned in the right moment were shot by Germans in the  streets.
Segment 12

Germans were afraid of typhus so they were not present in the ghetto. There were the navy-blue police. I had an uncle in Warsaw, I visited him on my way back from U.S.S.R before I went to Gora Kalwaria.  There were no ghetto in Warsaw yet. We knew about persecutions, roundups and killings. 

I did not have any immediate contacts with Germans yet. When I reported to work I was told to take off my cap but it was all. They  had never been in our apartment. Volksdeutche would rob richer Jews of money, cigarettes anything of value. They came with carts and took everything. We did not have anything (only a sewing machine).

On February 25 and 26 1941 Judenrat ordered all Jews to gather at 7 a.m. (with only a small hand luggage) in front of the Jewish town hall. People cried but the navy-blue police took them to the train and sent to Warsaw {Sept 1942, EG}. A few days before I had escaped to Magnuszewo. Jews were deported from there only in 1942. I walked from Gora Kalwaria to Magnuszewo and spent nights in Polish houses. I was given shelter because there was no death sentence for helping Jews yet. I had known about the Warsaw ghetto and did not want to go there. My mother, sister and brother went to the Warsaw ghetto. I was advised to escape because I did not look Jewish. I did not escape earlier because I did not want to leave my family (my brother was 3 years younger and my sister was 2 years older, she was born in 1914). They could not escape from the ghetto because they did not have any money. I survived because I was a tailor.
Segment 13

Magnuszew is near Kozienice, 19 kilometres south from Gora Kalwaria. I rented an apartment from Wojtas, a blacksmith and I stayed there, as a Jew, for a year till the deportation. All that time I was as a Jew, why should I desert my roots? When the others still lived, I lived with them as they did, only later it changed.

Till June or July 1942 people came to my apartment and I sewed clothes for them in Magnuszewo. There were arm-bands. In July Germans organized a ghetto (for two months) {EG, created 3/41- 9/32}. Jan Cwyl, my Polish very close friend advised me to obtain a Catholic birth certificate. I got it in Osiecko from the priest {cannot verify, 2 in BGN, quite far away}. My new name was Feliks Zoladek. I also got a mobilization card. On the basis of these two documents Roman Szczydlinski from Magnuszewo gave me my Kennkarte [a German document proving Polish identity]. From that moment I passed as a Pole. Jan Cwyl kept me for a month in his house, I was also at Wdowiak's (I sewed for them, they knew I was Jewish but I stayed there as a Pole). The priest knew I was Jewish, I told him. He gave me the Catholic birth certificate and he did not want any payment for it. He blessed me. Feliks Zoladek, a Pole, had belonged to this parish and died. The documents were very important also for people who gave me shelter because there had already a death sentence for anyone helping a Jew. Since I had a Kennkarte they could always say they did not know about anything because I had right documents. 

Soon the Jews from Magnuszewo were deported to Kozienice (EG). I had already had my Kennkarte but I did not show it to anyone and I went to a forced labor camp in Chmielewo along with other young Jews whom Germans deported there {cannot verify, several very close to Magnuszew}. They were to dig ditches for food. I did not believe that war would last so long and I thought I would survive there. I stayed there till December 1943. I worked there as a Jew. There were 100 Jews in the camp, we slept in the fire station. When Jews were deported from this camp to Kozienice I went to Magnuszewo and Jan Cwyl took me to his house. After a month he sent me to Wdowiak and I sewed clothes there too for a few months. There were a lot of Germans who had lived in Magnuszewo before the W.W.II. Later Wdowiak told me to go to a German to sew clothes. I was afraid to do that at the beginning but Wdowiak told me not to be afraid because Wdowiak guaranteed that the German would not do any harm to me. I stayed at Ferdinand Kurtz's for three months and sewed clothes. He gave me food and treated me very well. After the W.W.II he asked whether I had survived the war. Later he sent me back to Wdowiak.
Segment 14

When I was in Chmielewo I did not have any contacts with my mother and my siblings. I knew that my mother had died in the  ghetto. I saw my brother and sister in Gowaczeow near Magnuszew in January 1943. They escaped from the Warsaw ghetto. My brother lived in various villages working as a saddler till he was betrayed to Germans. Germans shot him in spring 1944 on the cemetery in Gora Kalwaria. I made him a symbolic grave.

I had sent my mother some groats to the ghetto but I did not have any letters from her.

Jews from Chmielewo were marched to Magnuszewo and later to Kozienice. I stayed in Magnuszewo. A lot of Jews stayed I had a friend, others tried to hide somewhere. I do not know were the  Jews from Kozienice were sent, probably to Majdanek or  Treblinka.

I did not appear as Feliks Zoladek in Magnuszewo and all people who helped me knew I was Jewish. Only when I went  to the other side of the Wisla River I was Feliks Zoladek and there I was not hiding, I went  to church, etc. While I stayed at Kurtz's (he was a volksdeutch) he knew I was Jewish and one more German knew about it but I did not sew anything for that other German, only a pair of trousers for his son.  I felt secure in Ostrow near Magnuszew {cannot verify, 2 in BGN next to Magnuszew}. People knew me at the village but nobody betrayed me. They liked me. I am one  of the million who has survived. I was lucky; I was not especially hidden.

Later people in Ostrow began to fear Germans because a lot of Poles were shot by Germans in 1943 and beginning of 1944 in Magnuszewo. Wdowiak told me that it would be better if I went to the other side of the Wisla River but as a Pole not as Henryk Preis but as Zoladek.

Subject:

Już byliśmy odcięci w ogóle od świata. Za wyjście w ogóle z getta groziła kara śmierci. I zapłacili życiem. Niektórzy co w ogóle pouciekali co nawet nie powychodzili szukać tam gdzieś pomocy u znajomych. Jeżeli nie zdążyli wrócić jak to się mówiło w odpowiednim okresie to zostali zastrzeleni na ulicy.

Interviewer:

A czy Niemcy się też kręcili po getcie?

Subject:

Niemcy po getcie nie kręcili się bo się bali tyfusu w ogóle. Ale koło getta tak, granatowa policja przeważnie w getcie.

Interviewer:

A miał jakąś rodzinę poza Górą Kalwarią? W Warszawie, na przykład?

Subject:

Jak wyglądało?

Interviewer:

Nie, czy miał pan rodzinę w Warszawie, na przykład.

Subject:

W Warszawie miałem rodzinę w Warszawie, wujka miałem.

Interviewer:

I były kontakty?

Subject:

Nie.

Interviewer:

Absolutnie nie było nic.

Subject:

Nie, już wtedy kontaktów nie było. Można było pisać ale już wtedy [inaudible] już kontaktów nie było.

Interviewer:

Dobrze to

Subject:

Jak wróciłem z wojska to wstąpiłem jeszcze do mojego wujka. Jak wróciłem do Warszawy. I od od niego przyjechałem do tego do Góry Kalwarii.

Interviewer:

A pan wiedział mniej więcej co się dzieje w Warszawie w tym okresie? Czy pan wiedział?

Subject:

Że co, że?

Interviewer:

Co się dzieje w ogóle, jak powstało getto?

Subject:

Jeszcze w Warszawie też getta nie było wtedy, getto zrobili od października.

Interviewer:

No właśnie.

Subject:

No jak to, myśmy wiedzieliśmy, no ja kto, no przecież tak samo. Żydzi byli prześladowani od pierwszej chwili, łapanki i zabójstwa i tej w ogóle no przecież od pierwszej chwili to było no jak wszyscy wiedzieli. Każdy jeden świadomy Żyd to wiedział o tym.

Interviewer:

A czy pan pamięta z tego pierwszego okresu, powiedzmy do lutego 41. roku, jakiś kontakt bezpośredni z Niemcami?

Subject:

Ja bezpośredni z Niemcami?

Interviewer:

Tak, kiedy pan spotkał po raz pierwszy Niemca, zobaczył?

Subject:

Za wyjątkiem do pracy coś, co szedłem do pracy przy budowie wału. Myśmy tam robili wał, w tym, w Podłężu to tam miałem styczność z Niemcem. Jak przychodziłem to “Nimm die Muetze ab.” Żeby zdjąć no więc czapkę zdjąłem no więcej z nimi nie miałam styczności.

Interviewer:

Nigdy nie byli w domu?

Subject:

U nas nie. Były rabunki znaczy, ale u bogatych Żydów to folksdojcze [volksdeutsche] to robili i czyli, czyli ten Polizeischutz, folksdojcze [volksdeutsche] rabowali. U bogatych Żydów w ogóle wyrabowali wszystkie te ten ubrania wszystko w ogóle pieniądze tam i papierosy w ogóle wszystkie kosztowne kosztowności. Normalnie rabunek. Przy… zajeżdżali wozami pozabierali wszystko i koniec. I tak u nas tego nie było bo myśmy nic nie mieli.

Interviewer:

Tak.

Subject:

Co prócz biedy nic nie mieliśmy i ta jedna maszyna co stała w domu.

Interviewer:

Maszyna do szycia?

Subject:

Do szycia, Singerowska.

Interviewer:

I pan jeszcze korzystał z niej?

Subject:

No z tej maszyny jeszcze korzystałem. I mama ją chyba zabrała do Warszawy jak, jak się nie mylę.

Interviewer:

W 41. roku w lutym było

Subject:

W 41. roku

Interviewer:

Było wysiedlenie do Warszawy

Subject:

Było wysiedlenie, tak, do Warszawy.

Interviewer:

Jak jak w ogóle ogłosili to wysiedlenie?

Subject:

No normalnie. Był rozkaz Judenratu że wszyscy Żydzi, od dzieci, starzy, chorzy, obojętnie kto by nie był, ma się stawać przed magistratem 25. o godzinie siódmej tyle i tyle osób i 26. tyle i tyle osób i mają tylko zabrać ze sobą tylko paczuszkę do ręki nic więcej nie wolno im zabrać. Płacz był okropny nawet nie do pomyślenia. Co w ogóle się wtedy działo. Ale to nic. I granatowa policja, nie żandarmeria, prowadzili właśnie Żydów do tego do kolejki. Wtedy była tak zwana ciuchcia. I wsiedli do wagonów i odwieźli ich do Warszawy. I stamtąd już szli

Interviewer:

To było wiadomo że to jest do Warszawy?

Subject:

Do Warszawy.

Interviewer:

I co pan myślał wtedy? Znaczy nie teraz tylko wtedy?

Subject:

Ja wtedy ja już nie byłem bo uciekłem, chyba dwa czy trzy dni wcześniej uciekłem do Magnuszewa. Bo w Magnuszewie jeszcze byli Żydzi. Bo Żydów z Magnuszewa wysiedlili dopiero w 42. roku.

Interviewer:

A dlaczego pan uciekł?

Subject:

Dlaczego uciekłem? Bo czułem się tego że może tam wiedziałem że tam jeszcze są Żydzi w Magnuszewie. Ponieważ jestem z zawodu mówię krawiec to może mi się uda jakoś tam dotrzeć do nich i tak faktycznie było. I panie wędrując z Góry Kalwarii pieszo to dostałem się do niektórych i polskich mieszkań i trzeba powiedzieć że dali mi schronienie bo jeszcze wtedy nie groziła kara śmierci. Dali mi schronienie.

Interviewer:

Znaczy pan uciekł do Magnuszewa?

Subject:

Tak do Magnuszewa. I tam jeszcze mieszkałem.

Interviewer:

Żeby nie być wysiedlony do Warszawy, tak? To było?

Subject:

Nie, normalnie bo nie chciałem się dostać do getta bo już czułem że mówię tak a jeszcze tam są Żydzi może się uda.

Interviewer:

Bo powiedziano panu, powiedziano rodzinie że ten wyjazd do Warszawy to jest wyjazd do getta, prawda?

Subject:

To jest do getta. Od razu, myśmy wszyscy wiedzieli do getta bo już getto wtedy w Warszawie było bo getto już było wcześniej bo getto było od października. A getto w Górze Kalwarii to było od lipca. To myśmy wiedzieli że że jadą do getta. Siostra pojechała wtedy, brat i mama. Ja jako trochę więcej taki więcej jak się mówi no a mówili do mnie że nie jestem podobny do Żyda że mogę się trochę tak swobodnie poruszyć tak żeby w ogóle raczej uciec. I tak faktycznie było.

Interviewer:

Ale dlaczego pan wcześniej nie uciekł? Przecież pan mówi po polsku, pan wygląda

Subject:

No ale no gdzie mogłem uciec jak była rodzina? Dlaczego miałem uciec, jak jeszcze [inaudible]?

Interviewer:

Pan się czuł odpowiedzialny za rodzinę?

Subject:

No ale przecież szkoda było zostawić matkę. Szkoda, szkoda było zostawić siostrę, brata, no przecież.

Interviewer:

O ile był wtedy pana brat był młodszy od pana?

Subject:

Brat był młodszy ode mnie o trzy lata. A siostra była starsza ode mnie o dwa lata. Ona była czternastego roku.

Interviewer:

Oni nie mogli uciec?

Subject:

Gołda, a brat Dawid. Oni nie, no uciec no gdzie w ogóle uciec, mogli uciec w 39. roku do

Interviewer:

Nie, ja mówię uciec z getta

Subject:

A nie to nie mogli uciec. Bo w ogóle to jest tak samo wszędzie zrobiło się ta sama historia, uciec nie mieli pieniędzy byli biedne dzieci. Mieli tylko to co mieli na sobie na sobie. I a uciec to też nie tak łatwo. Ja tylko za pomocą tego że byłem wtedy że miałem ten zawód że może jakoś i to dzięki temu że byłem z zawodu krawiec mogę mówić że ocalałem.

Interviewer:

Tak że pan wtedy uciekł do Magnuszewa?

Subject:

Do Magnuszewa.

Interviewer:

A co to jest Magnuszew? To jest miasto?

Subject:

To jest, to jest województwo, w tej chwili to będzie chyba radomskie. To jest od Góry Kalwarii z 19 kilometrów na południe, jest koło Kozienic.

Interviewer:

Ale pan powiedział że pan postanowił pojechać do Magnuszewa ponieważ tam byli Żydzi?

Subject:

Tak. I tam jeszcze sobie wynająłem mieszkanko u Wojtasa. Mieszkałem jeszcze, wynająłem sobie mieszkanie u Wojtasa Edwarda. On był kowalem i miał takie małe mieszkanko i tam jeszcze sobie szyłem do, do wysiedlenia jeszcze cały rok tam byłem.

Interviewer:

Jako? Jako Polak, jako katolik, jako Żyd?

Subject:

Jako, nie, jako normalnie jeszcze jako Żyd. Bo tam jeszcze Żydzi byli tak samo, tak samo jeszcze.

Interviewer:

Znaczy, przyznam że nie rozumiem pewnej rzeczy bo przecież pan był w wojsku był pan szwoleżerem, pan mówił

Subject:

Później, później, później, dojdzie do tego

Interviewer:

Nie, dlaczego pan nie wybrał swojej drogi powiedzmy polskiej?

Subject:

Tak

Interviewer:

A nie żydowskiej? Że pan by uciekł podając się jako Polak a nie jako Żyd?

Subject:

Wtedy kiedy w ogóle wyemigrowałem jako Żyd nawet w tą, tą drogę co przebywałem z Góry Kalwarii do Magnuszewa przebywałem jako Żyd. I to co mieszkałem w Magnuszewie mieszkałem jako Żyd.

Interviewer:

Dlaczego?

Subject:

Dlatego, no dlaczego miałem uciec znaczy się z mego rodu? Dlaczego miałem to zrobić inaczej wtedy kiedy jeszcze wszyscy byli, żyli to jeszcze byłem razem z nimi. Dopiero późniejszy okres dopiero zaczął się ten o którym będę mówił.

Interviewer:

Rozumiem, dobrze, dobrze.

Subject:

Tak. Więc jak mieszkałem u Wojtasa

Interviewer:

Tak

Subject:

To tak samo przychodzili do mnie znajomi. Szyłem im spodnie, ubrania, marynarki w ogóle wszystko do 42. roku. Tak samo chyba do lipca ,czy do do czerwca czy do lipca jeszcze w ogóle nie było getta. Tak a Magnuszewie. W lipcu

Interviewer:

A były opaski?

Subject:

Opaski były. Obowiązkowo, to już nie ma w ogóle, tak samo. W lipcu tak samo zrobili getto i zrobili i tam getto tylko było dwa miesiące w tym w całym tym tym Magnuszewie, tam getto nie było dłużej.

Subject:

Miałem kolegów. Miałem kolegów, nazywał się Cwyl [?] Jan, Polak, z którym się bardzo przyjaźniłem.

Subject:

I on doradził mi żeby wystarać się metryki urodzenia. I poszedłem do, jak to się nazywa ta miejscowość, do Osiecka, do parafii rzymskokatolickiej, do księdza i poprosiłem i ksiądz mi wydał metrykę urodzenia na nazwisko Żołądek Feliks. I karty powołania do wojska i ja sobie wyrobiłem kenkartę, to mi wyrobił Roman Szczudliński z Magnuszewa. Wyrobił mi kenkartę i za pomocą tej kenkarty i w ogóle i to to to udawałem że jestem Polakiem że nazywam się Żołądek Feliks. I dostałem się wtedy i właśnie i ten Cwyl utrzymał mnie u siebie jakiś tam czas z miesiąc czasu byłem u niego w tym okresie. I później on za.. przepro… i u Wdowiaka byłem też po tej stronie koło Magnuszewa, u Wdowiaka, też tak tam szyłem im ale już jako Polak oni wiedzieli znaczy moje pochodzenie ale już ja już byłem jako jako Polak.

Interviewer:

A ten ksiądz na jakiej podstawie dał panu tę metrykę?

Subject:

Ksiądz nic nie chciał.

Interviewer:

Ale na jakiej po… on wiedział że pan jest Żydem?

Subject:

Jak najbardziej, no przecież powiedziałem mu no. I pobłogosławił i mówi niech Cię, tam, niech Ci się, tam jak to się mówi, święci.

Interviewer:

A ten Żołądek Feliks to był?

Subject:

Polak, no.

Interviewer:

Polak który już tam umarł?

Subject:

Tak, on już był umarły z tamtej właśnie parafii. To jest bardzo charakterystyczne.

Interviewer:

Ale pan przecież wrócił do tej samej, do tej samej miejscowości, do Magnuszewa?

Subject:

I w ogóle zupełnie ja tych ludzi nikogo nie znałem. Później wróciłem z powrotem tutaj. 

Interviewer:

Ale z innym nazwiskiem tylko?

Subject:

Już a no oni w ogóle nazwisko nie było potrzebne dlatego że ja się tak nie ukazałem tam byłem u tych ludzi a oni tam szyłem im co mogłem ale ja im tam nic nie tego przecież oni nie musieli, oni znali mnie że ja się jestem Prajs [Prais] że jestem Heniek, wszystko wiedzieli jak najbardziej. Ale to nazwisko w razie jakiś tam wpadka w razie Niemców żeby oni nie mieli bo też groziła kara śmierci, żeby oni nie odpowiadali żeby za mnie to [inaudible] tak no Polak, no przeszedł proszę no to tamto więc myśmy go wzięli kenkarta była no.

Interviewer:

A w tym okresie ilu było jeszcze Żydów w Magnuszewie?

Subject:

To już ogóle było wysiedlenie, ich wysiedlili do Kozienic.

Interviewer:

Ich wysiedlili i pan się uratował przez nazwisko?

Subject:

Tak, tak, no tak. I później stamtąd, z Magnuszewa dostałem się do Podwie… nie nie, jeszcze nie. Z Magnuszewa dostałam się do Chmielewa. Tam był jeszcze obóz. Niemcy robili obóz przymusowej pracy, kopanie rowów. Tylko też za jedzenie. I zabrali tych różnych młodych tych Żydów. Zabrali z Magnuszewa tam do Chmielewa. Zabrali, normalnie.

Interviewer:

Pana też?

Subject:

Mnie też.

Interviewer:

Ale

Subject:

Już jako, jako, jeszcze jako Prajs [Prais]. O tym, o tej kenkarcie w ogóle nikomu nic nie mówiłem, nawet Żydom nie mówiłem.

Interviewer:

Pomimo tego że pan miał tą fałszywą kenkartę?

Subject:

Już miałem. Ale nic im nie mówiłem absolutnie bo myślałam może tam się udał uratować się może tak może bo. Każdy liczył że wojna tak długo nie potrwa. No nikt nie liczył że wojna tak trwa to się mówiło jeszcze wtedy Anglia jeszcze i Francja już byli w tym razem z nimi w tym, jak to się nazywa, w okresie wojny. Już w ogóle były walki, już tu były walki, tam były walki. Myśmy wiedzieli o tym. I dostałem się do Chmielewa. W Chmielewie robiłem do grudnia 43. roku, nie, czterdziestego… trzeciego roku, już jesteśmy już przy 43. roku.

Interviewer:

Ale znaczy pan w tym Chmielewie Pan pracował jako?

Subject:

Jako normalnie jako, jako Żyd.

Interviewer:

To był obóz pracy?

Subject:

Obóz pracy. Tak to był taki, no może niekoniecznie taki obóz w pełnym znaczeniu, tylko był obóz pracy ten i ten myśmy, myśmy mieszkali w remizie strażackiej. Prymitywnie.

Interviewer:

I tylko Żydzi byli w tym obozie?

Subject:

Tylko Żydzi, tylko Żydzi.

Interviewer:

Ilu, ilu mniej więcej ich było?

Subject:

Nas, mogło być nas około stu osób.

Interviewer:

No ale pan tą kenkartę gdzie miał schowaną?

Subject:

To ja miałam schowane no przecież tam. Miałam jakąś koszulę miałam spodnie miałam jeszcze jakiś sweter. Więc ja nikomu nawet Żydom nie mówiłem o tym. Wtedy kiedy zabrali Niemcy, kiedy wysiedlili Żydów z Chmielewa do Kozienic wtedy doszedłem do Magnuszewa mając tą kartę to ten Janek Cwyl do mnie powiedział “Heniek chodź do mnie.” Właśnie. Ja u tego Cwyla byłem z miesiąc i ten Janek Cwyl mnie później przekazał do Wdowiaków. Tam też byłem parę miesięcy i naznaczam że ten Wdowiak, z kolei, ponieważ tam była kolonia niemiecka i tam mieszkali Niemcy, i to z uznaniem dla tego Kultza [?], Wdowiak mnie poprosił mnie żebym poszedł do tego Niemca tam robił. Na początku obawiałem się więc on mówi “nie bój się ja gwarantuję że ten Niemiec nic ci nie zrobi” i u tego Niemca byłem trzy miesiące, Kultz [?] Ferdynand, tak się nazywał. I to jest z wielkim uznaniem on jeszcze żył po wojnie nawet miałem, kontaktu nie miałem tylko on pytał się czy przeżyłem wojnę. Bardzo dobrze mnie traktował. Dał mi jeść, dał mi jeść w ogóle tam szyłem tak samo dla niego, dla żony, wszystko to co mogłem tam szyłem. I później normalnie po tym okresie już mówi “dalej nie mogę cię trzymać i rób teraz” mówi tak i przekazał mnie z powrotem do Wdowiaka. A ponieważ tutaj już u nas Wdowiak również się bał, mówi “słuchaj ja cię przewiozę na tamtą stronę Wisły,” znaczy na prawy brzeg.

Interviewer:

Ale proszę mi powiedzieć taką taką rzecz, czy pan był do czterdziestego trzeciego roku do grudnia w Chmielewie?

Subject:

Tak

Interviewer:

W tym obozie?

Subject:

Tak

Interviewer:

Znaczy tam pan przetrwał i powstanie w getcie warszawskim i te inne wszystkie wysiedlenia?

Subject:

Tak, tak, tak, tak

Interviewer:

A matka i brat i siostra byli wtedy w Warszawie?

Subject:

Już byli w getcie.

Interviewer:

I były jakieś kontakty?

Subject:

Nie, nie. Tylko wiem że matka na pewno zginęła. Bo siostra jeszcze była również wysiedlona, siostra była w Głowaczewie. I stamtąd ją zabra…, z siostrą widziałem się jeszcze potem w tym okresie bo ona była w tym w Głowaczewie koło Magnuszewa, tam też jeszcze byli Żydzi.

Interviewer:

Ale co ona, ona uciekła? Czy?

Subject:

Uciekła z getta.

Interviewer:

Z getta

Subject:

Tak, tak. I brat też był, brat, z bratem jeszcze się widziałem w styczniu w 43. roku.

Interviewer:

A były jakieś

Subject:

Też uciekł z getta w Warszawie. Też tutaj wędrował też po wsiach. I jako rymarz i utrzymał się dłuższy czas dopóki nie został wydany do Niemców. I Niemcy go zabili w czterdziestym chyba czwartym roku na wiosnę w Górze Kalwarii na cmentarzu. I tam niestety jest pochowany mój brat co zrobiłem mu symboliczny grób. Jest tam.

Interviewer:

Także były jakieś kontakty z rodziną w getcie?

Subject:

Z rodziną później tak. Z siostrą tak, a z matką to już nie. Matki nie widziałem. Jak w ogóle było wysiedlenie, jak wyjechałem z Góry Kalwarii dwa czy trzy dni przed wysiedleniem, z matką więcej się nie widziałem.

Interviewer:

Jakieś listy? Nic?

Subject:

Nic.

Interviewer:

Nic nie było.

Subject:

Posłałem raz matce przez jakiegoś gońca posłałem trochę kaszy do getta. Bo wiedziałem że matka tam była, ale listów żadnych nie miałem.

Interviewer:

Ja się trochę, trochę zgubiłem wątek bo pan mówił tak że pan był tam w tym Cholewie do grudnia i potem pan powrócił do Magnuszewa?

Subject:

Do Magnuszewa. A z Magnuszewa uciekłem.

Interviewer:

Ale proszę powiedzieć tak pan powrócił do Magnuszewa już jako ten Feliks Żołądek?

Subject:

Nie.

Interviewer:

W dalszym ciągu pod swoim własnym nazwiskiem?

Subject:

Tak. Jeszcze to bo nikt w ogóle nie wiedział, to nie było ani Żołądek ani Prajs [Prais]. W ogóle razem ze wszystkimi proszę pana wróciliśmy do Magnuszewa bo myśmy szli pieszo. I stamtąd zabrali do Kozienic tak samo pieszo. Żydzi szli pieszo calusieńki czas.

Interviewer:

To był? Kozienice to był co?

Subject:

W Kozienicach to jeszcze tam, jeszcze tam był jakiś obóz czy coś takiego. Czyli stamtąd zabrali Żydów nie wiem dokąd czy zabrali czy do Treblinki czy do Majdanek z Kozienic.

Interviewer:

A pan sam wtedy?

Subject:

Ja już wtedy, nie sam, w Magnuszewie uciekło dużo nas uciekło. Ja miałem znajomego Cwyla.

Interviewer:

No tak.

Subject:

Tak. Więc on mnie trochę pomógł. On mnie zabrał do wsi a ci co nie mieli to gdzie mogli, gdzie kto mógł to uciekł. A kto nie mógł to zabrali do Kozienic poszli, a co się w ogóle z nimi stało to nie wiem. Czy w ogóle poszli do... Bo tam jeszcze był też jakiś obóz w Kozienicach i oni je złączyli, czy wywieźli chyba do Majdanek albo do Treblinki, tu lub tu nie wiem bo chyba do Majdanek to raczej stamtąd już poszli do na na Majdanki.

Interviewer:

Tak.

Subject:

Tak. I to wtedy i ja później wtedy kiedy jak jak mówiłem Cwyl oddał mnie do Wdowiaka, Wdowiak oddał mnie właśnie do tego Niemca, ten Niemiec z kolei

Interviewer:

A to był Niemiec? To był folksdojcz [volksdeutsch]?

Subject:

Folksdojcz [volksdeutsch] co tam mieszkał niedaleko Wdowiaka. Tak.

Interviewer:

I on znał pana sprzed wojny?

Subject:

I on, nie, nie znał mnie. Wdowiak też mnie nie znał tylko Cwyl. Cwyl mnie też nie znał tylko oni mnie znali z tego z Magnuszewa.

Interviewer:

A znali Pana jako kogo? Jako Żyda?

Subject:

Jako Żyda mnie znali tak, jako normalnie jako Żyda. I oni dopiero później, jak sobie wyrobiłem kenkartę też w Magnuszewie, Szczudliński Roman też wiedział że jestem Żydem bo przecież musiał, musiał mi zrobić zdjęcie tym podobnym. I dopiero wtedy jak on to ja rozumiesz Żołądek tylko udawałem po tamtej stronie, po prawej stronie Wisły. O tu a tam już w ogóle nie wiedzieli o mnie myśleli ale nie wiedzieli tam już w ogóle nikt nie wiedział jestem Żydem bo tam ja ich nie byłem ukryty tylko normalnie chodziłem tam chodziłem do kościoła.

A to już było bo później.

Subject:

To już było bo później, tak.

Tak, trzy miesiące byłem u tego Niemca.

Interviewer:

Subject:

Krawcem, szyłem im.

Interviewer:

Wszystkim? Czy tylko temu Niemcowi?

Subject:

Tylko temu Niemcowi. I tam jeszcze był jakiś jeden też wiedział o mnie, nazywał się Arn… Arnbrandt [?] czy jak tam. Też wiedział o mnie że jestem ale jemu nie szyłem tylko spodnie dla syna. Arnbrandt [?] jak, tak mi się wydaje tak się nazywał.

Interviewer:

Czuł się pan bezpieczny?

Subject:

U nich tak. U nich czułem się bezpieczny.

Interviewer:

Subject:

Nie. Skąd. Absolutnie.

Subject:

No jak mogłem wyjść?

Przecież to było na wsi to nie było w mieście. Na wsi.

Interviewer:

Na wsi.

Na wsi, tak. To było w Ostrowie. Ostrów.

Subject:

Nie. Tylko byłem znany w tym u Wdowiaka i u tego i u Cwyla, ale w tej wsi byłem znany, nikt mnie nie wydał.

Znaczy powiem panu dlaczego się pytam

Subject:

Tak. To jest charakterystyczne że nikt mnie nie wydał. Lubili mnie, no ja wiem

Bo jednej rzeczy nie rozumiem

Subject:

Ja jestem jeden z miliona co w ogóle tak szczęśliwie przeżyłem. Z miliona bo przeżyli inaczej bo byli ukryci tu tam, przecież ja nie byłem ukryty specjalnie.

Pan wie, kiedy ja rozmawiałem np. w Izraelu, w Yad Vashem, w innych miejscach z ludźmi którzy przeżyli Holokaust to między innymi mówili tak że oni po prostu nie mogli uciec nie mogli być na żadnej wsi ponieważ nazywali to mieli “zły wygląd” mówili źle po polsku no ale pan służył w wojsku, pan miał “dobry wygląd,” pan mówił dobrze po polsku bez akcentu. To dlaczego pan się bał chodzić po wsi na przykład?

Subject:
