Interviewer: So in July 1940 you moved to the ghetto?
Subject: We were already inside the ghetto in July 1940. The surroundings of the ghetto and the ghetto itself were sealed off completely.
Interviewer: But how was it in your case?
Subject: Well, normal.
Interviewer: Because you were living at home?
Subject: I liv… I continued to live in the same place because the ghetto was located where I lived.
Interviewer: I see.
Subject: Yes, it was.
Interviewer: That's good.
Subject: I didn't have to move anywhere. Nonetheless, it was a tragedy. Others came. We had to take them in.
Interviewer: Whom?
Subject: Well, other... Jews.
Interviewer: From Gora Kalwaria?

Subject: Yes, only from Gora Kalwaria. They came from the neighboring villages. There was a number of families, they lived in Czersk, Potycz, they all travelled to Gora Kalwaria, and we had to take them all in.
Interviewer: What did the ghetto look like?

Subject: The ghetto... You would have to see for yourselves what it looked like. Because the whole area was fenced... that dedicated part [of the town]. It was in Gora Kalwaria, an area made of a section of Dominikanska Street, the market square, the whole market square, Strazacka Street as well as a short section of Pijarska Street. It had a shape of a wedge, more or less, and Kalwaryjska Street. Yes, the Jews were not allowed to go any further, they could just get to that point [inaudible] and it was not locked up at all, only fenced, with barbed wire in one place, and where the street was, that street was passable, open. However, you were not allowed to venture out. If you did, you paid with your life.
Interviewer: Well, was there a gate to be crossed?
Subject: No gate, there was no gate because it was impossible to build a gate there. After all, it was Gora Kalwaria with open streets.
Interviewer: Well, you said there was a fence?
Subject: The area was fenced off in one place only, in Strazacka Street so that you could not go in the direction of the Vistula river. This is why the fence was there. That's correct.
Interviewer: But you said that you were living in which street at the time, Dominikanska Street?
Subject: I used to live, no, I lived in Pilsudskiego Street.
Interviewer: OK.

Subject: That's right. And that is precisely where the ghetto was. Poles lived in my neighborhood, for instance, Catholics, not Poles but Catholics. Wozniak, Rytko and Jarosz lived there. And they and they had to move to other Jewish flats and the Jews moved into their flats instead.
Interviewer: Was anyone moved also into your flat?
Subject: One person from the countryside was also placed in my flat as an additional resident.
Interviewer: So there were already four of you, right?
Subject: Yes, four, four.
Interviewer: I mean, your family?
Subject: Five persons.
Interviewer: There were five of you already there, right?
Subject: We were five in that one small flat. The flat was probably a 6 to 5 meter room. And so we had to squeeze in there until the 25th, 25 February 1941.
Interviewer: What was that period of seven months like?

Subject: Dreadful. In general, that period was... With 10 persons squeezed into every single flat, people started to [inaudible] from a severe illness. Typhoid fever came and there were no medications. In general, there was very little food. Poor people could only go to the kitchen in the commune and eat a meal, they would get a small piece of bread. And that's how they got by. There was no help. Those better off Jews had to make contr... contributions because they had to build a bath house for those, for not, for the Jewish population even, they had to build it and had to allocate their own money toward the construction.  Once the bath house was built and ready, Jews were forcibly relocated. They were forced to relocate.
Interviewer: Was there also a Jewish police force in the ghetto or was it set up?
Subject: There was a Jewish police force. Yes, there was. They could hardly be called the police. It wasn't exactly the police. They more more like security staff.
Interviewer: Responsible for keeping order.

Subject: Right.  But they did not beat anyone. They normally designated people [for work] and came to flats and summoned people to work. That was their task. They were appointed by the Jewish commune.

Interviewer: Please tell me one thing, in your case personally or possibly in the case of your family, what was the change between the period before the ghetto and the period after the ghetto? Because you lived in the same flat, didn't you?
Subject: In the same flat.
Interviewer: Even though they placed an additional person in your flat.

Subject: That's right. That man had to live with us. There was a storage unit next to our flat. We made a room out of that storage unit so that the man could live there. That's how it was, unfortunately.
Interviewer: In what sense did the situation take a turn for the worse?

Subject: The situation deteriorated by full 100%. We could not go out. We were not allowed to. Nobody, no one could come to see us. We couldn't do anything. Hunger got to the point, how do you say it, it got to the point that was unimaginable.  So people started dying. A lot of people died during that period. Very many people. They could still be buried. That was not forbidden by the Germans. When someone died, they still allowed for him to be taken to the cemetery. So the conditions were dire.
Interviewer: I understand that you were in contact with your friends, with the Poles? With Catholics?
Subject: With the Poles no. If only... if they could give us bread, they would do so during the night and even then in total secrecy.
Interviewer: But when you went back to Kalwaria, Gora Kalwaria...
Subject: Yes.
Interviewer: You obviously turned to your friends, colleagues and so on in December 1939.

Subject: Yes, I did. Very much so, I was was very... we are still friends very much. Many persons felt sorry for me, after all, and they would come to me even during that period, for instance, Jozek Lewandowski would come and bring me firewood. He brought me firewood. Already somewhere during 1939.
Interviewer: I understand. And that was until July?

Subject: As late as July. And they brought firewood even in 1940. The people we knew brought us potatoes. They gave them to us. As far as hunger is concerned, my family had everything they needed, together with me. We did not experience hunger. We did not have any delicacies but no hunger either, there was no situation where we would have nothing to eat, no potatoes or some groats to put into the pot. We had those. We could even support that man living next to us.
Interviewer: With the help of your friends?
Subject: Well, with the help of my Catholic friends, the Poles.
Interviewer: And in July 1941 you felt you were cut off from them?
Subject: Back in 1940, any contact was out of the question. The Poles were not allowed into the ghetto and we had completely different conditions in general. It was bad already.
Interviewer: So you were sort of isolated at the time, right?

Subject: We were already cut off from the outside world. Exiting the ghetto was punishable by death in general. And some paid with their life. Some who escaped altogether and did not even go out [of the ghetto] to seek help from friends. Those who did not manage to return, as we used to say, on time, were shot dead in the street.
Interviewer: Were the Germans wandering through the ghetto also?
Subject: The Germans did not venture into the ghetto at all because they were afraid of typhoid fever. But they did go round the ghetto. There was usually the blue police inside the ghetto.
Interviewer: Did you have any family outside Gora Kalwaria? In Warsaw, for instance?
Subject: What did it look like?
Interviewer: No, did you have any family in Warsaw, for instance?
Subject: I had family in Warsaw. I had an uncle.
Interviewer: And there were contacts?
Subject: No.
Interviewer: There was absolutely nothing?
Subject: No, there was no contact already. We could write but at the time [inaudible] there was no more contact.
Interviewer: I see.
Subject: When I came back from the army, I managed to visit my uncle. When I returned to Warsaw. I went to Gora Kalwaria on my way from his place.
Interviewer: Did you know more or less what was happening in Warsaw during that period? Did you know?
Subject: About what?
Interviewer: What was happening in general, about the ghetto uprising?
Subject: There was no ghetto in Warsaw yet. The ghetto was established starting from October.
Interviewer: Right.

Subject: Of course, we knew. What do you think? We still knew. The Jews were being persecuted from day one. Street arrests, homicides. In general, everybody knew from the very start.  All sensible Jews were aware of that.
Interviewer: Do you recall any direct contact with the Germans from that initial period, let's say until February 1941?
Subject: Myself, direct [contact] with the Germans?
Interviewer: Yes, when you encountered or saw a German for the first time?

Subject: Not really, except went I went to work on the embankment. We were building an embankment there in that, Podleze. There, I came into contact with a German. When I arrived, [he would say] 'Nimm die Muetze ab' [Take your cap off]. [He told me] to take [my cap] off so I did. Other than that, I had no contact with them.
Interviewer: They never came into your home?

Subject: Not into ours. There were robberies. Rich Jews were robbed by the Volksdeutsche. I mean Polizeischutz, the Volksdeutsche, were the robbers. They stole everything, clothes, cash, cigarettes and valuables from rich Jews.  Regular robbery. They would come... in horse-drawn carriages and they would take everything. And that was it. We experienced nothing of the kind because we had nothing.
Interviewer: I understand.
Subject: We had nothing but poverty and that one machine standing at home.
Interviewer: Sewing machine?
Subject: Sewing machine, a Singer.
Interviewer: Did you use it?
Subject: Yes, I still managed to use it. My mother took it to Warsaw if I am not mistaken.
Interviewer: That was in February 1941.
Subject: In 1941.
Interviewer: Forced relocation to Warsaw.
Subject: Yes, there was forced relocation to Warsaw.
Interviewer: How did they announce that forced relocation?

Subject: The usual way. There was an order from the Judenrat that all Jews, children, older persons and the sick alike, whoever it was, were to report in front of the town hall at 7 am on [February] 25th, their number specified, and on the 26th, their number specified again, and they were to take with them only a small package as hand luggage and were not permitted to carry anything else. People cried a lot. It was unimaginable. All those things happening at the time. But that was nothing. And it was the blue police, not the gendarmerie, that led the Jews to the train. It was the so-called ciuchcia [tank locomotive]. Jews boarded the train's cars and were taken to Warsaw. And from there they walked.
Interviewer: Did everybody know that [the train was going] to Warsaw?
Subject: To Warsaw.
Interviewer: What were you thinking at the time? I mean not now but then?
Subject: I wasn't there any more. I ran away to Magnuszow probably two or three days earlier. Because there were still Jews in Magnuszow. The Jews were not relocated from Magnuszow until 1942.
Interviewer: Why did you run away?

Subject: Why did I run away? Because I felt that, maybe I knew that there were still Jews in Magnuszow. I was a tailor by profession so I thought that I could manage somehow to reach them and that was what actually happened. When travelling on foot from Gora Kalwaria, I stayed at some Polish flats. I have to admit that they offered me shelter because they were not yet threatened with death penalty at the time.  They offered me shelter.
Interviewer: You mean you ran away to Magnuszow?
Subject: Yes, to Magnuszow. And I lived there, too.
Interviewer: So as not to be forcibly relocated to Warsaw, right? It was that?
Subject: No, I didn't want to end up in the ghetto because I felt that there are still some Jews out there and I can still manage.
Interviewer: Because you had been told, your family had been told that the trip to Warsaw was in fact a trip to the ghetto, is that correct?

Subject: That it was [a trip] to the ghetto. We all knew that it was a trip to the ghetto right from the start. The Warsaw ghetto had already been in place since October.  And the ghetto in Gora Kalwaria had been operating since July. We knew they were going to the ghetto. At the time, my sister, my brother and my mother went there. Me being slightly more..., how do you say. They were telling me that I didn't look like a Jew, that I could move freely and that I could escape. And that is what happened.
Interviewer: Why didn't you run away earlier? You spoke Polish. You looked...
Subject: How could I run away with my family around? Why would I run away when still [inaudible]?
Interviewer: You felt responsible for your family?
Subject: Well, it would have been a pity to leave my mother behind. I didn't want to leave my sister and my brother behind. It would have been a pity.
Interviewer: How much younger than you was your brother?
Subject: He was three years younger than me. My sister was two years older than me. She was born in 1914.
Interviewer: They couldn't escape?
Subject: Golda and David, my brother. No, they couldn't. Where were they supposed to escape to? They could have run away to Russia in 1939.
Interviewer: No, I'm talking about escaping from the ghetto.

Subject: Oh, no. They couldn't escape. It was the same story everywhere. They were poor children. They didn't have money to escape. Their clothes were all they had. Running away wasn't that easy either. I could just only manage because I had that profession. I can say that I survived owing to the fact that I was a tailor by profession.
Interviewer: So you ran away to Magnuszow?
Subject: To Magnuszow.
Interviewer: And what is that Magnuszow? Is it a town?
Subject: It's, it's in the Radom province. It will probably be the Radom province right now.   It's situated 19 km to the south of Gora Kalwaria, near Kozienice.
Interviewer: You said that you had decided to travel to Magnuszow because there were Jews there.

Subject: Yes. I rented a little flat there from Wojtas. I lived there, I rented a flat from Edward Wojtas. He was a blacksmith and owned a small flat. I worked there as a tailor for a whole year until the forced relocation.
Interviewer: As who? As a Pole, as a Catholic or as a Jew?
Subject: As, no, normally still as a Jew. Because Jews were still there as before.
Interviewer: I have to admit that there is one thing I don't understand. You were in the army. You said you were a cavalry man.
Subject: Later, later, later, we will come to that.
Interviewer: No, why didn't you choose to identify as a Pole?
Subject: Well...
Interviewer: Instead of choosing a Jewish identity? Why didn't you escape passing yourself for a Pole and not a Jew?
Subject: At the time when I emigrated as a Jew, I even travelled from Gora Kalwaria to Magnuszow as a Jew. And I lived in Magnuszow, I lived there as a Jew.
Interviewer: Why?

Subject: Because, why was I supposed to run away from my people? Why would I do it at a time when they were still there? I stayed with them as long as they were alive. The subsequent period had just began, the one I will talk about.
Interviewer: I understand. Good. Good.
Subject: Yes. So I was living in the flat rented from Wojtas.
Interviewer: Yes.

Subject: People I knew would come to see me. I sewed pants, clothes and jackets for them until 1942. It went on until probably July or June. There was no ghetto there until July. Yes, in Magnuszow. In July...
Interviewer: And were there armbands?

Subject: Yes, there were armbands. Armbands were obligatory. The same as everywhere. They opened the ghetto in July. And the ghetto was in place for two months only in the whole of Magnuszow. That ghetto did not operate any longer.
Subject: I had friends. I had friends. One of them was Jan[?] Cwyl, a Pole, a close friend of mine.

Subject: He advised me to get a birth certificate. I went, what is the name of that place, to Osiecko to a Roman Catholic parish to see the priest and I asked for a birth certificate and the priest provided me with a birth certificate issued in the name of Feliks Zoladek. I had draft registration cards and a Kennkarte issued . Roman Szczedlinski from Magnuszow had it issued for me. He had the Kennkarte issued for me. With the help of that Kennkarte I pretended to be a Pole by the name of Feliks Zoladek. I managed to get... and Jan Cwyl kept me at his home for around a month during that period. Later, he suggest... a mov... and I stayed with Wdowiak in the same neighborhood near Magnuszow. At Wdowiak's place, I sewed for them as a Pole already. They were aware of my heritage but I was already living as a Pole.
Interviewer: And on what basis did the priest issue a birth certificate to you?
Subject: The priest didn't want anything.
Interviewer: But on what bas... did the priest know that you were a Jew?
Subject: Sure, I did tell him who I was. He gave me a blessing and, how do you say it, said Godspeed.
Interviewer: And that Feliks Zoladek. Who was he?
Subject: He was Polish.
Interviewer: A Pole who was no longer alive?
Subject: Yes, he was already dead and from that very parish. This is very characteristic.
Interviewer: But you returned to the same, to the same place, to Magnuszew, didn't you?
Subject: I didn't know those people at all. Then, I returned here.
Interviewer: Just with another surname?

Subject: Well, the surname was of no use because when I arrived and lived among those people and I sewed for them whatever I could. They knew that I was Prajs [Prais], that I was Heniek, they knew it all.  But that [adopted] surname was used with the Germans so that the Poles wouldn't get into trouble. After all, they were threatened with death penalty. So that they could not be held responsible for me [inaudible]. 'He's a Pole. He arrived, had a Kennkarte so we took him in'.
Interviewer: And how many Jews were there in Magnuszow during that period?
Subject: They had already been forcibly relocated to Kozienice.
Interviewer: They had been relocated and you saved yourself because of your surname?

Subject: Yes, yes, exactly. Later, from there, from Magnuszow I went to Podwie…, no, no, not just yet. From Magnuszew, I went to Chmielew. There was still a camp. There, the Germans set up a forced labor camp where people would dig ditches. The only difference being they would do it in exchange for food. The Germans took various young Jews. They took them from Magnuszow to Chmielew. They took them, just like that.
Interviewer: They took you, too?
Subject: Me too.
Interviewer: But
Subject: Already as, as, still as Prajs [Prais]. I didn't tell anybody about that, the Kennkarte. I didn't even tell the Jews.
Interviewer: Despite the fact that you carried that forged Kennkarte?

Subject: I already had it. But I didn't tell them anything, no way, because I thought maybe I could rescue myself somehow, just maybe because... Everybody counted on the war not lasting too long. Well, nobody thought that the war would last. People kept saying that at the time England and France were already in it together with them, what do you call it, in the state of war. There were fights here and there, there were fights going on. We knew about it. I reached Chmielew.  I worked in Chmielew until December 1943, no, 194... 3, we are already in 1943.
Interviewer: You worked in that Chmielew as who?
Subject: Normally, as a Jew.
Interviewer: Was it a labor camp?
Subject: Yes, it was. It was sort of, not necessarily a camp in the full meaning of the word, just a forced labor camp, and we lived at a fire station. In primitive conditions.
Interviewer: Were there only Jews in that camp?
Subject: Jews only, Jews only.
Interviewer: How many, how many were there, more or less?
Subject: We could have been about 100.
Interviewer: Where did you hide your Kennkarte?

Subject: Well, I had it hidden there. I had a shirt, pants and a sweater. So I didn't tell anybody about it, not even the Jews. When the Germans forcibly relocated Jews from Chmielew to Kozienice, I went to Magnuszow. I had that Kennkarte and Janek Cwyl said to me, 'Heniek, come to my place'. That's what happened. I spent around one month at Cwyl's home and Janek Cwyl later took me to the Wdowiak family. I spent a few months there, too. I wish to point out that Wdowiak, in turn, because there was a German colony where Germans lived, spoke highly of that Kultz[?] and told me to go to that German and work for him. I was apprehensive at first and Wdowiak told me, 'Don't be afraid, I guarantee that German would not do you any harm'. So I worked for three months for that German. His name was Ferdynand Kultz [?]. I have nothing but great respect for him. He lived through the war and was asking around to find out whether I made it. He treated me very well. He gave me food, he gave me food. I sewed for him and his wife. I sewed whatever I could. After that period, he just told me 'I cannot keep you any longer' and he sent me back to Wdowiak. Wdowiak was afraid, too, and he told me, 'Listen, I will take you to the other side of the Vistula river'. To the right bank.
Interviewer: Tell me, please, did you stay in Chmielew until December 1943?
Subject: Yes, I did.
Interviewer: In that camp?
Subject: Yes.
Interviewer: There, you lived through the Warsaw ghetto uprising and those other forced relocations?
Subject: Yes, yes, yes, yes.
Interviewer: And your mother and brother and sister were in Warsaw at the time?
Subject: They were already in the ghetto.
Interviewer: Was there any contact?

Subject: No, no. I only knew for sure that my mother had died. Because my sister was also relocated, my sister was in Glowaczow. And she was tak... from there. I saw my sister afterward in that period because she was in Glowaczow near Magnuszow. There were still Jews there, too.
Interviewer: Did she escape? Or?
Subject: She escaped from the ghetto.
Interviewer: From the ghetto.
Subject: Yes, yes. And my brother was there, too, my brother, I saw my brother in January 1943.
Interviewer: Were there any...

Subject: He also escaped from the Warsaw ghetto. He travelled from one village to another. As a saddler. He had managed to survive over a longer period of time before he was handed over to the Germans. He was killed by the Germans at the cemetery in Gora Kalwaria in spring 1944 probably. He was buried there and I made a symbolic grave for him. It's there.
Interviewer: So there was contact with your family in the ghetto?

Subject: Yes, there was contact with my family later. With my sister but not with my mother. I didn't see my mother. When the relocation happened, once I left Gora Kalwaria two or three days before the relocation, I never saw my mother again.
Interviewer: Were there any letters? Nothing?
Subject: Nothing.
Interviewer: There was nothing.
Subject: Once I sent some groats to my mother to the ghetto by a courier. Because I knew she was there but I had no letters.
Interviewer: I'm a bit lost here. You said you were in Chmielew until December and then you returned to Magnuszow.
Subject: To Magnuszow. Then, I escaped from Magnuszew.
Interviewer: Did you return to Magnuszow already as Feliks Zoladek?
Subject: No.
Interviewer: Still under your own name?

Subject: Yes. Still because nobody knew. It was neither Zoladek nor Prajs [Prais]. I returned with all Jews to Magnuszow on foot. From there, Jews were taken to Kozienice, also on foot. Jews were walking all the time.
Interviewer: And where to? Kozienice, right?
Subject: There was still some sort of a camp or such in Kozienice.  And from there, they took Jews, I don't know where, whether to Treblinka or Majdanek.
Interviewer: And you yourself?
Subject: Many of us escaped in Magnuszow. I had a friend called Cwyl.
Interviewer: Right.

Subject: Yes. He helped me a little. He took me to a village and those who had no [friends] went wherever they could and those who could, escaped. Those who couldn't, were taken to Kozienice. I don't know at all what happened to them afterward. Whether they ever went to... Because there was also a camp in Kozienice and they merged them, or maybe deported Jews to Majdanek or Treblinka, one of those places, probably to Majdanek. They rather went to Majdanek from there.
Interviewer: Yes.
Subject: Yes. It was then, as I later said, that Cwyl passed me over to Wdowiak and Wdowiak passed me over to that German, that German, in turn...
Interviewer: He was German? He was a Volksdeutsche?
Subject: Yes, he was a Volksdeutsche and lived not far from Wdowiak. That's correct.
Interviewer: He knew you from before the war?
Subject: He, no, he didn't know me. Neither did Wdowiak. Only Cwyl knew me. Well, Cwyl didn't know me either. They only knew me from Magnuszow.
Interviewer: They knew you as whom? As a Jew?

Subject: They knew me as a Jew. Yes, as a Jew. And only later when I had my Kennkarte issued also in Magnuszow, Roman Szczudlinski also learned that I was a Jew because he had to, he had to take a picture of me. And then when he, you understand, I just pretended to be Zoladek on the other side, on the right bank of the Vistula river. There, they didn't know about me at all. They were guessing but did not know. No one knew I was a Jew because I was no longer in hiding there. I moved freely and went to a [Catholic] church.
Interviewer: But that was later.
Interviewer: Yes, that was later.
Interviewer: Please tell me, did you stay with that German?
Subject: Yes, I stayed for three months with that German.
Interviewer: But you were a tailor?
Subject: A tailor, I sewed for them.
Interviewer: For everybody? Or just for that German?

Subject: Just for that German. And there was another one who knew about me. His name was Arn… Arnbrandt[?] or something like that. He also knew about me that I'm there but I didn't sew for him. I just did pants for his son. Arnbrandt[?]. This seems to me was his name.
Interviewer: Did you feel safe?
Subject: I did at their house. I felt safe at their place.
Interviewer: Did you also go to the town's center?
Subject: No. No way. Absolutely not.
Interviewer: But why not?
Subject: How could I go out?
Interviewer: Did everybody know you?
Subject: After all, we were in the countryside. This was no town. In the countryside.
Interviewer: In the countryside.
Subject: In the countryside, yes. That was in Ostrów.  Ostrów.
Interviewer: Were you known there?
Subject: No. I was known only at Wdowiak's place and Cwyl's place but nobody knew me in that village and nobody betrayed me.
Interviewer: Let me tell you why I'm asking.
Subject: Yes. It's characteristic that nobody betrayed me. I guess they liked me.
Interviewer: There is one thing I don't understand.
Subject: I'm one in a million who is lucky to have survived.  One in a a million because some others survived because they were in hiding.I didn't go to great lengths to hide.

Interviewer: You know when I talked, for instance in Israel, in Yad Vashem and in other places, to people who had survived the Holocaust, they would tell me, among other things, that they simply couldn't escape and they couldn't go to the countryside because they claimed they didn't 'look right' or their Polish was poor. But you served in the Polish army, 'looked right' and spoke good Polish without an accent. So why were you afraid to walk in the village, for example?

Subject: Well, that was later, later I will talk about it toward the end. Later, Wdowiak knew... saw that people knew me in Ostrow, knew me from Magnuszow, as it is very close. They were apprehensive because terrible repressions were already in place and not only Jews but also many Poles were shot dead in 1943 and at the start of the year 1944 in Magnuszow. So Wdowiak told me, 'Listen Heniek, I would be better if you moved on. You can go to the other side [of the river] and find your way around there'. Right. As a Pole already, not any longer as Prajs [Prais] but Zoladek.
Interviewer: But when? Was it already in 1943?
Subject: It was, it was probably in 1943 or 1944, toward the end of 1943 in fall or or at the start of 1944 in January. It was probably already in January or February 1944.
Interviewer: Right. And where did you go?

Subject: I was generally in hiding at the time. I crossed the Vistula river and started hiding in bushes.  I had no idea where to go. It was already spring, I think. I met a woman. Initially, she was scared when she saw me. I told her, 'Don't be afraid of me. I am..., I escaped from Warsaw. My name's so and so. Could you give me shelter somewhere, please?' At the beginning, she was afraid but later she started talking to me and said, 'Listen, I'm very poor, I live very modestly but I have a good heart so I'll take you home. Come, come to my place'.
No.
Także pan wrócił do Góry Kalwarii w 45.
roku?
Czy?
Pan wrócił, tak? W 45.?
Tak, tak.
A dlaczego?
Dlaczego wróciłem?

Przecież to było moje miasto, panie, i tam
gdzie się urodziłem.
I pan się dowiedział że są Żydzi w Kalwarii?

Tak jeszcze byłem, przyjechali z Rosji bardzo
15 osób czy ileś tam przyjechało z Rosji i

później wyemigrowali, część do Izraela a
część do Ameryki.
I to pana przekonało żeby tam pojechać?
Tylko dlatego?

Tylko no nie, no przyjechałem bo dlatego że
później ściągnąłem tą rodzinę bo jeszcze

miałem tam wujka miałem który też przeżył
okupację tutaj.
W Górze Kalwarii?
W Górze Kalwarii.
On przeżył okupację w Zawichoście.
A swojej matki i rodzeństwa pan nie?
Już nikogo.

No ja rozumiem, ale pan nie próbował ich
szukać?
Jak to nie szukałem?
Jak to było?

Szukałem wszędzie, tam u znajomych. No nie bo
matka była chora na pewno była nie kto to wie
czy ona nie umarła w getcie w Warszawie.

Nie wiem. A o bracie to wiedziałem i
siostrze też nic nie wiem gdzie zginęła czy w

Treblince czy w Majdanku to nie wiem o
siostrze.

Zdjęcie jej mam jeszcze szkolne zdjęcie ładne
.
Była bardzo zdolna dziewczynka ładna.

A pan poszedł do Komitetu Żydów Polskich po
wojnie szukać ich?

Wszędzie. Szukałem jak najbardziej w
Instytucie i tam do pisałam do Izraela na Ben

Yehudy, wszędzie. Nie nie nie bo i oni by
mnie szukali przecież tak samo.

A pan się ożenił w Powierzbie czy w Kalwarii
już?
Nie, w Kalwarii ożeniłem się, panie.
To znaczy pan w 45.
roku przybył do Kalwarii?
Tak, tak.
Ale dokąd?
Do swojego domu?
No tak normalnie, nie do swojego domu.
Nie. Normalnie przybyłem do Góry Kalwarii.

Moje pierwsze kroki tak jak powiedziałem
były do sąsiada.
Do Rytki i pytałem, tam przenocowałem.

Na następny dzień zacząłem szukać bo mojego
domu już nie było, Niemcy rozebrali, Niemcy

czy tam kto inny czy Polacy [inaudible] nie
wiem.

W każdym bądź razie rozkoszy w tym domu tam
nie było prócz biedy tam nic nie było.

Stare łóżka, stara szafa i to był taki
drewniany domek.

No ale ponieważ wynająłem se mieszkanie,
mieszkałem normalnie tak jak się należy i nie
było problemu.

Znaczy domek pan sobie wynajął czy
mieszkanie?
Nie, u kogoś.
Znaczy blok?
[inaudible]
Nie, gdzie tam bloki w Górze Kalwarii bloki.

Teraz to są ale dawniej tam w jakiejś tam
chałupie.
No tam w jakimś tam domku.

I miałem [inaudible] i zacząłem szyć bo
jeszcze był tam jeszcze jeden krawiec nazywał

się Pelc [?]. On wrócił, z tym, z Oświęcimia
nawet wrócił i za… razem założyliśmy warsztat
krawiecki.

Szyłem razem z nim do jakiegoś tam czasu i
później tak było.
To ile, ilu Żydów było?
I później. Ile Żydów?
Wtedy.

Nie wiem czy było może może razem wszyscy ci

Do you remember your last leave from the military in Gora Kalwaria before the war?
Yes, it was in 1938, at Christmas, in December. That’s when I came to Gora Kalwaria on leave.
Did you see your mother?
Well, I got a 14-day leave from the army as a good soldier, a soldier’s leave.
Did you stay with your mother?

I did, actually. My brother was there, too, and my sister; we were all there and they were very happy and not only them; in general, it needs to be said that 80 per cent of Jews were very happy because they were proud to have a chevau-léger, from Gora Kalwaria, because I was a cavalryman; in addition, I was a tailor by profession, a far cry from cavalry. However, I was a very capable soldier and, I must stress the fact that, during regimental field drills, the corporal said to other soldiers: ‘Follow Prajs’ example and see how well he has is riding his horse at the front of the formation’. I have to say it because I’m proud of myself.
Obviously, you also carried a sabre, didn’t you?

Yes, I did. A sabre and a carbine, and I was a section leader because I had a section under my command, I had a machine gun; at the time, it was called RKM, a light machine gun, and I had one of those.
As far as I understand that that was your last leave at Christmas before the start of the war?
Yes, no soldier would be granted a leave later in 1939. Starting from March 1939, all leaves were cancelled because everyone, more or less, felt that the situation was not good.
Did you write letters to your family?

We exchanged letters with my family until the very last moment, until 1939; it’s just that my family did not receive the letters I had sent to them in 1939 informing them I was on my way to the frontline with the regiment.
I wanted to go back to that pre-war period or, you know, did your mother write anything to you about the atmosphere at the time?
Yes, she did. Very much so.
What I mean are the matters related, let’s say, to a greater extent to the possible breakout of the war. Did she feel herself in any danger?

Well, in general all Jews in 1939 were terrified by the prospect of a war. This is why a very large group of them had emigrated to Russia.  We need to state the truth, those who emigrated,  whether it was right or not, they did, after all, stay alive. I do not mean to make political comments, about certain times, nobody supported Stalin’s crimes and nobody would support them, I don’t want to get political, because it was a crime, a genocide. Those Jews who had emigrated to Russia, some of them did survive, whereas those here did not, with the exception of myself who was kept in hiding by the Pokorski family, because my mother in law had referred me to those people and they had agreed to keep me safe and she had even risked her life for me, which I’m going to talk about later.
You didn’t get married before the war?
No, I got married after the war. I did.

I understand. You said that many had emigrated, also from Gora Kalwaria?
Subject:00:04:04 Yes, some 100 or 150 persons also emigrated from Gora Kalwaria and about 30 persons made it back alive from Russia.
So maybe let’s now go over to the breakout of the war.
OK.
On September 1st, you were with your regiment in Suwalki. Is that right?

My regiment, our regiment. We were mobilized back on August 23rd. After roll call, everybody was handed live ammunition and we set off in the direction of that village, the village of Raczki was its name, near Suwalki.  We stayed there for a few days. We cleaned our horses, there was the evening bugle call, as usual during military exercises.
In the barracks?
We usually slept at local farmhouses because we had left the regimental barracks on August 23rd.
On horseback?

On horseback, all on horseback. On the first, on the first of September in the morning we got up at five as usual and none of us, soldiers, knew at the time that the war had started.  During breakfast, it was not the regiment’s commander but the squadron’s commanding officer at the time, given that the regiment was divided into smaller units as was the usual practice for the maneuvers because we could not all be in one location, who said: ‘Listen up soldiers! The war has started’. We were already hearing explosions because the railway station in Suwalki had been shelled in the morning. We knew what to do right away, we were advancing in battle formation from that moment onwards. We were told not to disperse. I mean we advanced in battle formation only. On the second of September, during the night, two squadrons, the fourth and the second under the command of Major Witkowski, were given the order to advance in the direction of the East Prussia towards Koenigsberg, today’s Kaliningrad, right? Koenigsberg. We set off at night in full battle formation, I mean, those two squadrons, horses and everything. We reached the village of Reuss, today’s Cimochy. There, we entered the German land. We advanced, left the horses in the wood behind a hill, and went to battle on foot. We did not encounter any resistance when entering Reuss. I think that we penetrated 5 to 7 km deep into the German territory. Depending from which direction, from Grajewo it would be some 7 km to the village of Reuss. We even went as far as..., I can’t remember, and later we stopped because we actually entered, what do you call it, or else

How do you say it, what do you call it, a bar not a bar, sort of a restaurant, no, something like that. People were even having a party there. We were surprised that there was no, that there were no guard posts at all, nobody was standing guard.  At that point, we heard that one of our chevaux-légers had crawled up to that building where it the party was taking place. It must have been a club not a restaurant, not a bar, just a club because they were partying and dancing. And he threw in a grenade. There was havoc. I don’t know. Szyciński ? was the surname of that soldier who had thrown in the grenade, I remember it as if it were today, a senior chevau-leger. So havoc ensued and panic spread at that point. We took two Germans captive. We did. Of course, I was already present at the time because I had been summoned by the commanding officer to interpret for him as I spoke some German and could act as an interpreter. So we held them captive and later, we spent a few hours there, in the early hours the order came to retreat From that moment onward, the whole tragedy unfolded. In general, we could not stop anywhere during the day. We could not stop anywhere because planes were dropping bombs all the time. It was virtually impossible to... anywhere. We had to stick to woods, hide in woods and could only start marching in the evenings.
What general direction did you take?
Direction? We were all told to go east.

- East?
- East.
It was already sort of the beginning of the retreat.
Yes, the general retreat. Yes.
When was it, more or less? What day?

It was, more or less, well, we started retreating, not only withdrawing from the frontline, we were moving in the direction of Zambrow and in general through the surrounding area because everybody was marching, during the night, yes, I remember different locations, I remember Wisniewo, I remember those other locations inaudible and we reached Zambrow.
When was that?

On the 11th or maybe on the 10th. There was also... because the Germans were already there in that..., there was a major skirmish there and one of our soldiers probably died. We did not take any prisoners because that group was stronger. The regiment held out, the regiment was still operating and did not disperse at that point.
Did you keep your horses?

We still had our horses, and everything, the regiment was still combat-ready, had its commander and all squadrons. It was not until September 13th, the night of September 12th to 13th that we arrived in Olszewo, a village situated between Bransk and Lapy.  It was there that we encountered fierce resistance from the Germans.  Heavy fighting erupted and there was a major exchange of fire. Very many, very many of our soldiers died there, more than twenty. The commanding officer of our regiment was still with us, he was wounded near Olszewo and so was I, among others.  My immediate commanding officer, cavalry cadet Glusek, that was his name, died two meters away from me. I was covering him with my machine gun. I don’t know how it happened. Apparently, the Germans must have... a shrapnel exploded and I was wounded in my neck, leg and hand. I still have the scars. And he just collapsed and never got up. He was standing maybe two meters away from me. After that, I was no longer capable of fighting. They took me to, what was his..., no, no in inaudible, his name was, his name was, I also forgot that but maybe I can recall it later.
Well, it doesn’t matter. Where did they take you? To a field hospital?
No, no, to the encampment.
Encampment?

Enampment. Yes, to a physician, a standard procedure. I forgot the name of the orderly. And another one. They took me to a physician to..., at the time lieutenant Gerula was the head physician for our entire brigade. They took me to him. He tended to my wounds because they were not that horrific. Sure, I had multiple injuries but not life-threatening ones. He sent me back to the encampent. That was on September 13th or 14th. The encampment no longer followed the regiment. The regiment went more to the east, later reached Klodzko and engaged the enemy there. They fought until October 5th, until the end. I wasn’t with the regiment during that period because I was wounded and we were sent in the direction of Grodno.  Our part of the unit went as far as Szczuczyn, Nowogrodzki. And there and there until September 17th. And we remained there, we were met by that army, we were disarmed by the Soviet Army and taken into captivity, no, I wasn’t taken prisoner on that day yet.  But we were already... Major Diaczenko disbanded our unit.  Everybody was on their own and, as it was not possible to reach Warsaw, we went east.
Please tell me: Was it the 17th?
It was September 17th.
September, the Soviet Union declared war, engaged in the war, yes, against Poland.
Well, at the time I was already, I was no longer taking part in combat because I had been wounded.
Did you know about it at all? But you knew?
What do you mean?
It was no surprise to you that suddenly the Soviet Army units...?

Well, it was a surprise, surprise, we went out and heard right away that the army, that is the Soviet troops entered that..., crossed the border and were moving in that direction capturing the whole... They were approaching, they were supposed to reach the Vistula river. That was... at the time. Obviously, our commanding officer, Witkowski, told us that we were not to fight with the Russians but surrender to them. But I was wounded at the time so I was not armed any longer but I was still in my uniform and they took us into captivity. I stayed there 2 or 3 days maybe.
The Red Army, but where?
The Red Army. In Szczuczyn, in Szczuczyn Nowogrodzki.
Did they set up camp in Szczuczyn?
Szczuczyn Nowogrodzki.
POW camp?

Yes, not far from Liga. It was not a POW camp. They had just brought and, I mean, were bringing all that military personnel and took them away for internment because we were not far away, we were in... near Minsk,  Niehorele  or whatever this place is called. We were planting trees there and later the exchange of prisoners took place. Yes and I at the time during that exchange... it was in December.
Exchange of POWs?
Exchange of POWs. I mean the Russians returned the Germans and the Poles wishing to return to Poland, and they took back the Belarusians and the Ukrainians.
The exchange was between whom?
The Russians, between the Russians and the Germans.
That was in December.
It was December.
This means that you spent in fact a few months in captivity.
Yes, I was interned those few months in Russia, behind Minsk, 40 kilometres beyond Minsk. We were clearing and planting forests there.
And how was it? How did those Russians treat you?

As far as their attitude goes, I will not, I will not say things that did not take place because as long as you did your allocated share of tree planting, so much and so much to plant, and logged it nicely, you were given, as far as possible, a portion of bread to live on, some 40 decagrams of bread, if I recall, and a soup. In the morning, we would get a cup of coffee and tinned food, tinned fish or other, nothing special but, being a prisoner, you could live on that.
The Russians treated you in the same way as soldiers and civilians?

No difference here. We were all prisoners, we were interned and we were not allowed to leave the area. A foreman, or whatever he was called, would take us into the wood in the morning and would walk us back to the camp in the evening, so much and so much, just like I told you. I could not manage my daily quota but there were two fellow soldiers from somewhere in Silesia or elsewhere.  I don’t even remember their names, they helped me leave captivity so I managed to make that quota and was eligible to claim the lunch, that is the soup given to those who made the quotas.
Did you know what was happening during the period leading up to December 1939?
No, absolutely nothing.
In Poland, family, nothing, Germany?
I knew nothing but they, but they didn’t know about me and I didn’t know about them. I didn’t write any letters because there was no way to write them.
Did you know that Warsaw had been captured, for instance, that the Germans...?
Yes, we knew.
How did you know? Because that...
Because we could not get here.
Were the Russians saying that? Or?
The Russians told us that Warsaw had surrendered: ‘Don’t worry, we are taking you into captivity now and later we will fight the Germans together’. Those, in general, were their inaudible
The prisoners were swapped in December, right?
Yes, the swap was later. I returned here to, to Warsaw and, thereafter, to Gora Kalwaria.
But how did it happen? You mean you were given civilian clothing?

No, yes, I received civilian clothing from an acquaintance. I simply got a plain jacket from an acquaintance back in Szczuczyn. Because I had my own pants and boots. He gave me a cap and a jacket and I kept my army-issue sweater. I still had a blanket and so I managed somehow in the end.
And you decided to return home to Gora Kalwaria?
To Gora Kalwaria. Of course, I later regretted that I had gone back after seeing what was going on.
But how did you travel there? By train?

I travelled normally, from Lapy. I got to Lapy from Bialystok and from there to Warsaw and from Warsaw to Gora Kalwaria, normally by train. When I arrived in December, everybody inaudible was baffled that I came back in one piece and was still alive.  We had a meeting of various residents of Gora Kalwaria, the Jews and the Poles, right away. They asked me what the situation was like and I told them my story and how things were in general.
Were there any Germans in Gora Kalwaria?
There were. There were Volksdeutsche.
But were there...
Rather large colonies.
Were there any repressions against the Jews during that period?
Not before the war, not before the war. After the war.
No, I’m talking about that first period in 1939, let’s say from September to December, when you came to be there?
Where?
In Gora Kalwaria, did the Jewish population or your mother tell you anything about the arrival of the Germans?

Sure, they did. Volksdeutsche joined straightaway what do you call them... They joined the blue..., black police and were in that Schutzpolizei, whatever it was called, and the repressions began right away. The Jews had to report, those aged 16 to 60, had to report for work. I also wrote about that. That was was obligatory. And immediately one of those Jews, a young boy, Mojsze Cybula was his name, Moszek Cebula took a crumb of bread and was killed by a German. Thereafter, Pinio Rawski was also killed when leaving the synagogue by the Germans, too. That all happened during the period. And very many young persons fled Gora Kalwaria at that point. Still in Sept..., still in October.
And tzaddik Elster Alter from Gora Kalwaria?
The tzaddik from Gora Kalwaria emigrated to Warsaw.
You mean he fled, left for Warsaw and later moved to America?
They took him to Warsaw. He was offered protection in Warsaw and he could not be seen at all, in general.
What do you mean... who took him? The Germans took him?
No, he was taken by the Jews.
The Jews? Yes?
The Jews took him, yes, at the time.
But what happened to him afterward?
He later lived in Warsaw, I don’t know where he lived in Warsaw.
No, he left for America.

He, no, he left for Warsaw in 1939. From Warsaw he was there in that..., he was probably in hiding in a shoemaker’s workshop. When the Germans searched the premises, not specifically for the tzaddik but in general, they entered a room and saw him sitting on a stool holding a hammer. The Germans did not go after craftsmen, shoemakers etc. in the beginning. And he stayed there for some time. Thereafter, as far as his emigration, he didn’t travel to America but was taken to Trieste. He was assisted by the Italian embassy, specifically by a Pole by the name of Stefan Porajski,  a cousin of our president Moscicki.  He worked at the Italian embassy and issued paperwork with the help of the Italian ambassador. They bribed the Gestapo or SS personnel. I don’t recall whom exactly. In fall 1942, they ordered a whole train car to Rome. And, thus, thus the rabbi with his family got out of Warsaw.
I see and...
And he travelled to Trieste.
And you, your family and in general all residents of Gora Kalwaria, Jewish residents, of course...
We were forcibly relocated.
But no, my question is whether you didn’t feel betrayed given that your, sort of, spiritual leader...

It’s hard to say. It depends on your point of view. It depends what they thought, what their point of view was. If somebody is a believer, if somebody in general thinks that it, that it was actually divine retribution or something else, I myself...
No, I’m talking about something else, you know, because, for instance, part of the Jewish leadership.
Yes.
When the war had started, they fled east.
Yes, some of them, some of them did.
Revisionists, Begin... the rabbi from Gora Kalwaria was an example of somebody who, sort of, fled, abandoned... But there were cases of people who returned, for example, Antek Cukierman.
Yes.
Who returned from Vilnius to Warsaw.
Yes, he did.
And the question is whether, whether the Jewish community from Gora Kalwaria did not feel abandoned by their leader when in need, whether there was no inaudible

I’m not going to say what I don’t know but there is no doubt that a portion of the Jewish population was certainly upset that the tzaddik was leaving. I mean that he was leaving Gora Kalwaria at all. But others..., it needs to be said that he left via the Vistula river. He reached the river and got to Warsaw somehow on a timber float, not by train but by the Vistula river.  His followers and, specifically, that that that entourage of his, decided to evacuate him, right. And he, the rabbi, even wanted to say himself as I read in his memoirs that he wasn’t exactly pleased that he was leaving. But he was right to leave because when the Germans arrived, they went looking for him immediately.
Good. So tell me now: you return to Gora Kalwaria in December. Is that right?
Yes, it is.
It was December. What did you see in Gora Kalwaria?

What did I see? It was a tragedy. Because Germans in general, like I said, among other things, I was made to clear roads. I had to remove snow from roads for free. I had to go to work and, in general, carry out various dirty jobs like many other people.
Tell me, when you went back to Gora Kalwaria, were there armbands already? Or not yet?
Yes, there were armbands already.
There were? And you put on an armband?
Sure I did.
Because everybody knew you?
Well, yes.
What did your mother and fam… and your brother and sister say?
The same as everybody else.
What did they tell you about the first period?

My mother was rather unhappy. She kept saying: ‘Pity you didn’t tell me you were coming, you should have stayed where you were because now you can see what is awaiting us here’. But we stayed almost the whole year in Gora Kalwaria and it wasn’t until February 25th or 26th that the general forced relocation took place.
1941. February 25th or 26th, 1941. The order came that all Jews were to leave the town.
And until then?
To the Warsaw ghetto.
No, I mean until February 1941. How was it?

By February, Germans had set up the ghetto in Gora Kalwaria in July 1940. They were setting up the ghetto. The Polish population had to move into the Jewish flats and the Jews had to move into the Polish flats where the ghetto was.
Because residents, I understand, the Polish and Jewish residents mixed in general?
They were mixed so some had to leave and others came.
In July?
In July.
The ghetto was set up in July 1940.
Starting from July, from July onward.
And what was it like until July?

The Jews could still go outside the town, when possible, they could buy food until July. Only work was compulsory. They had to report for work: 60, 100 or 50 persons, as many as requested by the Germans.
But who?
Aged 16 to thir... to 60.
Who decided about the persons going to work?
Well, the mayor. The mayor of the town of Gora Kalwaria. At the time, it was a German called Janke.
There was no Judenrat Jewish Council in Gora Kalwaria?
There was and the Judenrat designated the people for work.
Designated.
Yes, the Judenrat.
Who were the members of the Judenrat?
Members of the Judenrat?
Yes, who were they?
Well, there were the Orthodox Jews... there were the Hasidic Jews and the progressive Jews, the same leaders that were there before
Meaning those were...
It was a Jewish community so it was the leadership of the community, still activelater.
Were they relatively known activists?
Activists, known activists from every organization. The majority were the Orthodox Jews because they were the largest group.
Did it happen in the same way as in other towns and cities? When the Germans arrived in Gora Kalwaria, they summoned one of the Jewish elders?

Yes, yes, yes, just the same, they summoned the elder and said that the Jews were to comply with all orders and regulations issued by the Germans. Otherwise, there was death penalty even though the ghetto was not in place yet.
And compulsory work.
Compulsory. Work was compulsory, compulsory.
You mean 60 persons? Were all involved in that work?

Everybody, there was no difference. Everybody, each person designated inaudible by the Judenrat had to report... for work in front of the town hall starting from 7 am. The Germans would then come and take them to perform various onerous jobs. It was predominantly dirty work such as cleaning toilets, stables etc.
It is not... Did the Judenrat designate all persons or were there some people who did not work?
In rare cases. Probably the sick and the elderly.
Did you have any permanent job at the time?
Did I have a permanent job? Well, as as...
In addition to forced labor assignments.

A tailor, I sewed in my free time because customers would come to me. The Catholics came to me as long as they were allowed. I sewed for them whenever I could. Of course, I charged very low rates but at least I could sew.
And where did you...
During that period.
Yes, yes.
Were you also involved in that forced labor assignments?
Well, of course. When I was designated for work, I had to report at 7 am and work until 4 or 5 pm. I still had some free time so I could, I had to do something.
And how was it?
It was hard, believe me.
What kind of work did you do?

I had to go and clear snow from roads. I once had to go to the barracks and take out some garbage. One time they took me to the stables because they knew that I had been in the army and that I am familiar with the job. I was told to clean those... I had to remove horse manure from stables. Well, I did all that. Obviously, later on they took us into the ghetto, then from the ghetto...
How about your mother?

My mother was an elderly woman. She was suffering from poor health so they didn’t take her to work. She stayed at home as far as possible. When she felt well enough, she continued to sew as long as she was allowed to. And later she couldn’t sew, the customers stopped coming because it was forbidden.
During that period until July 1940, was there hunger, for example?
We were hungry from day one.
From day one.

In Gora Kalwaria, 80% of the Jewish population were poor. Just poor people. Those 20% were, more or less, craftsmen and merchants and such. They were slightly better off. You could count rich people on the fingers of your hands only. There were maybe five or six rich persons.
Did the Judenrat organize any help for the poor? Did they hand out food?
Well, they arranged lunches.
Lunches?

From the moment they had organized themselves, the Judenrat was established and they started offering lunches but what difference would those lunches make? What that lunch, that little soup, could change for those poor?
For all?
Whoever wanted could get that lunch.
Interviewer: Do you remember your last leave from the military in Gora Kalwaria before the war?
Subject: Yes, it was in 1938, at Christmas, in December. That's when I came to Gora Kalwaria on leave.
Interviewer: Did you see your mother?
Subject: Well, I got a 14-day leave from the army as a good soldier, a soldier's leave.
Interviewer: Did you stay with your mother?

Subject: I did, actually. My brother was there, too, and my sister; we were all there and they were very happy and not only them; in general, it needs to be said that 80 per cent of Jews were very happy because they were proud to have a chevau-léger, from Gora Kalwaria, because I was a cavalryman; in addition, I was a tailor by profession, a far cry from cavalry. However, I was a very capable soldier and, I must stress the fact that, during regimental field drills, the corporal said to other soldiers, 'Follow Prajs' example and see how well he has is riding his horse at the front of the formation'. I have to say it because I'm proud of myself.
Interviewer: Obviously, you also carried a sabre, didn't you?

Subject: Yes, I did. A sabre and a carbine, and I was a section leader because I had a section under my command, I had a machine gun; at the time, it was called RKM, a light machine gun, and I had one of those.
Interviewer: As far as I understand that that was your last leave at Christmas before the start of the war?
Subject:  Yes, no soldier would be granted a leave later in 1939. Starting from March [1939], all leaves were cancelled because everyone, more or less, felt that the situation was not good.
Interviewer: Did you write letters to your family?

Subject: We exchanged letters with my family until the very last moment, until 1939; it's just that my family did not receive the letters I had sent to them in 1939 informing them I was on my way to the frontline with the regiment.
Interviewer: I wanted to go back to that pre-war period or, you know, did your mother write anything to you about the atmosphere at the time?
Subject: Yes, she did. Very much so.
Interviewer: What I mean are the matters related, let's say, to a greater extent to the possible breakout of the war. Did she feel herself in any danger?

Subject: Well, in general all Jews in 1939 were terrified by the prospect of a war. This is why a very large group of them had emigrated to Russia.  We need to state the truth, those who emigrated,  whether it was right or not, they did, after all, stay alive. I do not mean to make political comments, about certain times, nobody supported Stalin's crimes and nobody would support them, I don't want to get political, because it was a crime, a genocide. Those Jews who had emigrated to Russia, some of them did survive, whereas those here [did not], with the exception of myself who was kept in hiding by the Pokorski family, because my mother in law had referred me to those people and they had agreed to keep me safe and she had even risked her life for me, which I'm going to talk about later.
Interviewer: You didn't get married before the war?
Subject: No, I got married after the war. I did.

Interviewer: I understand. You said that many had emigrated, also from Gora Kalwaria?

Yes, some 100 or 150 persons also emigrated from Gora Kalwaria and about 30 persons made it back alive from Russia. Subject:
Interviewer: So maybe let's now go over to the breakout of the war.
Subject: OK.
Interviewer: On September 1st, you were with your regiment in Suwalki. Is that right?

Subject: My regiment, our regiment. We were mobilized back on August 23rd. After roll call, everybody was handed live ammunition and we set off in the direction of that village, the village of Raczki was its name, near Suwalki.  We stayed there for a few days. We cleaned our horses, there was the evening bugle call, as usual during military exercises.
Interviewer: In the barracks?
Subject: We usually slept at local farmhouses because we had left the regimental barracks on August 23rd.
Interviewer: On horseback?

Subject: On horseback, all on horseback. On the first, on the first of September in the morning we got up at five as usual and none of us, soldiers, knew at the time that the war had started.  During breakfast, it was not the regiment's commander but the squadron's commanding officer at the time, given that the regiment was divided into smaller units as was the usual practice for the maneuvers because we could not all be in one location, who said, 'Listen up soldiers! The war has started'. We were already hearing explosions because the railway station in Suwalki had been shelled in the morning. We knew what to do right away, we were advancing in battle formation from that moment onwards. We were told not to disperse. I mean we advanced in battle formation only. On the second [of September], during the night, two squadrons, the fourth and the second under the command of Major Witkowski, were given the order to advance in the direction of the East Prussia towards Koenigsberg, today's Kaliningrad, right? Koenigsberg. We set off at night in full [battle] formation, I mean, those two squadrons, horses and everything. We reached the village of Reuss, today's Cimochy. There, we entered the German land. We advanced, left the horses in the wood behind a hill, and went to battle on foot. We did not encounter any resistance when entering Reuss. I think that we penetrated 5 to 7 km deep [into the German territory]. Depending from which direction, from Grajewo it would be some 7 km to the village of Reuss. We even went as far as..., I can't remember, and later we stopped because we actually entered, what do you call it, or else

Subject: How do you say it, what do you call it, a bar not a bar, sort of a restaurant, no, something like that. People were even having a party there. We were surprised that there was no, that there were no guard posts at all, nobody was standing guard.  At that point, we heard that one of our chevaux-légers had crawled up to that building where it [the party] was taking place. It must have been a club not a restaurant, not a bar, just a club because they were partying and dancing. And he threw in a grenade. There was havoc. I don't know. Szyciński [?] was the surname of that soldier who had thrown in the grenade, I remember it as if it were today, a senior chevau-leger. So havoc ensued and panic spread at that point. We took two Germans captive. We did. Of course, I was already present at the time because I had been summoned by the commanding officer to interpret for him as I spoke some German and could act as an interpreter. So we held them captive and later, we spent a few hours there, in the early hours the order came to retreat From that moment onward, the whole tragedy unfolded. In general, we could not stop anywhere during the day. We could not stop anywhere because planes were dropping bombs all the time. It was virtually impossible to... anywhere. We had to stick to woods, hide in woods and could only start marching in the evenings.
Interviewer: What general direction did you take?
Subject: Direction? We were all told to go east.
Interviewer: East?
Subject: East.
Interviewer: It was already sort of the beginning of the retreat.
Subject: Yes, the general retreat. Yes.
Interviewer: When was it, more or less? What day?

Subject: It was, more or less, well, we started retreating, not only withdrawing from the frontline, we were moving in the direction of Zambrow and in general through the surrounding area because everybody was marching, during the night, yes, I remember different locations, I remember Wisniewo, I remember those other locations [inaudible] and we reached Zambrow.
Interviewer: When was that?

Subject: On the 11th or maybe on the 10th. There was also... because the Germans were already there in that..., there was a major skirmish there and one of our soldiers probably died. We did not take any prisoners because that group was stronger. The regiment held out, the regiment was still operating and did not disperse at that point.
Interviewer: Did you keep your horses?

Subject: We still had our horses, and everything, the regiment was still combat-ready, had its commander and all squadrons. It was not until September 13th, the night of September 12th to 13th that we arrived in Olszewo, a village situated between Bransk and Lapy.  It was there that we encountered fierce resistance from the Germans.  Heavy fighting erupted and there was a major exchange of fire. Very many, very many of our soldiers died there, more than twenty. The commanding officer of our regiment was still with us, he was wounded near Olszewo and so was I, among others.  My immediate commanding officer, cavalry cadet Glusek, that was his name, died two meters away from me. I was covering him with my machine gun. I don't know how it happened. Apparently, the Germans must have... a shrapnel exploded and I was wounded in my neck, leg and hand. I still have the scars. And he just collapsed and never got up. He was standing maybe two meters away from me. After that, I was no longer capable of fighting. They took me to, what was his..., no, no in [inaudible], his name was, his name was, I also forgot that but maybe I can recall it later.
Interviewer: Well, it doesn't matter. Where did they take you? To a field hospital?
Subject: No, no, to the encampment.
Interviewer: Encampment?

Subject: Enampment. Yes, to a physician, a standard procedure. I forgot the name of the orderly. And another one. They took me to a physician to..., at the time lieutenant Gerula was the head physician for our entire brigade. They took me to him. He tended to my wounds because they were not that horrific. Sure, I had multiple injuries but not life-threatening ones. He sent me back to the encampent. That was on September 13th or 14th. The encampment no longer followed the regiment. The regiment went more to the east, later reached Klodzko and engaged the enemy there. They fought until October 5th, until the end. I wasn't with the regiment during that period because I was wounded and we were sent in the direction of Grodno.  Our part of the unit went as far as Szczuczyn, Nowogrodzki. And there and there until [September] 17th. And we remained there, we were met by that army, we were disarmed by the Soviet Army and taken into captivity, no, I wasn't taken prisoner on that day yet.  But we were already... Major Diaczenko disbanded our unit.  Everybody was on their own and, as it was not possible to reach Warsaw, we went east.
Interviewer: Please tell me: Was it the 17th?
Subject: It was September 17th.
Interviewer: September, the Soviet Union declared war, engaged in the war, yes, against Poland.
Subject: Well, at the time I was already, I was no longer taking part [in combat] because I had been wounded.
Interviewer: Did you know about it at all? But you knew?
Subject: What do you mean?
Interviewer: It was no surprise to you that suddenly the Soviet Army units...?

Subject: Well, it was a surprise, surprise, we went out and heard right away that the army, that is the Soviet troops entered that..., crossed the border and were moving in that direction capturing the whole... They were approaching, they were supposed to reach the Vistula river. That was... at the time. Obviously, our commanding officer, Witkowski, told us that we were not to fight with the Russians but surrender to them. But I was wounded at the time so I was not armed any longer but I was still in my uniform and they took us into captivity. I stayed there 2 or 3 days maybe.
Interviewer: The Red Army, but where?
Subject: The Red Army. In Szczuczyn, in Szczuczyn Nowogrodzki.
Interviewer: Did they set up camp in Szczuczyn?
Subject: Szczuczyn Nowogrodzki.
Interviewer: POW camp?

Subject: Yes, not far from Liga. It was not a POW camp. They had just brought and, I mean, were bringing all that military personnel and took them away for internment because we were not far away, we were in... near Minsk,  Niehorele  or whatever this place is called. We were planting trees there and later the exchange of prisoners took place. Yes and I at the time during that exchange... it was in December.
Interviewer: Exchange of POWs?
Subject: Exchange of POWs. I mean the Russians returned the Germans and the Poles wishing [to return to Poland], and they took back the Belarusians and the Ukrainians.
Interviewer: The exchange was between whom?
Subject: The Russians, between the Russians and the Germans.
Interviewer: That was in December.
Subject: It was December.
Interviewer: This means that you spent in fact a few months in captivity.
Subject: Yes, I was interned those few months in Russia, behind Minsk, 40 kilometres beyond Minsk. We were clearing and planting forests there.
Interviewer: And how was it? How did those Russians treat you?

Subject: As far as their attitude goes, I will not, I will not say things that did not take place because as long as you did your allocated share of tree planting, so much and so much to plant, and logged it nicely, you were given, as far as possible, a portion of bread to live on, some 40 decagrams of bread, if I recall, and a soup. In the morning, we would get a cup of coffee and tinned food, tinned fish or other, nothing special but, being a prisoner, you could live on that.
Interviewer: The Russians treated you in the same way as soldiers and civilians?

Subject: No difference here. We were all prisoners, we were interned and we were not allowed to leave the area. A foreman, or whatever he was called, would take us into the wood in the morning and would walk us back to the camp in the evening, so much and so much, just like I told you. I could not manage my daily quota but there were two fellow soldiers from somewhere in Silesia or elsewhere.  I don't even remember their names, they helped me leave captivity so I managed to make that quota and was eligible to claim the lunch, that is the soup given to those who made the quotas.
Interviewer: Did you know what was happening during the period leading up to December 1939?
Subject: No, absolutely nothing.
Interviewer: In Poland, family, nothing, Germany?
Subject: I knew nothing but they, but they didn't know about me and I didn't know about them. I didn't write any letters because there was no way to write them.
Interviewer: Did you know that Warsaw had been captured, for instance, that the Germans...?
Interviewer: Yes, we knew.
Interviewer: How did you know? Because that...
Subject: Because we could not get here.
Interviewer: Were the Russians saying that? Or?
Subject: The Russians told us that Warsaw had surrendered, 'Don't worry, we are taking you into captivity now and later we will fight the Germans together'. Those, in general, were their [inaudible].
Interviewer: The prisoners were swapped in December, right?
Subject: Yes, the swap was later. I returned here to, to Warsaw and, thereafter, to Gora Kalwaria.
Interviewer: But how did it happen? You mean you were given civilian clothing?

Subject: No, yes, I received civilian clothing from an acquaintance. I simply got a plain jacket from an acquaintance back in Szczuczyn. Because I had my own pants and boots. He gave me a cap and a jacket and I kept my army-issue sweater. I still had a blanket and so I managed somehow in the end.
Interviewer: And you decided to return home to Gora Kalwaria?
Subject: To Gora Kalwaria. Of course, I later regretted that I had gone back after seeing what was going on.
Interviewer: But how did you travel there? By train?

Subject: I travelled normally, from Lapy. I got to Lapy from Bialystok and from there to Warsaw and from Warsaw to Gora Kalwaria, normally by train. When [I arrived] in December, everybody [inaudible] was baffled that I came back in one piece and was still alive.  We had a meeting of various residents of Gora Kalwaria, the Jews and the Poles, right away. They asked me what the situation was like and I told them my story and how things were in general.
Interviewer: Were there any Germans in Gora Kalwaria?
Subject: There were. There were Volksdeutsche.
Interviewer: But were there...
Subject: Rather large colonies.
Interviewer: Were there any repressions against the Jews during that period?
Subject: Not before the war, not before the war. After the war.
Interviewer: No, I'm talking about that first period in 1939, let's say from September to December, when you came to be there?
Subject: Where?
Interviewer: In Gora Kalwaria, did the Jewish population or your mother tell you anything about the arrival of the Germans?

Subject: Sure, they did. Volksdeutsche joined straightaway what do you call them... They joined the blue..., black police and were in that Schutzpolizei, whatever it was called, and the repressions began right away. The Jews had to report, those aged 16 to 60, had to report for work. I also wrote about that. That was was obligatory. And immediately one of those Jews, a young boy, Mojsze Cybula was his name, Moszek Cebula took a crumb of bread and was killed by a German. Thereafter, Pinio Rawski was also killed when leaving the synagogue by the Germans, too. That all happened during the period. And very many young persons fled Gora Kalwaria at that point. Still in Sept..., still in October.
Interviewer: And tzaddik Elster [Alter] from Gora Kalwaria?
Subject: The tzaddik from Gora Kalwaria emigrated to Warsaw.
Interviewer: You mean he fled, left for Warsaw and later moved to America?
Subject: They took him to Warsaw. He was offered protection in Warsaw and he could not be seen at all, in general.
Interviewer: What do you mean... who took him? The Germans took him?
Subject: No, he was taken by the Jews.
Interviewer: The Jews? Yes?
Subject: The Jews took him, yes, at the time.
Interviewer: But what happened to him afterward?
Subject: He later lived in Warsaw, I don't know where he lived in Warsaw.
Interviewer: No, he left for America.

Subject: He, no, he left for Warsaw in 1939. From Warsaw he was there in that..., he was probably in hiding in a shoemaker's workshop. When the Germans searched the premises, not specifically for the tzaddik but in general, they entered a room and saw him sitting on a stool holding a hammer. The Germans did not go after craftsmen, shoemakers etc. in the beginning. And he stayed there for some time. Thereafter, as far as his emigration, he didn't travel to America but was taken to Trieste. He was assisted by the Italian embassy, specifically by a Pole by the name of Stefan Porajski,  a cousin of our president Moscicki.  He worked at the Italian embassy and issued paperwork with the help of the Italian ambassador. They bribed the Gestapo or SS personnel. I don't recall whom exactly. In fall 1942, they ordered a whole train car to Rome. And, thus, thus the rabbi with his family got out of Warsaw.
Interviewer: I see and...
Subject: And he travelled to Trieste.
Interviewer: And you, your family and in general all residents of Gora Kalwaria, Jewish residents, of course...
Subject: We were forcibly relocated.
Interviewer: But no, my question is whether you didn't feel betrayed given that your, sort of, spiritual leader...

Subject: It's hard to say. It depends on your point of view. It depends what they thought, what their point of view was. If somebody is a believer, if somebody in general thinks that it, that it was actually divine retribution or something else, I myself...
Interviewer: No, I'm talking about something else, you know, because, for instance, part of the Jewish leadership.
Subject: Yes.
Interviewer: When the war had started, they fled east.
Subject: Yes, some of them, some of them did.
Interviewer: Revisionists, Begin... the rabbi from Gora Kalwaria was an example of somebody who, sort of, fled, abandoned... But there were cases of people who returned, for example, Antek Cukierman.
Subject: Yes.
Interviewer: Who returned from Vilnius to Warsaw.
Subject: Yes, he did.
Interviewer: And the question is whether, whether the Jewish community from Gora Kalwaria did not feel abandoned by their leader when in need, whether there was no [inaudible].

Subject: I'm not going to say what I don't know but there is no doubt that a portion of the Jewish population was certainly upset that the tzaddik was leaving. I mean that he was leaving Gora Kalwaria at all. But others..., it needs to be said that he left via the Vistula river. He reached the river and got to Warsaw somehow on a timber float, not by train but by the Vistula river.  His followers and, specifically, that that that entourage of his, decided to evacuate him, right. And he, the rabbi, even wanted to say himself as I read in his memoirs that he wasn't exactly pleased that he was leaving. But he was right to leave because when the Germans arrived, they went looking for him immediately.
Interviewer: Good. So tell me now: you return to Gora Kalwaria in December. Is that right?
Subject: Yes, it is.
Interviewer: It was December. What did you see in Gora Kalwaria?

Subject: What did I see? It was a tragedy. Because Germans in general, like I said, among other things, I was made to clear roads. I had to remove snow from roads for free. I had to go to work and, in general, carry out various dirty jobs like many other people.
Interviewer: Tell me, when you went back to Gora Kalwaria, were there armbands already? Or not yet?
Subject: Yes, there were armbands already.
Interviewer: There were? And you put on an armband?
Subject: Sure I did.
Interviewer: Because everybody knew you?
Subject: Well, yes.
Interviewer: What did your mother and fam… and your brother and sister say?
Subject: The same as everybody else.
Interviewer: What did they tell you about the first period?

Subject: My mother was rather unhappy. She kept saying, 'Pity you didn't tell me you were coming, you should have stayed where you were because now you can see what is awaiting us here'. But we stayed almost the whole year in Gora Kalwaria and it wasn't until February 25th or 26th that the general forced relocation took place.
Interviewer: 1941?
Subject: 1941. February 25th or 26th, 1941. The order came that all Jews were to leave the town.
Interviewer: And until then?
Subject: To the Warsaw ghetto.
Interviewer: No, I mean until February 1941. How was it?

Subject: By February, Germans had set up the ghetto in Gora Kalwaria in July 1940. They were setting up the ghetto. The Polish population had to move into the Jewish flats and the Jews had to move into the Polish flats where the ghetto was.
Interviewer: Because residents, I understand, the Polish and Jewish residents mixed in general?
Subject: They were mixed so some had to leave and others came.
Interviewer: In July?
Subject: In July.
Interviewer: The ghetto was set up in July 1940.
Subject: Starting from July, from July onward.
Interviewer: And what was it like until July?

Subject: The Jews could still go outside the town, when possible, they could buy food until July. Only work was compulsory. They had to report for work: 60, 100 or 50 persons, as many as requested by the Germans.
