Interviewer: But who?
Subject: Aged 16 to thir... to 60.
Interviewer: Who decided about the persons going to work?
Subject: Well, the mayor. The mayor of the town of Gora Kalwaria. At the time, it was a German called Janke.
Interviewer: There was no Judenrat [Jewish Council] in Gora Kalwaria?
Subject: There was and the Judenrat designated the people for work.
Interviewer: Designated.
Subject: Yes, the Judenrat.
Interviewer: Who were the members [of the Judenrat]?
Subject: Members of the Judenrat?
Interviewer: Yes, who were they?
Subject: Well, there were the Orthodox Jews... there were the Hasidic Jews and the progressive Jews, the same leaders that were there before
Interviewer: Meaning those were...
Subject: It was a Jewish community so it was the leadership of the community, still activelater.
Interviewer: Were they relatively known activists?
Subject: Activists, known activists from every organization. The majority were the Orthodox Jews because they were the largest group.
Interviewer: Did it happen in the same way as in other towns and cities? When the Germans arrived in Gora Kalwaria, they summoned one of the Jewish elders?

Subject: Yes, yes, yes, just the same, [they summoned] the elder and said that the Jews were to comply with all orders and regulations issued by the Germans. Otherwise, there was death penalty even though the ghetto was not in place yet.
Interviewer: And compulsory work.
Subject: Compulsory. Work was compulsory, compulsory.
Interviewer: You mean 60 persons? Were all involved in that work?

Subject: Everybody, there was no difference. Everybody, each person designated [inaudible] by the Judenrat had to report... for work in front of the town hall starting from 7 am. The Germans would then come and take them to perform various onerous jobs. It was predominantly dirty work such as cleaning toilets, stables etc.
Interviewer: It is not... Did the Judenrat designate all persons or were there some people who did not work?
Subject: In rare cases. Probably the sick and the elderly.
Interviewer: Did you have any permanent job at the time?
Subject: Did I have a permanent job? Well, as as...
Interviewer: In addition to forced labor assignments.

Subject: A tailor, I sewed in my free time because customers would come to me. The Catholics came to me as long as they were allowed. I sewed for them whenever I could. Of course, I charged very low rates but at least I could sew.
Interviewer: And where did you...
Subject: During that period.
Interviewer: During that period.
Subject: Yes, yes.
Interviewer: Were you also involved in that forced labor assignments?
Subject: Well, of course. When I was designated for work, I had to report at 7 am and work until 4 or 5 pm. I still had some free time so I could, I had to do something.
Interviewer: And how was it?
Subject: It was hard, believe me.
Interviewer: What kind of work did you do?

Subject: I had to go and clear snow from roads. I once had to go to the barracks and take out some garbage. One time they took me to the stables because they knew that I had been in the army and that I am familiar with the job. I was told to clean those... I had to remove horse manure from stables. Well, I did all that. Obviously, later on they took us into the ghetto, then from the ghetto...
Interviewer: How about your mother?

Subject: My mother was an elderly woman. She was suffering from poor health so they didn't take her to work. She stayed at home as far as possible. When she felt well enough, she continued to sew as long as she was allowed to. And later she couldn't sew, the customers stopped coming because it was forbidden.
Interviewer: During that period until July 1940, was there hunger, for example?
Subject: We were hungry from day one.
Interviewer: From day one.

Subject: From day one. In Gora Kalwaria, 80% of the Jewish population were poor. Just poor people. Those 20% were, more or less, craftsmen and merchants and such. They were slightly better off. You could count rich people on the fingers of your hands only. There were maybe five or six rich persons.
Interviewer: Did the Judenrat organize any help for the poor? Did they hand out [food]?
Subject: Well, they arranged lunches.
Interviewer: Lunches?

Subject: From the moment they had organized themselves, the Judenrat was established and they started offering lunches but what difference would those lunches make? What that lunch, that little soup, could change for those poor?
Interviewer: For all?
Subject: Whoever wanted could get that lunch.

Dobrze to możemy tak mówić sobie teraz swobodnie.

Subject:

Już w tej chwili?

Interviewer:

Znaczy nie, tak tylko dla

Subject:

Jak powiedzą że tego, jak normalnie no tak będę mówił, tak, oczywiście jestem wzruszony nie ulega żadnej wątpliwości, chyba jeszcze nie na chodzie na…

Interviewer:

Nie, nie.

Interviewer:

Proszę 

Subject:

Pochodzę z małego miasteczka na południu od Warszawy, nazywa się Góra Kalwaria. Tak jak wszystkie małe miasteczka w Polsce tak i Góra Kalwaria był zamieszkany przez dość liczną społeczność żydowską. Można powiedzieć że Góra Kalwaria liczyła tak pół na pół, 50 procent było katolików a 50 procent Żydów. Z tym że Góra Kalwaria odróżnia się od wszystkich innych miaste… prowincjonalnych miasteczek że tam był ten słynny cadyk z rodziny Alterów, gdzie bardzo były duże zjazdy na święta. Szczególnie na święta jak Jom Kippur [Yom Kippur], jak Rosz HaSzune [Rosh HaShana], czyli to jest nowy rok, Zielone Świątki to się nazywa Szewues [Shavuot], bardzo dużo ludzi przyjeżdżało wtedy i w ogóle odbywali swoje pielgrzymki właśnie do tego cadyka. I tym się właśnie Góra Kalwaria różniła w ogóle od innych miast w Polsce.

Interviewer:

A przepraszam bardzo, a może Pan powiedzieć swoje nazwisko?

Subject:

Aha. Nazywam się Prajs [Prais] Henryk. Urodziłem się w Górze Kalwarii, w tej chwili mam lat 78.

Interviewer:

Pan się urodził w tysiąc którym roku…

Subject:

W którym roku? Tysiąc dziewięćset szesnasty rok, 30. grudnia 16. roku. No i tak mniej więcej wygląda pokrótce. Urodziłem się w biednej rodzinie. Nie mogę w ogóle mówić o żadnym bogactwie dlatego że ojca w ogóle nie miałem. Mojego ojca zabili bandyci, konkretnie bandyci. To był napad bandycki, w dwudziestym chyba pierwszym, czy w dwudziestym drugim roku. Sam ja jeszcze byłem w ogóle bardzo mały, wtedy ile mogłem mieć lat? Ja wiem [inaudible], no coś koło tego miałem dwa czy trzy latka miałem, więcej nie miałem. Czyli to mogło być nawet w 18. roku, tak. Także ojca nie pamiętam. Byłem wychowany, było nas troje dzieci. Matka była krawcową. W miarę możliwości wszelkimi siłami starała się nam dać jakieś minimalne wykształcenie w postaci szkoły podstawowej. Czyli wtedy była szkoła powszechna. Kończąc 7 lat uczęszczałem do szkoły, do pierwszej klasy. Bardzo miło wspominam ten czas. Nauczyciele byli bardzo mili do nas, w ogóle do żydowskich dzieci. W ogóle Góra Kalwaria charakteryzowała się tym że w ogóle tam w okresie przedwojennym nie występował żaden antysemityzm. Czyli społeczeństwo żydowskie również i polskie żyli bardzo dobrze ze sobą.

Interviewer:

A czy pan pochodził z rodziny religijnej?

Subject:

Czy ja? Nie. Pochodzę z religijnej nie, pochodzę z rodziny nie religijnej tylko z rodziny żydowskiej postępowej. Tak.

Interviewer:

Tak

Subject:

Czyli ja nie byłem Chusetem [Chasydem] byłem normalnym tak jak każde jedne żydowskie dziecko tak samo ja, z tym że uczęszczałem do szkoły powszechnej polskiej i również uczyłem się języka żydowskiego w szkole żydowskiej, czyli tak zwany cheder. Jednocześnie cokolwiek uczyłem się języka hebrajskiego, wtedy, teraz, obecnie ivrit, a dawniej to się mówiło język hebrajski. Tak stąd właśnie znam cokolwiek język hebrajski. No, w miarę możliwości uczyłem się względnie. Skończyłem 6 klas szkoły podsta… powszechnej. Dalej nie mogłem się uczyć bo dlatego że warunki w domu nie były konieczne. Nie były dobre, także uczyłem się ja…, poszedłem do zawodu krawieckiego. Uczyłem się przez parę lat, później

Interviewer:

Ale gdzie? Też w Górze Kalwarii?

Subject:

W Górze Kalwarii, tak, majster mój nazywał się Cybula, konkretnie Cybula, tak on się nazywał.

Interviewer:

On był Polakiem?

Subject:

Nie, on był pochodzenia żydowskiego, tak. Uczyłem się tam, skończyłem u niego chyba trzy lata, później pracowałem u Góreckiego, który był katolik. Górecki, na imię jak on miał to już nawet nie pamiętam, ale Górecki nazywał się. U niego pracowałem też chyba przez 2 lata, prac… pracowałem u Jasińskiego chyba też ze 2 lata jako krawiec. No i później nadszedł okres do wojska.

Interviewer:

Ale proszę powiedzieć mi jeszcze taką jedną rzecz, czy, znaczy pan mówił o Górze Kalwarii. Ilu było mieszkańców w tym okresie kiedy pan się urodził i w okresie dzieciństwa?

Subject:

Ilu było mieszkańców. Więc Góra Kalwaria liczyła w ogóle mieszkańców około 7 tysięcy. W tym było około 3 tys. było Żydów i około 4 tys. było Polaków, czyli razem Góra Kalwaria, razem z tym, te,, jak to się nazywa, ob.. obe..

Interviewer:

Z peryferiami?

Subject:

Tak tak, ale to się nazywa, ober.. nie, nie oberża, tylko to się nazywa, no te, te, nie sama Góra Kalwaria tylko te

Interviewer:

Peryferie

Subject:

O peryferie, nie, ale

Interviewer:

Góry

Subject:

mogą, mogą, może być

Interviewer:

Obrzeża Góry Kalwarii, tak

Subject:

O, o to mi chodziło.

Interviewer:

Znaczy było 3 tysiące mieszkańców żydowskiego pochodzenia

Subject:

Ile było? Tak.

Interviewer:

3 tysiące a wśród nich jakie były tendencje? Bo ja rozumiem że tam była przecież bardzo silna ta grupa Chasydzka?

Subject:

Więc normalnie to owszem jeżeli chodzi, bardzo dużo rzemieślników, między innymi ja w swoich wspomnieniach to napisałem. Przeważnie Góra Kalwaria bo żadnych tam fabryk wtedy nie było, nic absolutnie, tylko były tylko zakłady usługowe, rzemieślnicze, a mianowicie krawiectwo, szewstwo, kamasznictwo, no, czapnicy, no i rymarstwo, i tym podobne, także stolarstwo, także piekarzy bardzo duże było. Także z tego składała się ta ta cała Góra Kalwaria, no bo innej

Interviewer:

A ilu było tych religijnych, tych Chasydów?

Subject:

Religijnych, jeżeli chodzi o samych religijnych to nie było, znaczy było więcej postępowych, w postaci, właśnie to tak jak to oznaczyłem, ludu, no ludu żydowskiego, tak jak kiedyś pisał ten nasz wielki pisarz Sholem Aleichem – “pochodzimy z ludu” – no Żydzi, normalnie owszem może i byli wierzący nie ulega żadnej wątpliwości że byli wierzący, ale postępowi, nie, nie nosili te, te tzw. ortodoksyjne te te ubrania, tylko normalnie byli ubrani po europejsku. A Żydów tych Chasydów to mogło być w Górze Kalwarii, jeżeli było trzech tysięcy Żydów, około tysiąca było wyznaw… ale nie, nie zwolennicy Góry, nie zwolennicy cadyka podkreślam tylko normalnie zwolennicy znaczy Chasydyzmu.

Interviewer:

Różnych nurtów

Subject:

Tak, tak, tak, różnych bo tak samo należeli do, mieli tego swego rabina w Kozienicach, mieli w Kłodzku i w Górze Kalwarii też byli, znaczy byli wyznawcy tego cadyka z Góry Kalwarii.

Interviewer:

A ilu mniej więcej było zwolenników właśnie tego cadyka z Góry Kalwarii?

Subject:

No ja wiem, tak mogę określić, nie było więcej jak do pięciuset.

Interviewer:

Pięciuset 

Subject:

Jego zwolenników z Góry Kalwarii konkretnie, więcej nie było.

Interviewer:

Bo pan wie że dzisiaj patrząc na to niewątpliwie Góra Kalwaria jest jakby jednym z głównych tych nurtów w Izraelu i w Ameryce.

Subject:

Tak a to dlatego że, z głównych nurtów, dlatego że do Góry Kalwarii przyjeżdżali właśnie Żydzi przeważnie ortodoksi z całej Polski. To jest właśnie, bardzo dużo było w Łodzi, bardzo dużo, z Krakowa i w ogóle ze wszystkich miast z Polski, przyjeżdżało do Góry Kalwarii do cadyka i stąd właśnie bierze się ta, ta jego wielkość. No nie ulega żadnej wątpliwości był to człowiek mądry bo bardzo dużo nawet i katolicy przychodzili konkretnie do niego z różnymi pytaniami, różne takie te różne, jak to mówi się, jak to określić

Interviewer:

Pytania, kushiyot

Subject:

Jak?

Interviewer:

Zagadki, pytania, problemy

Subject:

Nie, nie, pytania, ale jeszcze inaczej się mówi, jeszcze inaczej można to określić, wskazówki, no wskazania, wskazania no w ogóle z jego wiedzą chcieli to i to zrobić. Między innymi był taki znany obywatel Góry Kalwarii Lech nazywał się, imię jego też nie pamiętam. On w ogóle bez, bez akceptacji cadyka Góry Kalwarii on nic nie robił. Czy w ogóle miał coś budować czy miał coś kupić czy coś to w ogóle musiał przyjść na na na konkretnie do cadyka na na poradę, o, poradę.

Interviewer:

A pan go spotykał na ulicy tego cadyka?

Subject:

Lecha?

Interviewer:

Nie, cadyka z Góry Kalwarii, Elstera [Altera]?

Subject:

Cadyka, on w ogóle nie wychodził, on się nie ukazał

Interviewer:

Nie wychodził

Subject:

Nie, on jeżeli chodził, tak w ogóle żeby chodził po mieście w Górze Kalwarii nie ukazał się. Natomiast dla swoich wiernych co sobota o godzinie 15. to na swoim balkonie spacerował z 10, 15 minut dla swoich wiernych tam i z powrotem, ukazał się, nic nie mówił, tylko ukazał się. Jego wierni byli na podwórku, czyli jego wyznawcy i obserwowali i byli oczywiście bardzo zadowoleni że mogą właśnie oglądać cadyka.

Interviewer:

A jak wyglądał jego dom?

Subject:

Proszę?

Interviewer:

Jak wyglądał dom tego cadyka?

Subject:

Jak wyglądało w domu, ja w ogóle

Interviewer:

Znaczy nie, dom z zewnątrz, był duży, mały

Subject:

A na z zewnątrz, ten dom jest do dnia dzisiejszego.

Interviewer:

Tak?

Subject:

Tak, oczywiście bez... Nie ulega żadnej wątpliwości że mieszkał trochę ładniej aniżeli przeciętny Żyd z Góry Kalwarii. Bo przed wojną jeżeli jakiś mieszkaniec pochodzenia żydowskiego jak miał pokój z kuchnią w Górze Kalwarii to już była wielka rzecz. Muszę powiedzieć że ja sam wychowałem się w jednym mieszkaniu. W tym mieszkaniu był i warsztat i w ogóle mama szyła w tym warsztacie.

Interviewer:

W jednym pokoju?

Subject:

W tym pokoju. W ogóle nawet nie chce się w ogóle na ten temat mówić bo to jest bardzo to jest przykre w porównaniu do teraźniejszych czasów. A jeżeli chodzi o cadyka na pewno miał kilka pokoi. I bożnica była dość okazała, która jest do dnia dzisiejszego. I przyjeżdżają do, dużo tych pielgrzymek z całego świata, w odwiedziny, oczywiście jego zwolennicy, nie tylko jego wyznawcy tylko w ogóle Żydzi. Mają to jak to się mówi w tym jako dowód uznania dla wielkości tego cadyka z Góry Kalwarii.

Interviewer:

A czy pan mieszkaniec z Góry Kalwarii był z tego dumny że tam mieszka ten słynny cadyk? Czy to w ogóle pana nie obchodziło?

Subject:

Jeżeli chodzi, jeżeli chodzi nie tylko ja, bo w ogóle trzeba powiedzieć wszyscy mieszkańcy Góry Kalwarii byliśmy tym może nie dumni ale byliśmy zadowoleni dlatego że Góra Kalwaria podczas tych świąt, jak podkreślałem na początku, Jom Kippur [Yom Kippur], Rosz Haszune [Rosh HaShana] i Szewues [Shavuot] to przyjeżdżało bardzo dużo ludzi. Co nota bene wynajmowali mieszkania tam u tych biedniejszych, między innymi jeszcze tak pomimo że to był jeden pokój jeszcze mama wynajęła po to żeby zarobić te parę groszy. I i między innymi magistrat też również zarobił parę groszy bo ci co przyjeżdżali do Góry Kalwarii musieli taki wpłacać do magistratu po złotówce od głowy. Także magistrat w tym w tym okresie jak przyjeżdżało dajmy na to do dwóch tysięcy, bo tam określają tyle i tyle, nieprawda. Bo Góra Kalwaria liczyła 7 tysięcy ludzi nie mogła pomieścić więcej aniżeli aniżeli tam do dwóch tysięcy ludzi. Bo przecież gdzie by to się pomieściło? [Inaudible] gdzie zasilili budżet państwa, czyli tam Góry Kalwarii. Był bardzo zacny był burmistrz Dziejko [?] który naprawdę u wszystkich Żydów, obojętnie, nie tylko u nas, miał wielkie zasługi i wielkie uznanie. On był również filosemitą był. Między innymi podczas wyborów do rady miejskiej koniecznie wyznaczył że właśnie Żydzi muszą dać swoich tych radnych do do miasta. Również mieliśmy bardzo dobrego komendanta, ostatnie lata. Nazywał się Janica. Trzeba powiedzieć że on tak samo wtedy kiedy były takie no niestety w Górze Kalwarii, Góra Kalwaria też przeżywała różne takie kiedy ta Falanga w latach trzydzieści siedem, osiem, no w dziewiątym to już było mniej bo już była ta, ta psychoza wojenna, to już może mniej było tych ekscesów, ale też było rozwalanie straganów, tam nie kupuj u Żyda, u Żyda. I przyjeżdżali z tak z okolicznych tych miejscowości jak z Warki jak z Grójca jak z Kaczewia, z Otwocka. I jak komendant podkreślał, "To tu uważajcie Żydzi, nie wolno wam się dać, brońcie się jak tylko możecie." Ten właśnie komendant, czyli po prostu bardzo dobry człowiek. No on niestety zginął w Katyniu, co w ogóle cała ludność ubolewała nad tym że on właśnie tam zginął. No nie mogliśmy mu dać żadnej pomocy bo w tym okresie no kto w ogóle, w ogóle nawet wiedział. Bo on opuścił Górę Kalwarię jak wszyscy policjanci co udali się na na wschód, tam biedny zginął, no. Ubolewamy nawet do dnia dzisiejszego, kto w ogóle pamięta Janicę ubolewa nad tym. No jeżeli chodzi o mnie dalej no to i wtedy

Interviewer:

Ale proszę powiedzieć jakie były w ogóle stosunki między ludnością miejscową żydowską a polską?

Subject:

Jeżeli chodzi o stosunki tak jak podkreślałem były bardzo dobre. Bardzo dobre. Góra Kalwaria jeżeli chodzi z punktu widzenia antysemityzmu w ogóle nie poz... nie doznała. I w ogóle tego nie było, nie, w ogóle nie występowało jeżeli chodzi o samą ludność Góry Kalwarii.

Interviewer:

U pana w domu mówiło się w języku polskim?

Subject:

Czy u nas?

Interviewer:

W domu.

Subject:

Czy mówiło się po polsku? I po polsku i po żydowsku.

Interviewer:

A pierwszym pana językiem jaki był?

Subject:

No oczywiście żydowski.

Interviewer:

Żydowski

Subject:

Żydowski, to nie ulega żadnej wątpliwości. Ale później w ramach wychowania się ponieważ na naszym podwórku mieszkało bardzo dużo tak samo prawie 50 procent Polaków i 50 procent Żydów. Więc miałam kolegów jak Bronek Woźniak, Józek, jak Olek Rytko, jak w ogóle no i Maniek Jarosz. Tak jak to podkreślam z całym szacunkiem dla tych ludzi jak na przykład jak wróciłem z tej tego nieszczęścia z dajmy na to tam z terenu tam gdzie byłem przechowywany to pierwsze moje kroki były do pana Rytki. Nazywał się Franciszek, szewc. I który nota bene przechowywał proszę pana różne księgi żydowskie. To jest to jest wielka wielka wielka rzecz, i przechowywał nawet zdjęcie mojego dziadka. Przechowywał to co nawet nie wiem czy nawet nie do pomyślenia. I nie obawiał się, przechowywał i który to wszystko mi oddał, a ja z kolei oddałem do Warszawy do Kongregacji Wyznaniowej, w 46. roku.

Interviewer:

A w szkole? Ja rozumiem że pan powiedział że byli i chłopcy Polacy i Żydzi. 

Subject:

Tak, tak, mniej, mniej

Interviewer:

Więcej Żydów by było w tej szkole?

Subject:

Nie mogę się [inaudible]. Mniej było tych żydowskich chłopców, bardzo mało. Oczywiście z takich progresywnych domów żydowskich to dzieci chodziły do szkoły polskiej. A z takich chasydzkich to raczej nie. Raczej profesorowie przychodzili do nich do domu, uczyli się po polsku, ale mało. A dziewczęta to więcej, więcej dziewcząt uczęszczało do szkoły podstawowej, do powszechnej.

Interviewer:

Tak. A proszę coś opowiedzieć o swoim rodzeństwie, pan miał siostrę i brata?

Subject:

Miałem siostrę. No siostra. I brat został zastrzelony.

Interviewer:

Nie ale w tym okresie przed wojną jeszcze, oni, pan był najstarszy?

Subject:

Przed wojną siostra też skończyła siedem klas szkoły podstawowej w Górze Kalwarii, tak samo jak i ja. Ja mówię podstawowa dlatego że już używam język powojenny, to się nazywało szkoła powszechna. Również bardzo dobrze się uczyła, była bardzo zdolna bo, bo w ogóle jak skończyła szkołę pojechała do Warszawy. Pracowała na Radzymińskiej 14. Tam była taka mała mydlarnia i tam prowadziła księgowość do tego stopnia, taka w ogóle była dobra uczennica. A ja tak samo też byłem średnim, znaczy się z polskiego miałem bardzo dobre stopnie, z historii, z niemieckiego, jeżeli chodzi o matematykę trochę byłem słabszy, ale zdałem, zdawałam. Nie było problemu w ogóle ze mną. Tak.

Interviewer:

A brat pana?

Subject:

Brat też skończył tak samo. Brat skończył sześć, normalnie sześć klas tak samo jak i ja. Do siódmej to tak samo bo poszedł bo ja wtedy już byłem w wojsku, a on poszedł, a on poszedł na rymarza, nie ja jeszcze nie byłem w wojsku, bo jeszcze pracowałem jako krawiec, jako czeladnik, a on uczył się rymarstwa. Był rymarzem. U Połonieckiego.

Interviewer:

Rozumiem. A proszę powiedzieć w którym roku pan poszedł został zmobilizowany do wojska?

Subject:

W 37. roku

Interviewer:

Czyli mając lat 21?

Subject:

W tysiąc dziewięćset, tak, tak. Tysiąc dziewięćset, czwartego listopada poszedłem do wojska, do Suwałk. To był, to był pułk wyborowy, Trzeci Pułk Szwoleżerów, tych takich pułków w Polsce mieliśmy tylko 3. Pierwszy Pułk Szwoleżerów to był w Warszawie na ulicy Szwoleżerów, to był, pod pod nazwą, bo to nie będzie [inaudible] tylko tak pod nazwą Józefa Piłsudskiego, Drugi Pułk Szwoleżerów był w tym w Starogardzie Gdańskim, dowódcą był, pod nazwą Wernickiego. A Trzeci Pułk Szwoleżerów był w Suwałkach pod nazwą Jana Hipolita Kozietulskiego, ten który zdobył Wąwóz Samosierry.

Interviewer:

Samosierry.

Subject:

Tak.

Interviewer:

I pan był w Suwałkach?

Subject:

I ten pułk stał w Suwałkach. Oczywiście tam, będąc dość zdolnym żołnierzem, dać, wybrali mnie do szkoły, do szkoły podoficerskiej i skończyłem tą szkołę w tym, to był, 8 miesięcy, ośmio-miesięczny kurs taki szkoleniowy, w tym samym pułku. Skończyłem w stopniu kaprala, no i później zamiast do domu w 39. roku we wrześniu, no to niestety wybuchła wojna. Zaraz

Interviewer:

Ale proszę powiedzieć mi wcześniej, pan był, znaczy pan poszedł do pułku szwoleżerów

Subject:

Tak

Interviewer:

I, znaczy pan był jednym z nielicznych Żydów w tym pułku? Czy było jeszcze wielu?

Subject:

Czterech razy było, czterech Żydów, tak, nie czterech tylko w każdym szwadronie było po cztery osoby pochodzenia żydowskiego.

Interviewer:

Dlaczego? Tak, takie były wskazówki?

Subject:

No tak akuratnie, czy był taki ogóle limit czy nie, tego to ja nie wiem

Interviewer:

To był przypadek może

Subject:

Mniej więcej tak było, były 4 szwadrony i w każdym jednym szwadronie było czterech Żydów. W tym moim szwadronie był tak, tak jak ja, Prajs [Prais] Henryk, Kylberg [?] Jan, Feldman Jakub, i czwarty był... Już nie pamiętam czwartego.

Interviewer:

Nie pamięta Pan. A jakie były stosunki z kolegami?

Subject:

Dobre bardzo, bardzo mnie lubieli. Bar... mogę podkreślić to w stu procentach do dnia dzisiejszego. A między innymi podczas wojny miałem kolegę nazywał się Józef Wolski. Będąc na froncie to jeden do drugiego tak mówił, słuchaj Heniek jak ty przeżyjesz wojnę gdybym ja zginął daj tam znać do mojej rodziny. On mieszkał w sieradzkim, on mówi ja zginę to ty daj znać. No oczywiście później myśmy się rozstali bo ja poszedłem dalej, z tym szwadronem w kierunku w kierunku po w kierunku południa bo mieliśmy się tam przedostać przez Czerwony Bór.

Interviewer:

Ale pan już mówi o okresie wojny, prawda?

Subject:

Okresie wojny

Interviewer:

To jeszcze możemy się skoncentrować na temat pana służby wojskowej. Jak pan przyjeżdżał np. na urlopy do kraju, do Góry Kalwarii, to pan przyjeżdżał na dłużej i jak było?

Subject:

Tak jak najbardziej, o to byłem bardzo szanowany, bardzo uważany. Wszyscy się oglądali, takie panie były znaczy szwoleżer bo to myśmy się odróżniali od innych bo inne wojska to mieli rogatywki a myśmy mieli okrągłe czapki, o żółty otok, także po prostu ja byłem dumny, no szabla przy boku no jak to się no, i to w ogóle także tylko to mogę określić [inaudible]

Interviewer:

A czy był rabin np. w tych jednostkach szwoleżerów?

Subject:

Był. Był rabin, tylko on był w ogóle z całej brygady, z brygady białostockiej, czyli garnizon będzie, to nie będzie brygada bo brygada była samodzielna suwalska, to nie, tylko była, był garnizon białostocki. To był rabin w stopniu kapitana naz... nazwisko jego nie pamiętam. Ale był, przyjeżdżał do nas na różne pogadanki oczywiście na tematy religijne na tematy znaczy na tematy społeczne i nawet polityczne. On w stosunku żeby właśnie Żydzi powinni być oddani w stosunku do, do państwa bo na pierwszym miejscu to jest państwo, na pierwszym miejscu jest wojsko, a następnie to jest owszem odprawiał co niedziela, co niedziela, prowadzili nas do modlitwy do synagogi tam.

Interviewer:

W niedzielę a nie w sobotę?

Subject:

Co niedzielę, nie w sobotę, tylko w niedzielę. I katolików prowadzili do, do kościoła, prawosławnych do cerkwi, ewangelików do kirchy, a Żydów prowadzili do do bożnicy.

Interviewer:

Ale jak to prowadzili? Znaczy panowie szli

Subject:

Normalnie, prowadzili, każdy miał swoje, dostał jakiegoś tam starszego który tę grupę prowadził. Również było czterech Niemców tylko, czterech ewangelików tak samo.

Interviewer:

A jeżeli pan nie chciał iść do ani do synagogi ani

Subject:

To nie było przymusowe, nie

Interviewer:

Nie było przymusu

Subject:

Nie nie to nie było przymusowe. Tak samo podczas modlitwy wieczornej jak był tam rano, “Kiedy Ranne Wstają Zorze,” wieczorem “Wszystkie Nasze Dzień,” to nie, Żydzi nie byli zobowiaząni, kto chciał mógł sobie stanąć, kto nie to w ogóle mógł wystąpić i sobie tam iść. Taki był [inaudible]

Interviewer:

Także rozumiem że nie było, że życie żołnierza Żyda było zupełnie podobne do życia żołnierza Polaka?

Subject:

Jak najbardziej, jak najbardziej. To nie było żadnej różnicy w ogóle podczas ćwiczeń. Podobnie jeżeli był zdolny był wyróżniany tak samo jak każdy jeden inny. Także to w ogóle nie odczuwało się absolutnie w wojsku.

Interviewer:

I służba wojskowa w tym okresie trwała ile? Dwa lata?

Subject:

Dwa lata

Interviewer:

Dwa lata. Bo Pan poszedł w 37. roku, miał pan zostać

Subject:

W 37. roku, dwadzieścia jeden lat

Interviewer:

Tak, miał pan

Subject:

Niecałe 21, bo ja kończę lata trzydziestego grudnia, ale to jest nieistotne, tak, liczy się tylko miesiąc, liczy się rok.

Interviewer:

I znaczy miał pan się znaczy udać do rezerwy w 39. roku?

Subject:

W 39. roku miałem pójść do rezerwy już.

Interviewer:

Także wojna zastała pana już

Subject:

Wojna zastała mnie od razu właśnie w zamiast [inaudible] tylko od razu od pierwszej chwili, nasz pułk

Interviewer:

Pan był żołnierzem kiedy wybuchła wojna?

Subject:

Tak. Byłem w czynnej służbie. Byłem w stopniu kaprala. Tak.

Interviewer:

A jaka była atmosfera z jednej strony w mieście w Kalwarii, w Górze Kalwarii przed wojną?

Subject:

To mi jest trudno określić dlatego że ja w tym okresie nie byłem, a tak samo, ta sama psychoza tak jak wszędzie, no w ogóle wiadomo było o tym że w ogóle, nawet bo ja wróciłem do Góry Kalwarii w tym, w okresie, w grudniu, to już wszyscy myśleli że ja zginąłem bo w ogóle nie mogłem dać znać bo byłem w niewoli, to jest internowany byłem w rosyjskiej, w tym, w, w, w Rosji no.

Interviewer:

Znaczy ja rozumiem odczuwało się już ja wiem od lata 39. roku było jakby wiadomo że wojna wybuchnie?

Subject:

No owszem u nas w pułku tak samo, bo ja w swoich wspomnieniach napisałem to, bo nawet myśmy się dziwili bo jeżeli chodzi o samo przemówienie Becka, wtedy nie pamiętam czy to było w marcu czy wtedy kiedy powiedział że już [inaudible] myśmy wiedzieli. Czuliśmy to, to w wojsku, że jest jakaś inna jakaś inna atmosfera, bo wydali nam już hełmy, już niektórzy poszli tam kopać te czyli

Interviewer:

Okopy

Subject:

Okopy, zasieki, także myśmy to czuli. No i później, no i tak samo jak w całym państwie, myśmy to, tak jak w całym państwie no to w ogóle było wiadomo było nawet myśmy, ja nawet to w swoich wspomnieniach to wspominałem o tym że przecież Beck powiedział że nie nie tylko nie oddamy Gdańska ale nawet guzika od munduru nie damy. A to niestety podczas wojny to myśmy wiedzieli że to było panie tylko, to się mówi to, to nie było realne. No już nie będę mówił o jakimś tam innym

Interviewer:

Tak ale pan jako żołnierz polski oczywiście wierzył wtedy w zwycięstwo i wielką przewagę oręża polskiego?

Subject:

A no myśmy, może nie tyle w zwycięstwo tylko no duch, i każdy jeden z nas był po prostu mocno przywiązany do swojej ojczyzny i do tego, obojętnie no bo wtedy my szliśmy z duchem pełnym przekonania no że zwyciężymy, bo wtedy mieliśmy jak to się mówi, jeszcze w dodatku wtedy kiedy Anglia i Francja wypowiedzieli Niemcom wojnę, to myśmy wszyscy myśleli faktycznie że to no że zwyciężymy, no że nie damy się. No okazało się później inaczej. No.

Interviewer:

Tak ale czy stosunek, stosunek pana i pańskich kolegów Żydów głównie, a z drugiej strony jakieś tam obawy. No chodzi mi głównie o stosunek pana i pańskich kolegów do Niemców, czy był inny od kolegów Polaków?

Subject:

Jeżeli chodzi w samym pułku muszę stwierdzić to w stu procentach tam z odpowiedzialnością nie było żadnej różnicy. Miałem kolegów tak samo ewangelików, Bertold, Zoller, Pratz [?], Mann, dokładnie pamiętam nawet nazwiska ich, i żyliśmy bardzo dobrze ze sobą.

Interviewer:

No tak ale

Subject:

W pułku, no wtedy kiedy żyliśmy w koszarach.

Interviewer:

Ale znaczy nie, nie o to mi chodzi. W 33. roku kiedy Hitler doszedł do władzy

Subject:

I trzeba powiedzieć że ci Niemcy byli do ostatniej chwili, nie nie jednak nie zdradzili

Interviewer:

Tak

Subject:

Niemcy byli do ostatniej chwili, wtedy kiedy Polska, myśmy się dostali się znaczy do niewoli nasz pułk, oni byli do ostatniej chwili. Natomiast wtedy kiedy dostaliśmy się na tereny wschodnie wszyscy Ukraińcy i Białorusini zdezertowali.

Interviewer:

Ja rozumiem, ale dzisiaj z perspektywy 50 iluś tam lat od wybuchu wojny, znaczy mówi się, po pierwsze, w 33. roku kiedy Hitler doszedł do władzy

Subject:

Tak

Interviewer:

Że jakby wszyscy Żydzi, większość Żydów jakby wiedziała co w ogóle Hitler szykuje dla Żydów. W związku z tym pytanie jest takie czy na przykład w 33. roku pan mając lat wtedy 17, prawda?

Subject:

Tak, nie, więcej,

Interviewer:

Czy pan, więcej, 16, 17. Po tej aferze w Zbąszyniu, po Brylantowej Nocy. Tak. Kryształowej Nocy. Czy w ogóle pana obawy ze strony Niemców były większe niż kolegi Polaka?

Subject:

Nie ulega żadnej wątpliwości że wtedy Żydzi ale nikt sobie nie wyobrażał nikt z rodu żydowskiego nikt podkreślam nikt że coś takiego może nastąpić, że nawet w Niemczech, wiedzieliśmy o tej nocy wiedzieliśmy o tym w ogóle o prześladowaniu. Myśmy wiedzieli o tej książce co on wydał “Mein Kampf.” No i w ogóle no przecież trzeba powiedzieć że w latach trzydziestych była silna emigracja już wtedy i o w ogóle nie tylko u nas. Bo u nas w Górze Kalwarii też były kibuce, byli panie, między innymi ja sam należałem do Hapoel, należałem do Poalej Syjonu [Polaei Tziyon], więc ja też. Wszyscy myśmy myśleli o emigracji ale emigracja nie była taka łatwa. Przede wszystkim nie nie można było dostać certyfikatu, nie można było dostać, więc gdyby wszyscy w ogóle przewidywali to co jest i nie ulega żadnej wątpliwości że wszyscy, może nie wszyscy bo starsi może nie, by wyemigrowali do Izraela czy w ogóle gdzie indziej, ale to w ogóle kto sobie, nikt sobie nie wyobrażał że coś takiego może nastąpić. O to chodzi.

Interviewer:

Ja rozumiem, ale pan znaczy pan wspomniał że pan miał jakby orientację syjonistyczną, należał pan do Hashomer Hatzair, i to jest od wczesnych lat młodzieńczych już taka była orientacja u pana?

Subject:

Od najmł… od 13. roku życia, należałem do tego. To wpierw byłem skautem a później normalnie członkiem

Interviewer:

Znaczy w Hatzair czy?

Subject:

Nie, Poalei Tziyon

Interviewer:

Poalei Tziyon. Tak?

Subject:

Poalei Tziyon - Prawica. Prawica.

Interviewer:

Prawica?

Subject:

Tak, Ber Borochowa [Ber Borochov]. Zwolennink Ber Borochowa.

Interviewer:

I ta organizacja była duża w Górze Kalwarii?

Subject:

W ogóle w w Górze Kalwarii były różne organizacje. Była komunistyczna partia, była Bund tak samo, najmniejsza partia to była Bundowska, a syjonistyczna to byli te, w tym mizrachiści właśnie co oni należeli do ortodoksów, byli te Shomer Haleumi, czyli ta organizacja Herzla, prawicowi syjoniści i była wlaśnie ta Poalei Tziyon, tylko jedna Poalei Tziyon – Prawica, lewicy nie było.

Interviewer:

I pan tam był członkiem tej organizacji aż do wojska?

Subject:

Byłem członkiem tej organizacji tak

Interviewer:

Aż do, aż do pójścia do wojska?

Subject:

Aż do pójścia do wojska.

Interviewer:

No dobrze. [inaudible]

Subject:

Nawet koledzy mnie żegnali

Interviewer:
Przerwę zrobimy krótką.
Segment 6

My last leave was for Christmas 1938. I spent it at my mother's. Most Jews were very proud of me for two reasons. First because someone from Gora Kalwaria was in Light-cavalry and second because I was only a tailor. I was a very good soldier and was well respected and even once I was set as an example for others because of the way I rode a horse. I was section leader and besides the sabre I also had an RKM, a machine gun.

Since March 1939 there were no more leaves. We felt that the situation  was not good. I wrote letters to my mother (but she did not get my last ones). All Jews were afraid of the situation and a lot of them emigrated to Russia. 

Of course nobody backed up Stalin and his crimes because this was genocide but at least some Jews who had decided to go there, survived while in Poland the situation was different. I have survived because I had been given the address of the Pokorskis and hid there. 

I did not marry before W.W.II. About 150 people emigrated from Gora Kalwaria, about 30 returned from U.S.S.R.
Segment 7

On August 23 1939 there was mobilization, we were given ammunition and we went to Raczki, near Suwalki for maneuvers. On September 1 during breakfast we were told that the war had started and on the same day Suwalki railroad station was bombed. We were not allowed to undress and the next night we were ordered to go towards Kaliningrad. We reached a small village Reus (now Cimochy) and it was a German territory. We left the horses and entered on foot. There was a club, Germans were dancing and there were no guards. One of us threw a hand-grenade, there was panic and we took two German prisoners. I was an interpreter. We  stayed there for a few hours and following orders went back. It was difficult because German planes bombed all day long so we had  to hide in forests and marched only during the night. We marched east towards Zambrow, about Sept 11 or 10, we fought Germans, one of us died but we had horses and the regiment was intact. On Sept 13, in Olszewo we fought Germans again and about 20 of our soldiers were killed {several near Zambrow, cannot verify which one}. The commandant of the regiment was hurt, I was hurt too in the back of my neck, hand and leg and my immediate  commandant, officer cadet Glusek died, two meters away from me.
Segment 8

I was not fit for combat any more and I was taken to the doctor and  sent to the transport and supply columns which went  to Hrodna (while the regiment went further and fought near Kock on October 5). My columns reached Shchuchyn Nowogrodzki and then we were disarmed by the Russian Army. Major Diaczenko let us free to go and since it was impossible to back to Warsaw we went east. It was on September 17 when U.S.S.R began war with Poland. We  knew about it, but it was a surprise. Our commandant Witkowski told us not to fight Russians. I was taken by the Red Army and kept prisoner in Sztucin, near Lida. We were interned and later we planted forests near Minsk and later were exchanged. Germans and Poles (if they wanted to) could go back while Russians took Byelorussians and Ukrainians.

The exchange was between Russia and Germany in December so I had been interned in U.S.S.R, forty kilometres behind Minsk for a few months. There we cut and planted forests. If one cut or planted a set norm one got his food, nothing special but there was bread, soup coffee and fish cans so the conditions were not so bad, taking into account that we were prisoners. Russians treated me in the same way as others. I was not able to meet my norm requirements so two colleagues from Silesia helped me and so I was able to get dinner as well. 

Till December 1939 I did not have news from Poland, no letters. I knew that Warsaw had capitulated because Russians told us about it. They used to say that they were taking us prisoners "for the time being" but later we would fight Germans together.
Segment 9

After  the exchange I returned to Warsaw. I got civil clothes from an acquaintance in Shchuchyn and I had some army equipment too like my blanket and a sweater. I went by train, from  Bialystok to Lapy to Warsaw and Gora Kalwaria. Jews and Poles came to ask how it had been.

There were Germans in Gora Kalwaria, there were a lot of volksdeutche [ people who claimed they had German ancestors
and were treated as semi-Germans]. Volksdeutche immediately entered the black police. Jews between 16 and 60 years old were forced to work.  A young Jewish boy, Moszek Cybula was killed by Germans for taking a piece of bread, similarly Germans killed Pinierawski who was leaving a synagogue. Zaddik from Gora Kalwaria had been taken to Warsaw by Jews and protected by them {Abraham Mordecai Alter- EJ}. He was kept in a shoe-shop because craftsmen were relatively safe at that  time. Later Italian Embassy helped and he was taken to Triest due to the influence by a Pole, Stefan Porajski (a cousin of the President Moscicki) who worked at the Italian Embassy. He procured papers for the Zaddik and in autumn 1942 the zaddik and his family left Warsaw  for Rome in a specially ordered train car. He reached Triest.

Some believers were disappointed at his departure but other Jews, especially those who had helped him to go to Warsaw on a  raft (on the Wisla [Vistula] river) were glad because Germans as soon as they entered Gora Kalwaria started looking for him.
Segment 10

When I came back to Gora Kalwaria in December I had to remove snow from the streets (without payment) and other dirty jobs. There were arm-bands, and I wore one too. My mother told me I should have written to her and she would have told me not to come back. I stayed in Gora Kalwaria for a year and on February 25 and  26 1941 Jews were ordered to go to Warsaw ghetto (EJ). Before they  had lived in the ghetto in Gora Kalwaria since July 1940. Before the ghetto Poles and Jews had lived together were allowed to leave the town, buy food etc., but Jews were forced to work, German mayor Jenke decided how many would go to work and Judenrat [Jewish Council] decided who would go to work. It was the same as in other places in Poland. Judenrat was appointed by Germans and its members were threatened with death if they did not follow German orders. Judenrat selected people, they were to come at 7 o'clock and wait till Germans come to take them to various parts  of the town to perform all dirty chores like cleaning toilets, stables, etc. The sick and old did not go to work.

Apart from my forced work I also worked as a tailor. Catholics would come to me and I would make clothes for them for not much money. My mother was old so she was not taken to work. She stayed at home and sewed but later it was forbidden. 

People were hungry in Gora Kalwaria from the beginning because 80% had been very poor before W.W.II. Craftsmen were in the remaining 20%, we had maybe 5 or 6 rich people. Judenrat organized soup for the poor, whoever wanted it but it was not much.

I pan
Zmienimy
Interviewer: You were talking about the meeting with that woman.

Subject: Yes. she asked me. I mean I asked her, I begged her. And she said to me, 'Listen, I will go first. Just make sure that nobody sees you. You will come', she says, 'to my place in the evening and we will help you somehow'. So when I got to her place in the evening, there were many children. A poor household, a very poor household. But she took pity on me as we talked. I told her about it, I didn't hide my..., well, the fact that I was a Jew. I told her, 'Don't be afraid because I have a Kennkarte issued for such and such surname so not my real surname. You are not taking any risk here. You are just giving me refuge'. She was very pleased. Although they were poor, they happened to have a sewing machine at home. So I told her, 'Mrs Pokorska, that's very well. I'm a tailor by profession. When you walk home through the village and visit good friends that you have nothing to fear from, don't tell them that I'm a Jew. Tell them that a Pole from Warsaw is staying with you who is in hiding because he is a member of the resistance movement. Tell them that he can sew clothes and they can bring him clothes to sew. And we will make ends meet somehow'. She was very happy and she did as I told her to do. One day, the Germans came to the flat whether acting on a tip or by sheer chance. There was no way out. I couldn't escape. It was so unexpected. When the Germans came in, I cannot say at present whether it was divine power or it just happened like that but I wasn't afraid. I had no fear in me. I was bold with them. And I talked to them. They came in and looked at me. 'Who are you? I said, I'm that lady's son. 'Really?' 'Yes, I am'. I took my photo and put it on the table. I said, 'Look, I was supposed to go to Garwolin to have an ID card issued but I have no money at the moment and that's it'. He stared at me and saw that my face did not fit in with that place because, after all, it was a... So he turned to Mrs Pokorska and asked, 'Is this your son?'. And she replied, 'Yes, it is. And children, there are so many children at home'. Somehow I kept my cool. In general, I just wasn't afraid. I was absolutely in no fear at all. But the German didn't seem to believe us. He asked once again what I was doing there. I said 'yes' because he noticed that I had been sewing something for somebody. A coat on a hanger. And that German says in German to the other, 'How come such coat is in this flat?' [Kuk was so ein schoen Mantel ist in so ein Haus].

Subject: And I replied, 'The coat is not mine'. 'Was? Verstehen Sie Deutsch? [What? Do you understand German?]. And I play possum [?]. 'The children are not mine. The children are not mine'. And he asked me again, 'Was? Verstehen Sie Deutsch?' And I said, 'Father, my father is ill'. 'Ah, verdummter Mann' [Man, damn it!]. I knew already that I was safe. Those thoughts rash through your head. It's unbelievable. But he didn't pay attention to what I was saying but instead addressed that woman. And he asked the question in Polish because he was from Silesia. 'Is this your son?'. She replied, 'Yes, it is'. So he asked me what I did for a living. In Polish, too. So I told him, 'In summer, [he imitates the sounds made by drivers of horse-drawn carts] and in winter [he pretends to be flailing]'.

Subject: 'Ah... A farmer?' 'A farmer'. Given that he talks to me, just talks to me, I know already that I'm safe. And I keep my cool throughout. I'm very much of control of myself. At the time, we were moonshining like every poor household during the Nazi occupation. From beetroot. They came close to me and one said to the other 'kuck, kuck' [Look, look]. And I said, 'Moonshine, beetroot, red beet juice, red beet juice, red beet juice'. 'Ah, verdummter Mann' Then, they left the flat and as they were leaving I realized I could be denounced as a Jew here because people said different thingsin the village, he didn't quite look like a Jew, he does go to church but nobody visits him and he doesn't really fit with the Pokorskis, their poor house. So maybe he is a Jew in hiding. And others would say 'how could he be a Jew if he goes to church?'. And that was the version [of the story] that the people in the village believed. But whether or not I might get denounced, I said to myself if they had showed interest in me, then I could no longer live in the flat. If they were to come in again, I'd better be out... I went outside and started stacking the firewood I chopped [inaudible] for winter. While doing so I watched them.  At that point, one of them came back and asked [Mrs. Pokorska] once again, 'Is this really your son?' And she replied, 'Yes, he's my son'. Then I told her, 'If he comes back again, I'll try to run away, let him kill me then instead of….

Subject: But they never returned. When it was over, my hair stood on end. This is very characteristic. Only after they were gone did I feel fear.  After everything. That was everything already but not quite. And I have to say something. Shame on them! After all that, one month later, more or less, they came for me at night. I suspect the people from the local NSZ [National Armed Forces] or WiN [Freedom and Independence, Polish right-wing anti-Communist underground military] unit. [They asked] where I was. And Mrs. Pokorska told them I was not there. 'What do you mean he is not there? He was here today'. She said, 'He was but he is not here at the moment'. 'Don't tell him anything. We'll be back later'. It turned out that they had wanted to kill me. They got the order. I don't know from whom, whether it was from their... Let them hear it. Let them know it. I have nothing to hide here. I also had good friends in that village. They simply didn't care who I was.
Interviewer: You mean your friends from before the war?
Subject: No.
Interviewer: From that period?

Subject: From that period. The liberation was to take place in a month or two. It was in April or May, and the Red Army came in July. They said, 'Heniek, be careful because they want to liquidate you'. During that period, two men came with a gun. Me and Mrs. Pokorska, we thought hard. There was a high bed. With a wooden board on the side. The bed had no straw mattress just straw. And she told me, 'You know what, Heniek, get into the bed and cover yourself with straw and I'll put the children on top of you'. And that's what we did. They came in and started asking questions and I could hear everything that was being said. They asked about this and that. They told Mrs. Pokorska, 'Listen, you're not to tell him anything. We'll be back. He'd better be there'. She didn't say a word. 'You're lying to us, bring a shovel because you'll be digging up your own grave'. They said that to Mrs. Pokorska. She took the shovel and went out with them [inaudible]. When they saw her grab the shovel, they might actually have thought that I wasn't there. This is typical. Let the whole world know that three or four small children were there. They didn't betray me, they didn't shout, 'He's here!' and they were not afraid. As soon as they had left, I went into hiding. I no longer hid in that flat. I wandered through fields and bushes, here and there. Mrs. Pokorska only brought me food. And so I was hiding for a few months wherever I could until the arrival of the Red Army. The Red Army entered the village of Podwierzbie  either in late July, on July 29th or 30th or on August 1st. At the time, I was lying on a levee nearby. I saw their reconnaissance unit, the so-called razvedka. They were armed and they looked at me. I wasn't unshaven because Mrs. Pokorska bought razor blades for me whenever she could. I shaved.

Subject: I looked like a man. Even though malnourished and frail, I looked like a man. They asked me, 'Who are you?' And somehow I couldn't say a word either in Polish, Yiddish or Russian. After all, I had been there for a few months and I could speak some Russian. In the end, I said, 'I hid here, hid, here, I hid here'. And there happened to be a lieutenant who understood something. He was a Jew. He had an idea and he asked me, 'Who are you? Who are you?' And I said to him, 'I'm Yevrey'. The lieutenant stopped right away and told his soldiers to put down their weapons, not to keep them pointed at me. He said that they would come the following day and take me to their military commander. Bubnov [?], Major Bubnov [?], their military commander was nearby.  And, true to their word, they came the following day and took me to Bubnov. Bubnov enlisted me in the Red Army as a volnonayomniy, a non-military volunteer.  I sewed for them over a longer period of time. It was, let's say, in August, September and the offensive started in January. They kept me by their side until January, I wore an army uniform but carried no weapon, nothing, and I just sewed uniforms and clothes and everything for them.
Interviewer: In that village, right? In Podwierzbie?

Subject: Yes, in Podwierzbie. Yes, in Podwierzbie and Podleze, Podwierzbie and Podleze, a neighboring village. And I stayed there until the end, they went to the... they went, I mean, the frontline advanced and I remained in that village with Mrs. Pokorska. I lived there over a longer period of time because I didn't know, because Gora Kalwaria was still occupied, Gora Kalwaria was still under occupation so I was in no hurry. I spent a few more months there and young people from Podwierzbie were very friendly to me. They really loved me. No, I'm using that word on purpose - they loved me. Girls were in love with me, literally. They liked me very much, I walked with them until I learned that the Jews from Russia had returned to Gora Kalwaria.

Interviewer: One more thing, you said that those people from NSZ [National Armed Forces] or WiN [Freedom and Independence] [Polish right-wing anti-Communist underground military] organizations were looking for you. Which means, however, that the residents of that village either knew or suspected that you were of Jewish heritage, didn't they?

Subject: Yes, they did. Like I said, the village was divided. Of course, they knew. How could they not know? What I mean is that some said this and others said that. People are not dumb. They were aware that the holidays would come, the New Year's Eve or such and I would not go anywhere and I would always stay put. After all, I was there and Mrs. Pokorska had never mentioned that she had a cousin.  But overall they liked me and treated me well. This is the sad truth. Truth must be told about how things were. There were such incidents and I know for a fact that NSZ militants had murdered Jews. After the liberation, after everything. Let them know it. Shame on them. Nonetheless, I'm polonized. I love Poland and that's why I chose not to emigrate. The woman who kept me, that family, was awarded the Yad Vashem medal. The trees have been planted.
Interviewer: You mean you submitted the relevant application?

Subject: Yes, yes, I did. I'm in touch with that family until the present day. They respect me a lot. They call me uncle. I'm like an uncle to them. They are like a sister, like a brother to me. I respect those people. I brought them from that village to Gora Kalwaria later. They live here till the present day.
Interviewer: Where do they live?
Subject: In Gora Kalwaria.
Interviewer: They do?

Subject: Yes, they do. They have a flat here. They are all elderly persons, they are already over sixty, seventy, the brother is 70, the sister, Wladka, is over sixty, and the others, too, so they are all elderly persons.
Interviewer: I understand that when you had been liberated and, thereafter, you were in that Red Army, you did it for status?
Subject: I had no contact with them.
Interviewer: I understand. And the Warsaw Uprising broke out in August 1944?

Subject: We knew about it. We even saw the fire, very much so. But I didn't take part. They were saying, the Russians were saying, at the time, 'The uprising has started. We'll not help'. I spoke to soldiers on a number of occasions, I asked them, 'Why?' They replied, 'No, if they make an uprising, why should we go help?' That's what they said.
Interviewer: And did you have any contact with Warsaw? I mean with your family?
Subject: Absolutely not.
Interviewer: You didn't know.

Subject: Nothing. I saw nobody. I didn't even imagine that anybody could have survived the war. I didn't imagine that anybody would... After all, I saw what it was like. Any moment, every every every gesture could betray you. Every gesture could betray you as a Jew. After all, you were given a death penalty for hiding Jews. Not only one person but the whole family. There were towns and villages described, among other things, by Władysław Bartoszewski in his book titled 'The Samaritans, heroes of the Holocaust' [Ten z ojczyzny mojej], where entire families had been executed.  Those were very good people. Those were very good people. I wish to stress that once again. I'll say it again, I wish to stress that I went to Sokolka when the Soviet Army was there to buy leather for shoes and uppers. Some Jews were already there, too. There, I saw a family, a Jewish family, that had been kept hidden by a Pole. The Jew wore a chalat [Jewish frock] and was bearded, and that Pole would prepare milk and meat meals for him separately. He didn't do it for money. I don't believe that a man would ever do... something like that. He did it in the name of faith. That Pole did it in the name of humanism, in the name of faith. I talked to him. It's pity I don't know his name. He is certainly dead already because he was old at the time. I also spoke to that Jewish family. They were from Sokolka, from Sokolka, that village. I saw that Jew, that, that Jewish woman and one child with my own eyes. Two of their children died. I don't know in what circumstances. But what is characteristic is that the Pole provided shelter to Jews in that attire. It was different to hide me or another person dressed more or less like a European, a person who like me speaks good Polish. That probably involved less risk. But what what what he did was extremely risky. And still he was not afraid and claimed, 'I did it in the name of faith'. That's what that Pole said to me. Sokolka is a town somewhere in the Bialystok province, that's where the town is. It certainly is part of history, there's no doubt that it is.
Interviewer: Earlier, you talked about the meetings with your brother and sister. You said that you had met them.
Subject: In 1940. Yes, I met my brother, Unfortunately, my brother...
Interviewer: What year was it?
Subject: It was..., I was in Ostrow at the time. I was working as a tailor in somebody's workshop or at Cwyl's. He came to me because he knew that I was from that village as we used to...
Interviewer: What year was it, nineteen forty what?
Subject: In nineteen forty-three.
Interviewer: In 1943?
Subject: Yes, yes. He was wandering from one place to another.
Subject: Was it already after the uprising in the Warsaw Ghetto or earlier?
Subject: Later, later, already after the uprising. Yes, he came to me.
Interviewer: You didn't see your brother for how long? Over a year, right?

Subject: At the time? No, I saw him because he was also in that, he was in Magnuszow, he was at my place in the ghetto, too. We just didn't stay together because he went closer to Gora Kalwaria. He lived in this area here.
Interviewer: But your brother had previously been in the Warsaw ghetto?

Subject: In the Warsaw ghetto. He had escaped from the ghetto but he knew I was here. Magnuszow is in province as well so he came and we talked. And he went somewhere. He was hiding at farmhouses. He did some sewing. Well, he didn't really because he did his saddlery work. And my sister, I hadn't seen my sister until we met in Glowaczow ahead of the forced relocation.
Interviewer: Please tell us, with your brother, did your brother talk to you about the situation in the ghetto?

Subject: Yes, he did. He visited me, yes, and he came to me in 1943, maybe one or two months before his death, and we talked. And as far as, he says, as far as... I couldn't provide for him because those people barely managed to support me. It would have been different in summer but it was winter. So he left. We said goodbyes with tears in our eyes. I learned later because my neighbor told me that German Jerke had marched my brother to the cemetery and that's where they killed him, in the Jewish cemetery in Gora Kalwaria. I made a symbolic grave there for my mother, my sister and my brother. It's there. It's standing there.
Interviewer: Because you didn't see your sister afterwards?
Subject: No, I never saw my sister again.
Interviewer: I see. Let's now go back to the period when you had been liberated by the Soviet Army and stayed with them as, well, a soldier?
Subject: Yes, as a, not as a soldier.
Interviewer: As a civilian, yes.
Subject: As a regular civilian. Only I didn't have civilian clothes so they gave me a coat that I altered and wore afterward.

Interviewer: People, I mean the Jews, said that when the liberation had come, although they referred mainly to the liberation from the Germans in 1945, many of them had the feeling as if they were the only Jews left in the world.
Subject: Yes, yes, yes. Just like me.
Interviewer: You also had that feeling?

Subject: I felt the same, too. The same. Identical. In general, I didn't imagine that anybody could have hidden anywhere during the Holocaust.  The people who didn't live through the Holocaust cannot even conceive what it was like although sometimes this or that is being said, why this, why that.  Even though those camps were set up in Poland, the Poles are not to be blamed. Let those Jews once and for all... and I mean all Jews because there are also nationalists among Jews. There are even chauvinists. Let's tell each other the truth. Maybe not to the same extent as in other nations because a Jew would never assault anyone. This is another issue. But there are nationalists. They have their views. But it was not like that. Who would want to welcome the Jews if they knew, just like such Polish families did, that they risked their life? We, Jews who lived through the war, talk about it because we know it. We've seen it. I say so confidently as an elderly man because I know it. So they shouldn't be surprised that people hold grudges against this or that person. I don't want to dwell on it too long but I put the same question again to Jews, since I speak objectively, I ask all those who talk this way, would they be willing to take that risk? Would they take a Pole home knowing that … if this did not come with the death penalty?. Let me stress that word – death - because Jews coexisted very well with Poles and so did Poles with Jews before the war. They traded and had business dealings, and were happy with it. But when the death penalty comes into play - is there a higher price than death? Nevertheless, they did it, like Mrs. Pokorska who welcomed me, that mother with so many children. One, two, three, four, six children. They still chose to take that risk. I had my Kennkarte but eventually somebody could have claimed that she had known I was a Jew. If I [inaudible] am I not fond of that person till the present day? She's like a mother to me. Once it was over, I told her, 'Let me call you mother'. She's my second mother. Let Jews remember that. Those who understand this recording and who see this recording should acknowledge that fact. Let them hold no grudges. Yes, there were also shmaltsovniks [persons blackmailing the Jews who were hiding, or blackmailing Poles who protected the Jews during the Nazi occupation], there were such incidents for sure. The truth must be told because I speak objectively. I'm telling the truth. They did exist, some even hid Jews, I know one case from Ryczywol.  Two Jews were murdered there. By Poles from Ryczywol, none other.
Interviewer: How do you know that fact? How did you learn it?

Subject: How? Because they were together in Magnuszow. They were reloc... because they lived in Magnuszow. They were relocated to Kozienice, just like me. They stayed in Ryczywol. Those two because they had their businesses or such there. Nobody saw them afterward. Obviously, they denounced each other claiming that this one or that one committed the murder. Those are the facts of life. Let them hear. Ryczywol, a village near Magnuszow.
Interviewer: But you personally had no contact with shmaltsovniks? Nobody ever threatened you?

Subject: No, no. I didn't experience that. There were such persons also. They would demand money from them [Jews] and later spend it. There were instances where, after the liberation, after everything, they would keep [Jews] in hiding for two or three months, with the Red Army already there, with Poland liberated, because they stood to gain financially from the situation. There were such individual cases. That was not common, only sporadic. But, nonetheless, it happened. Unfortunately, the truth must be told.
Interviewer: I understand. Please tell us...

Subject: Therefore, I'm simply..., I'm proud that I can tell the truth. I may not be the only one to tell that truth because I read a lot. But this, unfortunately, is how it is. There was also such moment, described by Bartoszewski, when a mother, a pre-war mother at that, a convert if I'm not mistaken, had children and her children were not recognized, and she approached a teacher, a scout leader, and asked him to let her child join a local scouts organization. The man replied that it was for Polish scouts only. And Bartoszewski describes the situation. Was he right Absolutely not. And that mother denounces that fact too and she tells the truth. I say the same thing. Was he right [to say so]? Absolutely not. And that Tejkowski?  Can I talk here about...? Take that Tejkowski who makes public appearances nowadays as a sworn anti-Semite. Is he right? In my view and in the opinion of good people, he is absolutely wrong. What is the point of being against anything? If he is against Jews or those skinheads, they are against each other. They hate themselves. They fight each other with knives, bats and such. So I'm asking him the question, here during this TV interview, 'Are you right?'  Absolutely not. Isn't it better to have a positive attitude towards other people, regardless of whether that person is a Gypsy, a Pole, a Russian or a German? I even have respect for that German. He may already be dead but I have respect for him and I'll always keep him in my thoughts. If I were to see him after the war, I would certainly give him not only bread but also my bed and everything. Because he was a Germ... because he was a human being. Is this relevant? Him being German isn't relevant. He was born that way. Was my mother inferior to somebody else's mother? This is how I was born, this is who I am and will be. I'll always keep my nationality. Because I have no need whatsoever to say that I'm not a Jew.

Interviewer: So you never felt that need to, 'need' is not the right word. Let's change the subject [inaudible] During that period until 1944, the liberation, did you ever hear about concentration camps?
Subject: Yes, I did.
Interviewer: Extermination camps?
Subject: We knew everything.
Interviewer: But how?
Subject: We knew. How? Because there were individuals who had escaped. That's how we knew.
Interviewer: And they reached out to you?

Subject: Some escaped. Individual persons managed to escape from Treblinka or here. People talked. And we were not dumb. There were newspapers and underground news bulletins and we  knew about it [concentration camps].
Interviewer: Did you read them?
Subject: A few. But there were also lampoons. There were those anti-Jewish newspapers, that sword, no wait wait, of King Chrobry, King Chrobry [Boleslaw the Great], am I right?
Interviewer: Szczerbiec [the jagged sword]?
Subject: Announcement, Szczerbiec. of King Chrobry, isn't it?
Interviewer: Well, yes.
Subject: It was an anti-Jewish newspaper. There were those those those different anti-Jewish photographs.
Interviewer: Did you read it during the Nazi occupation?
Subject: I did. I was allowed to read. I saw them. My heart ached right away. Such things happening after the Holocaust?
Interviewer: Oswiecim [Auschwitz] and Majdanek. It was [all clear] to you?

Subject: Yes. We [knew] it all, I mean, maybe I hadn't known it literally or in detail because I only became familiar with the subject after the war. But it wasn't like that under the [Nazi] occupation, it wasn't defined as such. It wasn't until after everything that we learned about it, the whole truth. We knew that there were lagers, labor camps. We knew about Majdanek. We knew about Auschwitz. We knew about Treblinka.  There's no doubt about it. There was even a moment when Hungarian Jews escaped from a train car they crashed somewhere in the vicinity of Garwolin while they were being taken to Treblinka. They were all caught. They died. They all died. Germans caught some. Poles caught some.
Interviewer: And how do you know that?
Subject: Well, people talked.
Interviewer: At the time?
Subject: Word of mouth, at the time.
Interviewer: Back then.

Subject: Because there were some very good people too back then. At the time, I heard a conversation between two Poles. They didn't know I could overhear them. One Pole said to another, 'Still, I feel sorry for those Jews'. Because they talked about this and that in general. Of course, we know, unfortunately, those those those things are true, and he said, 'Still, I feel sorry for those Jews'. Because it was common knowledge that the Polish population was not rich either before the war. Peasants, in particular. They had greatly limited options. So they preferred to engage with those those Jews. When he [a Pole] came to a Jewish tailor, he was shown respect and was offered proper service. Therefore, the Pole was pleased to go to Jews. When he went to see a Polish craftsman, this was not always the case.
Interviewer: Please tell me one more thing, when the Russians marched further east, west, yes, in the direction of Warsaw, did you go with them?
Subject: No, I didn't.
Interviewer: You stayed behind?
Subject: I remained where I already was, in that village.
Interviewer: You waited until the liberation, until the end of the war?
Subject: There was general liberation, I continued to live in that village for almost one year, we all did.
Interviewer: Another year?
Subject: [inaudible] Almost a year.
Interviewer: And then you...
Subject: Only when I had learned that there were still Jews in Gora Kalwaria, I made up my mind and travelled to Gora Kalwaria.
Interviewer: You mean from that village, Podwierzybie?
Subject: Podwierzbie.
Interviewer: Podwierzbie. And, at that point, you went to Gora Kalwaria?
Subject: Yes, yes, yes.
Interviewer: What year was it? As late as 1946?
Subject: No, in 1945.
Interviewer: 1945, right?
Subject: Already after the liberation.
Interviewer: And you...
Crew member: Let's change [the tape].
Interviewer: Let's change [the tape].
Segment 15

She told me she would go first and I should be very careful so that nobody saw me and come to her place in the evening. The house was very poor and there were a lot of children. I told her I was Jewish and explained that I had a Kennkarte so she did not risk anything. She was very glad. Her name was Pokorska. There was a sewing machine in the house so I told her not to tell anybody that I was Jewish but to go to people she could trust and tell them that she was sheltering an escapee from Warsaw who had been in the underground and who could sew (and in this way we would be able to survive). She was very glad and she did this.

One day, either by accident or because someone had denounced me, I do not know, two German soldiers came into her apartment. I could not escape. They started talking to me. They were from Silesia so they spoke Polish too. I told them I was Mrs. Pokorska's son  and showed them a photograph and told them I was to go to Garwolin to obtain documents. Mrs. Pokorska confirmed that. They asked several times what my name was and  what I was doing there. I could understand what they spoke in German but  I pretended that I am a farmer and a little dumb. Finally they went away. All the time I had kept my composure and only later the fear began. I suspected that there might have been denunciation. People thought that I did not look Jewish and attended church but nobody visited me and they were also puzzled why there was such a  good-looking man in such a poor house. The  conclusion, at least for some of them, must have been that I was a Jew who were hiding. Others contradicted them that a Jew would not go to church, so the opinions were divided.
Segment 16

A month later, one night there came people who, I think, were from NSZ or WIN [NSZ- Narodowe Sily Zbrojne, a rightist Polish organization]. They asked for me and Mrs. Pokorska told them I was not there. They forbade her to tell me about their visit and they told her they would return. They wanted to kill me: I learnt about it from friends I had made in the village, people who did not care who I really was. It was close to the liberation, in April or May. The people who were looking for me came several times. Although they threatened Mrs. Pokorska with death she hid me in the bed (the one without a mattress), covered me with the straw and put her children on me. I would like everybody to know that those little children did not betray me, they lay still all the time when the men were in the house. I left the house immediately and lived hiding in the fields till the Red Army entered the village. Pokorska brought me food. 

The Red Army entered Podwierzbie at the end of July or August 1. They saw me, I was not able to say a word in any language but finally an officer who was a Jew  talked to me and I told him I was Jewish and he told me they would take me to their commandant, major Buvnov the next day. They did come the next day and I stayed in his army as a tailor. I wore the army uniform but I did not carry a gun. I stayed with them till January in Podwierzbie and Podlez till they went away to fight. I stayed in Podwierzbie because Gora Kalwaria had not been liberated yet. Young people in  Podwierzbie simply loved me, I want to stress that word. They really liked me, young girls especially. I stayed with them till I learnt that Jews had returned to Gora Kalwaria in July.
Segment 17

I know that NSZ killed Jews even after the liberation and I want them to know about it but I love Poland and therefore I have not emigrated later. On the basis of my testimony Mrs. Pokorska and her family have been awarded the medal from Yad Vashem. I have been in touch with her and her brother all the time. Later I took them to Gora Kalwaria and  they have lived there now. I respect them very much and they like me very much, the children call me "uncle".

We knew  about the Warsaw Uprising, we even saw the flames. I often talked about it with the Russian soldiers but they said they would not help.

I did not have any contacts with my family. It was still very dangerous for Jews and not only Jews were killed then. Bartoszewski describes that in his book "Ten z ojczyzny mojej"
["The One from My Fatherland"] : whole families who hid Jews were killed for that. There were a lot of good people  who helped Jews. For instance when I went to Sokolka to buy some leather  for shoes I saw a Jewish family who had lived with a Pole and the Jew was in his traditional, orthodox clothes and he had a beard. Hiding him was much more difficult then hiding a Jew like me wearing European clothes and speaking good Polish. The Pole cooked for them and he cooked dairy products and meat separately. He did not do that for money. He said he did it because he was religious. Not only did I see those Jews but I talked to them too. I regret that I do not know the name  of  that Pole and it is possible that he has already died because he was quite old at that time, but I am sure he must  have been in the history of  Sokolka. It was a couple with one child, the other two children they had  lost, I do not know how. It was a great risk to hide them dressed in traditional clothes and this Pole was not afraid of doing it. He told me he did it for the sake of his religion. Sokolka is in Bialystok region. 

I saw brother in 1943 when I stayed at Cwyl's. My brother escaped  from the Warsaw Ghetto and was hiding in the villages close to Magnuszewo working as a saddler for various families. One month or two before his death we said goodbye to each other because it was winter and I could not provide a shelter for him. Later I learnt from a neighbor that a German ?Jerke had taken him to a Jewish cemetery in Gora Kalwaria and shot him. Later I made a ?symbolic tomb there for my mother, brother and sister.
Segment 18

I was not as a soldier in the Red Army but as a civilian. I got some army clothes which I changed to fit me.

When the war ended I also had a feeling that I was nearly the  only Jew who had survived such a terrible holocaust. The people who has not experienced holocaust cannot even imagine it and  it is pure fantasizing saying that this or that should have been done. Although the camps were placed in Poland it was not Poles' fault. There were nationalists among Poles but there were nationalists, even chauvinists among Jews too. Let's tell the truth. Maybe not to such an extent as to attack other nations because a Jew will never do that. I often ask Jews if they would be willing to risk and take Poles home if they knew that they might be killed for that. Because we had to understand that Poles were punished by death, I stress death, for helping Jews. If they had not been threatened with death, it would be a different story. Poles lived very well with Jews before the W.W.II, they traded with each other, did business. Mrs. Pokorska had six  small children and yet she took the risk. I had an ID stating I was a Pole but someone still could say she knew I was Jewish.  After the W.W.II I asked her to let me call her mother because she is a second mother for me. 

I would like all Jews who would see this film to understand it and not to blame Poles. Of course I know about other facts too. I know there were "szmalcownicy" [Jew-hunters]. I also know that some Poles from Ryczywol (close to Magnuszewo) murdered two Jews. I myself did not have any contacts with Jew-hunters. I know that there were Poles who took money for hiding Jews and then betrayed them. There was a case when Poles kept Jews even after the liberation for two or three months because they wanted to get more money but these were really single cases. I am proud that I can say truth.

I would also like to say that Teykowski [a Polish nationalist, recently politically active, with a small group of followers, of little national importance] is not right. Being anti-Semitic, he and his punks are against themselves. I have respect even for this German [the one he sewed for] because he was a good man. He is probably dead now. I will always remember him. If I saw him after the war I would gave him bread or a place to sleep because he was a good man. He was simply born a German. Was my mother lower than others? I was born Jewish and I would always preserve my nationality.
Segment 19

We knew about the concentration camps because people who had escaped from them talked about it. We also read underground newspapers. Some of them were unfortunately anti-Jewish like "Szczerbiec" ["The Jagged Sword"] and I saw it and thought how they could write such things after such terrible holocaust. We did not know all the names (those we learnt after the war) but we knew that there were extermination camps. Once when Hungarian Jews escaped from a train car near Garwolin and they were caught by Germans and Poles I heard a conversation among two Poles that they pitied those Jews very much. They did not know I could hear them. There were a lot of good Poles too. Some Poles were very poor, especially farmers and they preferred to go to Jews, for instance a Jewish tailor, because he would respect and serve them as he should and if they went to Polish craftsmen it was not the  case.

When Russians who had liberated Podwierzbie went further on I did not go with them. I stayed in the village for a year and went to Gora Kalwaria in 1945 when I learnt that there were still Jews there.
